{{Infobox building | name = 425 Park Avenue | alternate_names = | building_type = Office | architectural_style = | classification = | location = | address = 425 Park Ave. | location_city = [[New York City]] | location_country = [[United States]] | coordinates = {{coord|40.760542|-73.971157|type:landmark_globe:earth_region:US-NY|display=ti}} | est_completion = 2019 | topped_out_date = | completion_date = | closing_date = | cost = $1 billion | height = 900 ft. (274.3 m) | architectural = | tip = | antenna_spire = | material = | size = | floor_area = 670,000 sq. ft. | architect = [[Foster + Partners]] }} '''425 Park Avenue''' is an office building in [[New York City]], under redevelopment by [[L&L Holding]] and [[GreenOak Real Estate]] with a redesign by architectural firm [[Foster + Partners]]. Work on the new structure began in 2016, and is expected to end in late 2019. __NOTOC__
==History== ===Construction=== L&L acquired the original structure on the site in 2002.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://nypost.com/2018/04/02/425-park-avenue-finally-nears-transformation-into-steel-and-glass-stunner/|title=425 Park Ave. finally nears transformation into steel-and-glass stunner|last=Cuozzo|first=Steve|date=2 April 2018|publisher=NY Post|accessdate=12 October 2018}}</ref> The original building was constructed in the 1950s, and contained 33 floors. Due to zoning restrictions, the new structure will contain the same number of square feet as the previous one, and will incorporate some of the original structure into its base.<ref name=comobs>{{cite news|url=https://commercialobserver.com/2018/06/under-construction-why-lls-425-park-avenue-development-was-delayed/|title=Under Construction: L&L’s 425 Park Avenue Demo Nears the Finish Line|last=La Guerre|first=Liam|date=20 June 2018|publisher=Commercial Observer|accessdate=12 October 2018}}</ref> Preserving the original structure led to difficulties during construction, requiring the developer to hire a third engineering firm.<ref name=comobs/>
As of April 2018, the building was halfway to its full height.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ny.curbed.com/2018/4/17/17248766/425-park-avenue-norman-foster-construction-update|title=Norman Foster’s Park Avenue office tower is now halfway to its pinnacle|last=Walker|first=Ameena|date=17 April 2018|publisher=Curbed|accessdate=15 October 2018}}</ref> Facade installation began in June 2018, when the building was 22 floors from topping out.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://newyorkyimby.com/2018/06/425-park-avenues-facade-installation-begins-as-construction-nears-halfway-point-midtown-east.html|title=425 Park Avenue’s Façade Installation Begins As Construction Nears Halfway Point, Midtown East|last=Nelson|first=Andrew|date=29 June 2018|publisher=YIMBY|accessdate=12 October 2018}}</ref>
===Design=== [[Ely Jacques Kahn|Kahn & Jacobs]] designed the original office building on the site. [[Modernist architecture|Modernist]] in style, it replaced a row of townhouses. It was one of the first modernist buildings on Park Avenue.
Because of zoning restrictions, a portion of the former structure was included in thew new one. L&L chose Foster + Partners to design the building after a competition to choose an architect.<ref name=yimbylong>{{cite web|url=https://newyorkyimby.com/2016/04/425-park-avenue-pioneer-of-modernism-loses-half-its-height-to-make-way-for-893-foot-tall-21st-century-beacon.html|title=425 Park Avenue, Pioneer Of Modernism, Loses Half Its Height To Make Way For 893-Foot-Tall 21st Century Beacon|last=Ogorodnikov|first=Vitali|date=8 April 2016|publisher=YIMBY|accessdate=12 October 2018}}</ref> L&L solicited bids from 11 architectural firms. These entries were narrowed to four final proposals, from [[Zaha Hadid Architects]], [[Rogers Stirk Harbour + Partners]], [[Rem Koolhaas|OMA]], and Foster + Partners. Each incorporated a portion of the original structure. Real estate news site ''YIMBY'' noted that, due to its three roughly 200-foot concrete fins, the Foster plan would have "[...] the most pronounced skyline effect" compared to the other proposals.<ref name=yimbylong/>
===Financing=== Lender HFF provided a $556 million construction loan.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://commercialobserver.com/2015/07/hffs-geoffrey-goldstein-talks-leaving-banking-for-brokering/|title=HFF’s Geoffrey Goldstein Talks Leaving Banking for Brokering|last=Ghigliotti|first=Damian|date=9 July 2015|publisher=Commercial Observer|accessdate=12 October 2018}}</ref>
===Tenants=== L&L intended not to pre-lease the building, but in early 2016, hedge fund [[Citadel LLC|Citadel]] signed a lease for 200,000 square feet across several floors, including the penthouse floor.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bisnow.com/new-york/news/office/the-priciest-lease-in-nyc-history-may-have-just-been-signed-56099|title=The Priciest Lease In NYC History May Have Just Been Signed|last=Boysen|first=Ryan|date=17 February 2016|publisher=Bisnow|accessdate=12 October 2018}}</ref><ref name=yimbylong/> At the time it was signed, it was the most expensive lease in the city's history. Delays in construction have led some to speculate that Citadel may back out of the lease, or that it was seeking temporary offices due to the delays.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bisnow.com/new-york/news/office/citadel-may-be-having-second-thoughts-on-its-lease-at-425-park-ave-89098|title=Citadel, After Signing Most Expensive NYC Office Lease Ever, Exploring Other Office Options|last=Hall|first=Miriam|date=1 June 2018|publisher=Bisnow|accessdate=12 October 2018}}</ref> L&L has asserted that the tenant will move in as planned.
The founders of restaurant Eleven Madison will open two restaurants in the building, originally announced in 2015. One will be two stories tall, in the building's base, totaling roughly 14,000 square feet. According to L&L's founder, David Levinson, the intention is for the restaurant to be "...a [[Four Seasons (restaurant)|Four Seasons]] on steroids for the 21st century".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://nypost.com/2015/06/10/this-new-restaurant-is-the-next-four-seasons/|title=Park Avenue tower will boast hot new eatery|last=Cuozzo|first=Steve|date=10 June 2015|publisher=New York Post|accessdate=12 October 2018}}</ref> The other restaurant will be open only to tenants, and will be located on the 27th floor.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ny.eater.com/2015/6/10/8756915/eleven-madison-park-daniel-humm-will-guidara-new-restaurant-park-avenue|title=Eleven Madison Park Team to Open Fine Dining Behemoth on Park Avenue|last=Preston|first=Marguerite|date=10 June 2015|publisher=Eater|accessdate=12 October 2018}}</ref> Despite construction delays, both venues are still expected to open when construction is complete as of June 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ny.eater.com/2018/7/16/17578484/will-guidara-daniel-humm-financial-district-world-trade|title=Eleven Madison Park Team Nixes Plan for Big FiDi Restaurant|last=Dai|first=Serena|date=16 July 2018|publisher=Eater NY|accessdate=15 October 2018}}</ref>
==See also== * [[List of tallest buildings in New York City]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Skyscraper office buildings in Manhattan]] [[Category:Buildings and structures under construction in the United States]] [[Category:Norman Foster buildings]] [[Category:Park Avenue]] [[Category:Midtown Manhattan]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Software | name = ActiveReports | screenshot = ActiveReports_10_Designer_in_Visual_Studio.png | caption = | developer = [[Data Dynamics]], now [[GrapeCity]] | released = | latest release version = 11<ref>[http://arhelp.grapecity.com/2016/11/18/activereports-11-faster-reporting-for-the-enterprise/ ActiveReports 11, Faster Reporting for the Enterprise]</ref> | latest release date = {{Start date and age|2016|11|15|df=yes}} | latest preview version = | latest preview date = | platform = [[Windows Forms]] / [[ASP.NET]] / [[.NET Framework|.NET]] / [[Microsoft SQL Server]] / [[HTML5]] | genre = [[Business Intelligence]], [[Business reporting|Reporting]] | license = proprietary | website = {{ URL | 1=http://activereports.grapecity.com/ }} }}
'''ActiveReports''' is a [[.NET Framework|.NET]] reporting tool used by developers of [[WinForms]], [[ASP.NET]], and [[HTML5]] applications. It was originally developed by [[Data Dynamics]], which was then acquired by [[GrapeCity]]. ActiveReports is a set of components and tools that facilitates the production of reports to display data in documents and web-based formats. It is written in managed C# code and allows [[Visual Studio]] programmers to leverage their knowledge of C# or [[Visual Basic.NET]] when programming with ActiveReports.
Among the components included with ActiveReports are exports to file formats such as [[PDF]], [[Microsoft Excel|Excel]], [[Rich Text Format|RTF]], and [[TIFF]]. The main components are a [[Visual Studio]] integrated report designer, and an API that developers use to create customized reports from a variety of data sources. ActiveReports Standard Edition also includes a Visual Query Designer, a customizable Windows Viewer control, an [[HTML5]] Viewer control, and a [[Windows Presentation Foundation|WPF]] Viewer control.
The integrated report designer handles three types of reports:
* Section Reports with banded sections like the original ActiveReports (reminiscent of [[Microsoft Access]] reports) * Page Reports with a fixed layout for forms * RDL Reports with a continuous page layout like the original Data Dynamics Reports (uses [[Report Definition Language]])
The Professional Edition of ActiveReports includes the Standard Edition tools plus an End-User Report Designer control that developers use to host the report designer in their own Microsoft Windows applications to let end users create and modify reports. It also includes a server-side ASP.NET web viewer with Flash, PDF, and HTML viewer types; ASP.NET HTTP Handlers that export reports to HTML or PDF format without custom code; a [[Microsoft Silverlight|Silverlight]] viewer; and advanced PDF encryption and rendering features.
==ActiveReports Server== ActiveReports Server is a [[Scalability|scalable]] server platform with built in [[Load balancing (computing)|load balancing]]. It provides a secure and [[Extensibility|extensible]] report server to publish reports designed in ActiveReports. A comprehensive [[Representational state transfer|RESTful API]] enables integration of the [[Responsive web design|responsive]] [[HTML5]] Report Portal for end users to view, schedule and export reports.
==Features new to version 11 <ref>https://activereports.grapecity.com/press-releases/GrapeCity-Releases-ActiveReports-11-with-Faster-Report-Rendering/</ref>== * Optimized rendering for two times faster first page load times, 1.5 times faster PDF export file generation and 60% smaller peak memory footprint. * Added composite charts to RDL and Page reports to enable merging of line, bar, and area plots on the same chart with multiple Y axes. * Added JSON data provider that allows reports to consume data from JSON files, web services and REST API. * Added CSV data provider that allows reports to consume data from comma separated, tab separated, and other plain text files. * Improved the XML data provider with an XML Query Designer with a tree view of the data. * Added an Excel import wizard that can also be an intermediary for importing layouts from other reporting tools. * Added PDF printing pre-sets and optimized the PDF export for shorter export times and smaller output files. * Added galley mode to the HTML5 viewer so that wide and long reports can be viewed as a single, scrollable sheet. * Added new properties to the API: PageReportDesignerActions (End User Designer), OverwriteOutputFile (rendering extensions), and OptimizeStatic (PDF). * Added the Micro QR Code symbology to the barcode control.
==Features new to version 10 <ref>http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/grapecity-releases-activereports-10-with-a-new-tablix-data-region-and-style-sheets-300179098.html</ref>== * Replaced the Matrix with the new Tablix data region to allow users to create stepped matrices, merge cells vertically, and use multiple adjacent row and column groupings. * Added the Word rendering extension for [[Office Open XML|DOCX]] format exports. * Added style sheets for [[Report Definition Language|RDL]] and Page reports. * Improved integration between ActiveReports Server and the developer version of ActiveReports so that developers can execute reports on the server and use shared data sets. * Created a new lighter layout engine for faster rendering and fewer formatting and layout challenges.
==Features new to version 9 <ref>http://www.componentone.com/SuperPages/PressReleases/?newsID=128</ref>== * Added Layers, groups of controls that you can lock or unlock, add or remove, show or hide for complex layouts. * Added the Visual Query Designer, a graphical interface that allows users to interactively build queries and view the results. * Added the Table of Contents control to display an organized hierarchy of report headings and labels along with their page numbers in the body of a report. * Improved Excel Rendering Engine for better exporting performance and precise layout accuracy. * Added independent rounded corners for Shape and CrossSectionBox controls in Section Reports. * Added support for mouse-controlled resize handlers for overflow areas in Page Reports. * Improved reporting engine for better performance and smaller memory footprints.
==Features new to version 8 <ref>http://www.componentone.com/SuperPages/PressReleases/?newsID=116</ref>== * Added touch support for the Windows and WPF Viewer. * Added the Maps report item for spatial and analytical geographical representation of data with support for views, projections, vector layers, and Virtual Earth tile layers from the Microsoft Bing service. * Added the HTML5 viewer with touch and gesture support. * Updated reporting engine optimized for speed. * Expanded barcode support for GS1 Composite symbology including RSS14Stacked and RSSLimited barcode styles, and added MicroPDF417 options to control compaction and segments. * Added ActiveReports Server as an optional add-on that supports multi-tenant reporting, security extensibility, data caching, and report optimization features.
==Features new to version 7, service pack 1 <ref>http://www.componentone.com/SuperPages/PressReleases/?newsID=106</ref>== * Added a WPF Report Viewer. * Added a PDF/A export option for report archiving.
==Features new to version 7 <ref>http://www.componentone.com/SuperProducts/ActiveReports/Features/#ar7</ref>== * Added Page-Based Reports with advanced data regions including charts, tables, and crosstabs that can be mixed within the same report section, eliminating the need to use subreports in most instances. * Table Control * Matrix Control * Support for Visual Studio 2012 * Advanced Printing Support: Scale pages, add page watermarks, print multiple report pages on a single sheet (N-up). * Persistent Licensing makes the installed system remain licensed until the license is manually deactivated, making upgrade to maintenance releases easier.
==Features new to version 6== Latest Service Releases * [[Microsoft Silverlight]] Report Viewer * [[Windows Azure]] reporting in partial trust and full trust modes * [[ASP.NET]] medium trust support * Support for [[Visual Studio]] 2010 * Support for [[.NET Framework]] 4.0 Client profile * Utility to convert from Crystal Reports (2005 and 2008) to ActiveReports
Standard Edition * Cross-section box and line controls that span report sections * Quality and performance improvements * New [[GS1 DataBar|Reduced Space Symbology (RSS)]] barcode styles * External style sheets * Designer snap lines * Granular control over text boxes and labels * 64 bit support also support for various things
==Features new to version 3==
ActiveReports Designer * Design-time preview tab * Component tray for design-time work with .NET data providers * Report Explorer support for parameters and calculated fields * Design-time support for custom parameters * Design-time unbound fields
Windows Forms Viewer * Users can add annotations * Linked reports open in tabbed pages * Web links open within the viewer
Reporting Engine * Chart control supports seven new chart types ** Funnel ** Pyramid ** Gantt ** Kagi ** Point and figure ** Renko ** Three line break * ReportInfo control for page N of M or report run dates
==Features== <gallery> File:ActiveReports_(charts_control_panel).jpg|A number of the chart types supported in the Chart control. File:ActiveReports_Designer.png|The ActiveReports designer as it appears in Visual Studio, with important areas labeled. </gallery>
==Professional Edition==
Includes all of the Standard Edition features, and adds the following:.
End-User Report Designer * Allows developers to host the designer in Windows Forms applications * Provides end-user report editing capabilities * Provides easy access for saving and loading report layouts * Allows developers to monitor and control the end user's design environment * Allows developers to customize the designer to the needs of end users
ASP.NET * WebViewer control with Flash, HTML and PDF viewer types can be used on ASP.NET pages * Allows quick viewing of ActiveReports on the web * Provides printing capability with the Flash viewer and Acrobat Reader * Provides an RPX HTTP Handler so that reports on the web server are available via hyperlink and are run and displayed in HTML or PDF * Provides a Compiled Report HTTP Handler so that reports compiled in an assembly on the server are available via hyperlink
==Supported document formats== * [[Adobe Portable Document]] Format (*.pdf); * [[HTML]] Web Page (*.html); * [[MHTML]] Single-File Web Page (*.mht); * [[Rich Text Format]] (*.rtf); * [[Microsoft Excel]] Workbook (*.xls); * [[Plain text|Plain Text]] (*.txt); * [[Comma-Separated Values]] (*.csv); * Image formats: (*.[[BMP file format|bmp]], *.[[JPEG|jpeg]], *.[[GIF|gif]], *.[[Tagged Image File Format|tiff]], *.[[Portable Network Graphics|png]], *.[[Enhanced Metafile|emf]]).
==Included report items== * SubReport * Chart * Text Box * Label * Line * Picture * Check Box * Page Break * Report Information * Rich Text Box * Shape * Bar Code * Cross Section Line * Cross Section Box * OLE Object * 3rd party controls (charts, grids, calendars, etc.) * Matrix * Table * Banded List * Bullet * Calendar * Container * Formatted Text * Map * Overflow Placeholder * Sparkline * Table of Contents
==Awards and recognitions==
May 15, 2015 - [[SD Times|SD Times 100]] GrapeCity wins Best In Show in the User Experience category<ref>[http://sdtimes.com/sdtimes-100/2015/best-in-show/user-experience-2015/ 2015 SD Times 100 Winner]</ref>
February 27, 2015 - Ranked #6 in the ComponentSource Bestselling Product Awards for 2014-2015<ref>[https://www.componentsource.com/help-support/publisher/awards-2014-2015-product Ranked #6 in the ComponentSource Bestselling Product Awards for 2014-2015]</ref>
May 15, 2014 - [[SD Times|SD Times 100]] GrapeCity (dba ComponentOne) wins Best In Show in the User Experience category<ref>[http://sdtimes.com/sdtimes-100/2014/best-in-show/user-experience-2014/ 2014 SD Times 100 Winner]</ref>
February 28, 2014 - Ranked #5 in the ComponentSource Bestselling Product Awards for 2013-2014<ref>[https://www.componentsource.com/help-support/publisher/awards-2013-2014-product Ranked #5 in the ComponentSource Bestselling Product Awards for 2013-2014]</ref>
October 15, 2013 - Other Hot Products recognition in Best Microsoft Windows Development Printing/Reporting Tool of 2013<ref>[http://devproconnections.com/development/best-microsoft-windows-development-printingreporting-tool-2013 Other Hot Products recognition in Best Microsoft Windows Development Printing/Reporting Tool of 2013]</ref>
May 15, 2013 - [[SD Times|SD Times 100]] GrapeCity wins Best In Show in the User Experience category<ref>[http://sdtimes.com/sdtimes-100/2013/best-in-show/user-experience/ 2013 SD Times 100 Winner]</ref>
May 15, 2013 - [[SD Times|SD Times 100]] GrapeCity wins Best In Show in the APIs, Libraries & Frameworks category<ref>[http://sdtimes.com/sdtimes-100/2013/best-in-show/apis-libraries-frameworks/ 2013 SD Times 100 Winner]</ref>
February 27, 2013 - Ranked #4 in the ComponentSource Bestselling Product Awards for 2012-2013<ref>[http://www.componentsource.com/services/publisher/awards-2012-2013-product.html Ranked #4 in the ComponentSource Bestselling Product Awards for 2012-2013]</ref>
May 15, 2012 - [[SD Times|SD Times 100]] GrapeCity wins Best In Show in the Libraries & Frameworks category<ref>[http://sdtimes.com/sdtimes-100/2012/best-in-show/libraries-frameworks/ 2012 SD Times 100 Winner]</ref>
April 30, 2012 - Ranked #11 in the ComponentSource Bestselling Product Awards for 2011-2012<ref>[http://www.componentsource.com/services/publisher/awards-2011-2012-product.html Ranked #11 in the ComponentSource Bestselling Product Awards for 2011-2012]</ref>
May 15, 2011 - [[SD Times|SD Times 100]] GrapeCity wins Best In Show in the Components category<ref>[http://sdtimes.com/sdtimes-100/2011/best-in-show/components-2011/ 2011 SD Times 100 Winner]</ref>
February 28, 2011 - Ranked #6 in the ComponentSource Bestselling Product Awards for 2010-2011<ref>[http://www.componentsource.com/services/publisher/awards-2010-2011-product.html Ranked #6 in the ComponentSource Bestselling Product Awards for 2010-2011]</ref>
November 29, 2010 - Finalist in the 2010 Best of Connections Awards: Visual Studio Developer Products<ref>[http://devproconnections.com/aspnet/2010-best-connections-awards-aspnet-and-visual-studio-developer-products Finalist in the 2010 Best of Connections Awards: Visual Studio Developer Products]</ref>
May 15, 2010 - [[SD Times|SD Times 100]] GrapeCity wins Best In Show in the Components & Libraries category<ref>[http://sdtimes.com/sdtimes-100/2010/best-in-show/components-libraries-2010/ 2010 SD Times 100 Winner]</ref>
March 26, 2010 - Ranked #7 in the ComponentSource Bestselling Product Awards for 2009-2010<ref>[http://www.componentsource.com/services/publisher/awards-2009-2010-product.html Ranked #7 in the ComponentSource Bestselling Product Awards for 2009-2010]</ref>
May 7, 2009 - Finalist in the 2009 asp.netPRO Readers' Choice Awards<ref>[http://community.devproconnections.com/blogs/windowsdevpro/archive/2009/05/07/94439.aspx Finalist in the 2009 asp.netPRO Readers' Choice Awards]</ref>
March 13, 2009 - Ranked #4 and #5 in the 2008 ComponentSource Bestselling Publishers List<ref>[http://www.componentsource.com/services/publisher/awards-2008-publisher.html Ranked# 4 and #5 in the 2008 ComponentSource Bestselling Publishers List]</ref>
March 13, 2009 - Ranked #2 in the 2008 ComponentSource Bestselling Products List<ref>[http://www.componentsource.com/services/publisher/awards-2008-product.html Ranked #2 in the 2008 ComponentSource Bestselling Products List]</ref>
February 9, 2009 - ActiveReports Customers Give .NET Reporting and BI Tools High Ratings <ref>[http://www.pr-inside.com/grapecity-data-dynamics-customers-give-r1049000.htm ActiveReports Customers Give .NET Reporting and BI Tools High Ratings] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120229092747/http://www.pr-inside.com/grapecity-data-dynamics-customers-give-r1049000.htm |date=February 29, 2012 }}</ref>
June 2, 2008 - SD Times 100 Finalist in the Components category<ref>[http://www.sdtimes.com/content/article.aspx?ArticleID=32287 2008 SD Times 100 Finalist]</ref>
May 15, 2007 - SD Times 100 Finalist in the Components category<ref>[http://www.sdtimes.com/content/article.aspx?ArticleID=31720 2007 SD Times 100 Finalist]</ref>
February 9, 2007 - 2006 ComponentSource Bestselling Publisher<ref>[http://www.componentsource.com/services/publisher/awards-2006-publisher.html 2006 ComponentSource Bestselling Publisher Winner]</ref>
February 9, 2007 - 2006 ComponentSource Bestselling Product<ref>[http://www.componentsource.com/services/publisher/awards-2006-product.html 2006 ComponentSource Bestselling Product Winner]</ref>
May 15, 2006 - [[SD Times|SD Times 100]] Winner in the Components category<ref>[http://www.sdtimes.com/content/article.aspx?ArticleID=31719 2006 SD Times 100 Winner]</ref>
==Known Issues==
In the past, ActiveReports was known to be unable to handle large reports.<ref>http://forums.asp.net/p/1454550/3327154.aspx?Re+System+Out+of+Memory+Exception+active+reports+asp+net+C+</ref> This issue was ongoing across years and versions.<ref>http://arhelp.grapecity.com/groups/topic/approach-to-building-a-large-report/#post-502669</ref><ref>https://stackoverflow.com/questions/9365434/pdf-tmp-file-are-not-deleted-and-out-of-memory-exception-when-cachetodisk-is-us</ref> Since that time, development efforts have focused on improving large report handling in every release.
ActiveReports can be used in many ways, so each project can have a number of reasons for consuming memory. In newer versions, CacheToDisk and CacheToDiskLocation properties were added for PDF exports. Some other considerations that may cause too much memory use in section reports include:<ref>http://arhelp.grapecity.com/webhelp/AR10/index.html#OptimizingActiveReports.html</ref>
* Large or repeated images on every page * Subreports in repeating sections instantiated in the wrong event so that many new instances are created instead of one * Summaries in header sections that delay rendering * Report and Document object instances not released from memory
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * {{ Official website | 1=http://www.gcactivereports.com/ }} * [http://www.gcactivereports.com/Products/ActiveReportsServer/ ActiveReports Server] * [http://www.datadynamics.com/solution-briefs/Microsoft/Visual-Studio-ActiveReports.pdf Microsoft Solution Brief on ActiveReports Suite] * [http://www.componentone.com/newimages/PressCenter/CaseStudy/GCPTCaseStudies/ActiveReports-PrecisionBI.pdf Microsoft Case Study on ActiveReports Suite] * [http://www.componentsource.com/services/publisher/awards-2012-2013-product.html ActiveReports Bestselling Product Awards at ComponentSource] * [http://www.eggheadcafe.com/articles/20040619.asp EggheadCafe for .NET developers on ActiveReports] * [http://www.igloocoder.com/1763/crystal-reports-vs-active-reports Crystal Reports vs ActiveReports] * [http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20110131006488/en Business Wire:GrapeCity ActiveReports 6 Adds Support for Silverlight Reporting and Enhances Windows Azure Reporting] * [http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20090923005390/en Business Wire:GrapeCity Announces New Upgrade-To-Suite Options for ActiveReports Customers; New Hot Fix for ActiveReports 6] * [http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20090805005430/en Business Wire:GrapeCity Releases ActiveReports 6, Latest Version of the Premier .NET Framework Reporting Tool for Microsoft Visual Studio] * [http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20090430005417/en Business Wire Press Release:GrapeCity-Data Dynamics Announces New ActiveReports/BI Suite for .NET] * [http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20081020005865/en Business Wire Press Release:GrapeCity acquires Data Dynamics]

revision.text:
{{inline|date=November 2018}}{{onesource|date=November 2018}} [[Image:VictoriaBridgeHotelDamascus.jpg|thumb|right|300px|The Victoria Bridge and Hotel over the River [[Barada]] in the 1870s. The Victoria Hotel in Damascus, the largest tourist hotel in Syria at the time was owned by Abid]] '''Ahmad Izzat Basha Al-Abed''' (1851 - 1924) (أحمد عزت العابد) was a [[Syria|Syrian]] [[politician]].
Abid was born in [[Damascus]], but he was educated in [[Beirut]]. He spoke [[Arabic]], [[French language|French]] and [[Turkish language|Turkish]]. He moved to [[Istanbul]] where he served the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] sultan, [[Abdul Hamid II]] as an adviser. He left the Ottoman Empire in 1908 and moved to [[London]] for some time before living in [[France]] and [[Switzerland]]. He then left for [[Egypt]], where he died in 1924.
Abid accumulated great wealth during his life. He was also a businessman and owned numerous enterprises or buildings including the largest tourist hotel in Syria, the Victoria Hotel in Damascus.
He was the father of [[Mohammed Ali Bay al-Abid]], who served as [[List of Presidents of Syria|president of Syria]] from 11 June 1932 until 21 December 1936.
== Bibliography == *{{cite book |last=Commins |first=David Dean |date=2004 |title=" Abid, Ahmad Izzat al- (1851-1924) ", Historical Dictionary of Syria |url=https://books.google.fr/books?hl=fr&id=_EhACvcqVXkC&dq=%22Ahmad+Izzat+al-Abid%22&q=%22ABID%2C+AHMAD+IZZAT+AL-+%281851-1924%29%22#v=snippet&q=%22ABID%2C%20AHMAD%20IZZAT%20AL-%20%281851-1924%29%22&f=false |publisher=Scarecrow Press |edition=2nd |page=21-22 |isbn=9780810849341 |access-date= }}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Abid, Ahmad}} [[Category:1851 births]] [[Category:1924 deaths]] [[Category:Syrian businesspeople]] [[Category:Political people of the Ottoman Empire]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox nobility|type | name = Alfred Wojciech Potocki | title = | image = File:POL COA Potocki Hrabia.svg | caption = | alt = | CoA = [[Pilawa coat of arms|Pilawa]] | more = no | reign = | reign-type = | predecessor = | successor = | suc-type = | succession = | spouse = Princess [[Józefina Maria Czartoryska]] | spouse-type = Wife | issue = [[Alfred Józef Potocki]]
[[Ewa Józefina Julia Potocka]]
Zofia Ewa Potocka | issue-link = | issue-pipe = | full name = | styles = | titles = | noble family = [[Potocki family|Potocki]] | house-type = Szlachta | father = Count [[Jan Potocki]] | mother = Princess [[Julia Lubomirska (1764–1794)|Julia Lubomirska]] | birth_date = 3 March 1786 | birth_place = Paris | christening_date = | christening_place = | death_date = 23 December 1862 | death_place = [[Łańcut]] | burial_date = | burial_place = | occupation = }} Count '''Alfred Wojciech Potocki''' hr. [[Pilawa coat of arms|Pilawa]] (1785–1862) was a [[Poland|Polish]] nobleman ([[szlachcic]]), landowner, political and economic activist.{{Cite web |url=http://genealogia.grocholski.pl/gd/osoba.php?id=003246 |title=Archived copy |access-date=2013-12-16 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160421012542/http://genealogia.grocholski.pl/gd/osoba.php?id=003246 |archive-date=2016-04-21 |dead-url=yes |df= }}http://www.sejm-wielki.pl/b/3.662.587 Alfred was the 1st [[Ordynat]] of [[Łańcut]] estates. From 1809 until 1815 he served in the [[Polish Army]]. In 1812 he became [[aide-de-camp]] of Prince [[Józef Antoni Poniatowski]] and participated in [[Napoleon]]'s campaign against Russia. In 1838 he created the Łańcut [[Ordynacja]]. Since 1861 Alfred was member of the National [[Sejm]] in [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galicia]], and member of the [[Imperial Council (Austria)#House of Lords|Herrenhaus]]. He served as Austrian councillor and was Great Galician [[Ochmistrz]]. Alfred helped to modernize the agriculture in Galicia. He founded textile (1839–1844) and sugar (1836 industries and 1841) factories. He was co-founder of the "Estate Credit Society" in [[Lwów]]. Since 1823 he ran the [[Lubomirski]] family distillery in [[Łańcut]], which exists today under the name [[Polmos Łańcut]]. His father was the writer [[Jan Potocki]], best known for his famous novel ''"[[The Manuscript Found in Saragossa]]"''. His brother was Count [[Artur Potocki]] (1787–1832), who married Countess [[Zofia Branicka]]. ==Marriage and issue== Alfred Wojciech married Princess [[Józefina Maria Czartoryska]] on 21 June 1814 and had four children: * Count [[Alfred Józef Potocki]] (1817 or 1822–1889), married Princess [[Maria Klementyna Sanguszko]] * Countess [[Ewa Józefina Julia Potocka]] (1818–1895), married [[Prince Franz de Paula of Liechtenstein]] * Countess Zofia Ewa Potocka (1820–1882), married Count [[Dietrichstein|Moritz von Dietrichstein]] (1801–1852) ==Bibliography== * Polski Słownik Biograficzny t. 27 s. 760 ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Potocki, Alfred Wojciech}} [[Category:1785 births]] [[Category:1862 deaths]] [[Category:Counts of Poland]] [[Category:Polish Army officers]] [[Category:Polish businesspeople]] [[Category:Polish politicians]] [[Category:Potocki family|Alfred Wojciech Potocki]] {{Poland-noble-stub}} {{Poland-business-bio-stub}}

{{Infobox company | name = Alteryx, Inc. | logo = Alteryx logo.png | logo_caption = Alteryx company logo from 2014 | former_name = {{ubl|class=nowrap | SRC, LLC | {{small|(1997-2010)}} | Alteryx, LLC | {{small|(2010-2011)}} }} | type = [[Public company|Public]] | traded_as = {{NYSE|AYX}} (Class A)
[[Russell 2000 Index|Russell 2000 Component]] | industry = [[Software|Computer software]] | foundation = {{ubl|'''SRC, LLC''' in {{start date and age|1997|03}}|'''Alteryx, LLC''' in {{start date and age|2010|03}}|'''Alteryx, Inc.''' in {{start date and age|2011|03}}}} | founder = {{ubl|class=nowrap| | Dean A. Stoecker | Olivia Duane Adams | Ned Harding }} | location = [[Irvine, California]], United States | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = {{ubl|class=nowrap | Dean A. Stoecker | {{small|(Chairman & CEO)}} | Kevin Rubin | {{small|(CFO)}} }} | revenue = {{nowrap|{{increase}} US$ 131.61 million {{small|(2017)}}}} | operating_income = {{nowrap|{{increase}} US$ -18.20 million {{small|(2017)}}}} | net_income = {{nowrap|{{increase}} US$ -17.50 million {{small|(2017)}}}} | assets = {{nowrap|{{increase}} US$ 291.42 million {{small|(2017)}}}} | equity = {{nowrap|{{increase}} US$ 153.50 million {{small|(2017)}}}} | num_employees = {{nowrap|699 {{small|(2018)}}}} | homepage = {{URL|https://www.alteryx.com/|Alteryx.com}} | footnotes = {{cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1689923/000119312518073878/d530988d10k.htm|title=US SEC: Form 10-K Alteryx, Inc.|publisher=[[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]]|accessdate=April 3, 2018}} }} '''Alteryx''' is an American [[computer software]] company based in [[Irvine, California]],{{Cite news|url=https://stocknewstimes.com/2018/06/18/veeva-systems-veev-and-alteryx-ayx-financial-contrast.html|title=Comparing Veeva Systems (VEEV) & Alteryx (NYSE:AYX)|last=Steele|first=Andrew|date=2018-06-18|work=StockNewsTimes|access-date=2018-06-19|language=en-US}} with a development center in [[Broomfield, Colorado]].{{cite news |newspaper=Denver Post |date=31 July 2015 |first=Alicia |last=Wallace |title=Data analytics firm Alteryx moves to larger space in Broomfield |url= http://www.denverpost.com/business/ci_28568470/data-analytics-firm-alteryx-moves-larger-space-broomfield}}{{cite news |newspaper=BizWest |date=6 October 2014 |first=Joshua |last=Lindenstein |title=Alteryx Inc. nets $60 million in funding |url= http://bizwest.com/alteryx-inc-nets-60-million-funding/}} The company's products are used for [[data science]] and [[analytics]].{{cite news |newspaper=Fortune|date=6 October 2014 |first=Heather |last=Clancy |title=Another day, another $60 million analytics funding round |url= http://fortune.com/2014/10/06/alteryx-60-million-funding/}}{{cite news|newspaper=Daily Camera |title= Boulder's Alteryx Inc. raises $60 million |first=Alicia |last=Wallace |url= http://www.dailycamera.com/boulder-business/ci_26676831/boulders-alteryx-inc-raises-60-million |date=7 October 2014}} The software is designed to make advanced analytics accessible to any data worker.{{cite web |first=Kevin |last=Fogarty |website=InformationWeek |url= http://www.informationweek.com/big-data/big-data-analytics/when-big-data-questions-cant-wait-for-data-scientists/d/d-id/1105965?|date=24 August 2012 |title=When Big Data Questions Can't Wait For Data Scientists}} == History == SRC LLC, the predecessor to Alteryx, was founded in 1997 by Dean Stoecker, Olivia Duane Adams and Ned Harding.{{cite news|title=SAP Ventures invests $6M in Alteryx Inc.|first=Steven|last=Brown|newspaper=San Francisco Business Times|date=5 April 2011|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/news/2011/04/05/sap-ventures-invests-6m-in-alteryx-inc.html}} SRC developed the first online data engine for delivering demographic-based mapping and reporting shortly after being founded.{{cite press release |title=SRC Corporate Overview |url= http://src.mediaroomshowcase.com/file.php/2441/SRC+backgrounder.pdf |accessdate=2014-10-16}} In 1998, SRC released Allocate, a data engine incorporating geographically organized [[United States Census|U.S. Census]] data{{cite web |title= ExtendTheReach.Com / Products / SoloCast |url= http://www.extendthereach.com/products/allocate |archivedate=8 February 2003 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030208021200/http://www.extendthereach.com/products/allocate/}} that allows users to manipulate, analyze and map data.{{cite news |title=Census deal for O.C. firm |first=Jan |last=Norman |newspaper=The Orange County Register |date=17 July 2001}} Solocast was developed in 1998, which was software that allowed customers to do customer segmentation analysis. In 2000, SRC LLC entered into a contract with the [[U.S. Census Bureau]] that resulted in a modified version of its Allocate software being included on [[CD-ROMs]] of [[United States Census|Census Data]] sold by the [[U.S. Census Bureau|Bureau]].{{cite news|date=5 July 2001|newspaper=Daily Camera|title=SRC organizing census data}} In 2006, the software product Alteryx was released, which was a unified spatial and non-spatial data environment for building analytical processes and applications. In 2010, SRC LLC changed its name to that of its core product, Alteryx. In 2011, Alteryx raised $6 million in venture funding from the [[Palo Alto, California|Palo Alto]] investment arm of [[SAP AG]], SAP Ventures. In 2013, Alteryx raised $12 million from SAP Ventures and [[Toba Capital]].{{cite news|date=18 May 2013|first=Chris|last=Casacchia|newspaper=Orange County Business Journal|title=Toba in $12M Round for Big Data Analytics Firm}}{{cite web|website=TechCrunch|title=Alteryx Raises $12M For Data Analytics Platform That Shapes Data Into Apps|url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/05/20/819570/}} In 2014, the company raised $60 million in Round B funding from [[Insight Venture Partners]], [[SAP AG|SAP Ventures]] and Toba Capital, and announced plans for a 30% workforce expansion. In 2015, Iconiq Capital led a $85 million investment in Alteryx, with [[Insight Venture Partners]] and [[Meritech Capital Partners]] also participating. Alteryx announced plans to use the new capital to expand internationally, invest in research and development, and increase its sales and marketing efforts.{{Cite news|title = Iconiq Capital Leads $85 Million Investment in Alteryx|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/29/business/dealbook/iconiq-capital-leads-85-million-investment-in-alteryx.html|newspaper = The New York Times|date = 2015-10-28|access-date = 2015-10-28|issn = 0362-4331|first = Leslie|last = Picker}}{{cite news|title = Data firm Alteryx secures $85M investment, could make "unicorn" list|url = http://www.ocregister.com/articles/company-689558-alteryx-customers.html|newspaper = Orange County Register|date = 2015-10-28|first = Lauren|last = Williams}} Alteryx announced in 2015 a new relationship with [[Microsoft]] in order to enable faster and easier data analysis through [[Power BI]].{{Cite web|url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/alteryx-microsoft-corp-join-forces-120000713.html|title=Alteryx And Microsoft Corp. Join Forces To Accelerate Data Blending And Advanced Analytics For Business Analysts|website=Yahoo Finance|access-date=2016-10-04}} In 2016, Alteryx was ranked #24 on the [[Forbes|Forbes Cloud 100]] list.{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/cloud100/|title=Forbes Cloud 100|publisher=[[Forbes]]|accessdate=17 November 2016}} On March 24, 2017, Alteryx went public launching their [[IPO]] at the [[NYSE]].[http://www.investors.com/news/technology/alteryx-ipo-drawing-strong-interest-taps-into-hot-data-analytics-field Alteryx IPO] On February 22, 2018, Alteryx was named a leader in the 2018 Magic Quadrant for Data Science and Machine Learning Platforms. {{cite news|last1=Piatetsky,|first1=Gregory|title=Gainers and Losers in Gartner 2018 Magic Quadrant for Data Science and Machine Learning Platforms|url=https://www.kdnuggets.com/2018/02/gartner-2018-mq-data-science-machine-learning-changes.html|accessdate=February 26, 2018|publisher=KDnuggets}} == Products == Alteryx currently offers four main products as part of an analytics platform: Alteryx Connect, Alteryx Designer, Alteryx Promote{{cite news|last1=Guess|first1=A.R.|title=Alteryx Alters Data Science with New Release|url=http://www.dataversity.net/alteryx-alters-data-science-new-release/|accessdate=March 9, 2018|publisher=Davaversity}} and Alteryx Server. Alteryx also hosts a cloud-based website known as the Alteryx Analytics Gallery.{{cite journal|magazine=Businessweek|title=You Too Can Be Nate Silver|url=http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2012-11-09/you-too-can-be-nate-silver|date=9 November 2012|first=Ashlee|last=Vance}}{{cite web|website=TechCrunch|title=Alteryx Opens Big Data-Analytics Apps Studio For The Rest Of Us|url=https://techcrunch.com/2012/10/07/alteryx-opens-big-data-analytics-apps-studio-for-the-rest-of-us/}}{{cite web|website=Alteryx|title=Data Blending and Advanced Analytics|url=http://www.alteryx.com/products}} ==Awards and Recognition== Alteryx was recognized by research firm [[Gartner]] as a leader in the 2018 Magic Quadrant for Data Science and Machine Learning Platforms{{cite web|title=2018 Magic Quadrant for Data Science and Machine Learning Platforms|url=https://www.gartner.com/doc/3860063/magic-quadrant-data-science-machinelearning|website=Gartner.com|publisher=Gartner|accessdate=April 21, 2018}}. In addition, Alteryx was named the Gold winner in "The Best Business Intelligence and Analytics Software of 2017{{cite web|title=Magic Quadrant for Data Science and Machine-Learning Platforms|url=https://www.gartner.com/reviews/customer-choice-awards/business-intelligence-analytics-platforms|website=Gartner.com|publisher=Gartner}}, as Reviewed by Customers” by Gartner Peer Insights, a comprehensive platform that provides unfiltered, first-hand product and service ratings and reviews by experienced Enterprise Technology Buyers. Alteryx has also been named one of Deloitte’s Technology Fast 500{{cite web|title=Deloitte’s Technology Fast 500TM|url=https://www2.deloitte.com/us/en/pages/technology-media-and-telecommunications/articles/fast500-winners.html|website=www2.deloitte.com|publisher=Deloitte}} and a Top 20 AI All-Stars in Technology{{cite web|author=Krause, Reinhardt|title=This Artificial Intelligence All-Star List Has A Few Surprises|url=https://www.investors.com/news/technology/keybanc-artificial-intelligence-all-star-list-has-surprising-names/|website=Investors.com|publisher=Investor's Business Daily|accessdate=30 Apr 2018}} by KeyBanc Capital Markets. In 2017, co-founder and CEO Dean Stoecker received the Ernst and Young Entrepreneur of The Year 2017 Award{{cite web|title=Ernst and Young Entrepreneur of the Year 2017 Award|url=http://www.ey.com/us/en/about-us/entrepreneurship/entrepreneur-of-the-year/oc-2017-regional-winners|website=Ernst and Young|publisher=Ernst and Young|accessdate=April 21, 2018}} in the Orange County Region, which recognizes entrepreneurs who excel in areas such as innovation, financial performance and personal commitment to their businesses and communities. Alteryx was also named as one of the Best Places to Work in Orange County three years in a row. 2016,{{cite journal|title=2016 Best Places to Work in Orange County|journal=Orange County Business Journal|date=May 2016|url=http://www.bestplacestoworkoc.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=67&Itemid=1}} 2017,{{cite journal|title=2017 Best Places to Work in Orange County|journal=Orange County Business Journal|date=May 2017|url=http://bestplacestoworkoc.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=69&Itemid=1}} and 2018,{{cite news |title=2018 "Best Places to Work in Orange County" |url=http://www.bestplacestoworkoc.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=71&Itemid=1 |accessdate=24 July 2018 |publisher=Orange Country Business Journal |date=24 July 2018}} ranking within the top ten in the large employer category. Kevin Rubin was recognized as the CFO of the Year by the Orange County Business Journal,{{cite journal|title=CFO of the Year|journal=Orange Country Business Journal|date=Feb 15, 2018|url=http://www.ocbj.com/news/2018/feb/15/business-journal-fetes-five-cfos/}} an annual award that recognizes Orange County CFOs who demonstrated superior leadership and corporate stewardship in the preceding fiscal year. ==Data== In October 2017, it was discovered that Alteryx was subject to a data breach of partially anonymized data records for approximately 123 million U.S. households. While no names were attached, telephone numbers and physical addresses were among the 248 fields per household involved in the breach. Also included was "consumer demographics, life event, direct response, property, and mortgage information for more than 235 million consumers" according to the company.[https://www.forbes.com/sites/thomasbrewster/2017/12/19/120m-american-households-exposed-in-massive-consumerview-database-leak/#6de7226f7961] Alteryx assembled information from [[Experian]] and public sources like the [[United States Census Bureau|U.S. Census Bureau]] to create their product which sold for {{dollarsign|US}}39,000 per license. Alteryx's hosting on [[Amazon Web Services]] had been unsecured (its sources had no breach).{{cite news|url=http://fortune.com/2017/12/22/experian-data-breach-alteryx-amazon-equifax/|title=Data Breach Exposes 123 Million U.S. Households|author=Hackett, Robert|date=December 22, 2017|accessdate=December 23, 2017|publisher=Fortune: Time, Inc.}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.alteryx.com Alteryx website] * {{Finance links | name = Alteryx, Inc. | symbol = AYX | sec_cik = AYX | yahoo = AYX | google = AYX | bloomberg = AYX:US }} [[Category:Business intelligence companies]] [[Category:Business software]] [[Category:Software companies based in California]] [[Category:Companies based in Irvine, California]] [[Category:Software companies established in 1997]] [[Category:2017 initial public offerings]] [[Category:Companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange]]

{{Infobox NRHP |nocat = yes |name = Ames Free Library |nrhp_type = nhldcp |nrhp_type2 = cp |image = Ames Free Library (North Easton, MA) - oblique view.JPG |caption = |locmapin =Massachusetts#USA |coordinates = {{coord|42|4|2|N|71|6|18|W|display=inline,title}} |location = [[North Easton, Massachusetts]] |nearest_city = |area = |built = 1883 |architect = [[Henry Hobson Richardson]] |architecture = [[Richardsonian Romanesque]] |designated = |designated_nrhp_type = December 23, 1987 |designated_nrhp_type2 = November 3, 1972 |established = |visitation_num = |visitation_year = |partof_refnum = 87002598 |partof = [[H. H. Richardson Historic District of North Easton]] |mpsub = |governing_body = [[Easton, Massachusetts|Town of Easton]] }} {{Infobox library |library_name = Ames Free Library |library_logo = |image = |caption = |location = |coordinates = |established = 1883 |num_branches = |collection_size = |annual_circulation = |pop_served = <!--Population of area the library provides service to.--> |members = <!--Cardholders--> |budget = |director = Donna P. Richman |num_employees = |website = [http://www.amesfreelibrary.org/ AmesFreeLibrary.org] }} The '''Ames Free Library''' is a [[public library]] designed by noted American architect [[H. H. Richardson]]. It is located at 53 Main Street, [[Easton, Massachusetts]], immediately adjacent to another Richardson building, [[Oakes Ames Memorial Hall]].
In 2016 the Ames Free Library won the Best Small Library in America award from the [[Library Journal]]. This award was created in 2005 by the [[Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation]] to encourage and showcase outstanding libraries serving populations of fewer than 25,000.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Weinstein|first1=Susan|title=Easton’s Ames Free Library named Best Small Library in America -- again|url=http://easton.wickedlocal.com/news/20160421/eastons-ames-free-library-named-best-small-library-in-america----again|accessdate=19 September 2017|agency=Wicked Local - Easton|date=April 21, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Berry III|first1=John N.|title=Culture Convener - Best Small Library in America 2016|url=http://lj.libraryjournal.com/2016/01/lj-in-print/culture-convener-best-small-library-in-america-2016/|accessdate=19 September 2017|agency=Library Journal|date=January 28, 2016}}</ref> This marks the second time the library has won this award.
==History== On the death of [[Oliver Ames, Jr.]], he left $50,000 for the construction of a library.<ref name="Ochsner"/> The will stipulated that it was to be a private institution, not owned by the town, but operated in trust for the public.<ref name="Ochsner"/> The request was carried out by Ames' children, [[Frederick Lothrop Ames]] and Helen Angier Ames. They hired [[Henry Hobson Richardson]] to design the building.<ref name="Ochsner"/> The final cost of the building came to at least $80,000.<ref name="Ochsner">{{cite book |title=H. H. Richardson: Complete Architectural Works |last=Ochsner |first=Jeffrey Karl |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gBDXfLHsnc4C |publisher=MIT Press |date=1984 |pages=68, 183 |isbn=0-262-65015-0}}</ref>
The library was built from 1877 to 1879, although it did not open until March 10, 1883. It is generally rectangular, with broad gable projecting from its north end and a rectangular tower rising where the gable meets the main mass. The gable's front facade contains a heavily arched entry on the first floor and a row of five arched windows separated by pairs of short columns above. The facade is light-brown Milford granite laid in random ashlar with reddish-brown Longmeadow brownstone trim. Its roof is red-orange tile. A children's wing (red brick) was added in 1931, eliminating the original lavatory and document room.
Within, the library's major rooms, stack wing, hall, and reading room are laid out longitudinally. The reading room's fireplace is primarily by [[Stanford White]], and the stone and bronze medallions of [[Oliver Ames, Jr.]] were designed by [[Augustus Saint-Gaudens]].
==See also== * [[H. H. Richardson Historic District of North Easton]] * [[North Easton Historic District]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{commonscat inline|Ames Free Library}} * {{cite web |url=http://www.amesfreelibrary.org/history/ |title=History |work=About the Library |publisher=Ames Free Library}} * {{cite web |url=http://www.greatbuildings.com/buildings/Ames_Free_Library.html |title=Oaks Ames Memorial Library |work=Great Buildings |publisher=Artifice, Inc.}} * {{cite web |url=http://www.archiplanet.org/wiki/Ames_Free_Library |title=Ames Free Library |work=Archiplanet |publisher=Artifice, Inc.}}
==Gallery== <gallery> Image:RichardsonNEatonLibrary.jpg|Ames Free Library Image:Ames Free Library (North Easton, MA) - front facade.JPG|Front facade Image:Ames Free Library (North Easton, MA) - interior fireplace.JPG|Fireplace Image:Ames Free Library (North Easton, MA) - interior stacks.JPG|Stacks File:amesfreelibrary.jpg|Ames Free Library, ca. 1879-1895 File:EAST FRONT ELEVATION - Oliver Ames Free Library, 53 Main Street, North Easton, Bristol County, MA.tif </gallery>

{{Infobox person | name = | image = | caption = | birth_date = April 6, 1920 | birth_place = [[Manhattan]] | birth_name = Arthur Goodhart Altschul | death_date = {{Death date and age|2002|03|17|1920|04|06}} | death_place = | residence = | nationality = United States | education = [[Yale College]] | occupation = Banker | known_for = | networth = | children = ''with Wagner:''
--[[Stephen Altschul]]
--Charles Altschul
''with von Reis:''
--[[Arthur Altschul, Jr.]]
--Emily Helen Altschul
--[[Serena Altschul]] | spouse = Stephanie Rosemary Wagner (until her death)
[[Siri von Reis]] (divorced)
Diana Landreth Childs (divorced)
[[Patricia Altschul|Patricia Dey]] (until his death) | parents = Helen Lehman Goodhart
[[Frank Altschul]] | family = [[Mayer Lehman]] (great-grandfather) | website = }} '''Arthur Goodhart Altschul''' (6 April 1920 – 17 March 2002)[[Social Security Death Index]][http://ssdi.genealogy.rootsweb.com/cgi-bin/ssdi.cgi Rootsweb.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080820044629/http://ssdi.genealogy.rootsweb.com/cgi-bin/ssdi.cgi |date=2008-08-20 }} was an American banker and a [[Goldman Sachs]] Group partner,[https://www.nytimes.com/2002/03/21/classified/paid-notice-deaths-altschul-arthur-goodhart.html Paid Notice: Deaths: Altschul, Arthur Goodhart], New York Times and executive at his private [[family office]], Overbrook Management Corporation, founded by his father. ==Early life== Altschul was born in 1920 in [[Manhattan]] to Helen Lehman Goodhart (maternal granddaughter of [[Mayer Lehman]], one of the three founding brothers of Lehman brothers) and [[Frank Altschul]], an investment banker who was a senior partner at [[Lazard Frères]] until 1945 and chairman of General Investors Corporation until he retired in 1961. He graduated from [[Deerfield Academy]] in Massachusetts and in 1943 from [[Yale College]]. ==Career== He served in the [[USMC|Marines]] from 1943 through 1945 and was a reporter for ''[[The New York Times]]'' in the late 1940s. As he had family connections to the [[Lehman family]], he worked as an analyst with [[Lehman Brothers]] before joining [[General American Investors Company]] (a closed-end investment concern in which his family has a substantial interest) and then [[Goldman Sachs]] where he served as a general partner from 1959 to 1977 and a limited partner from 1977 to 1999. He was also chairman of General American Investors from 1961 to 1995.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/03/20/nyregion/arthur-g-altschul-81-banker-art-collector-and-philanthropist.html|work=The New York Times|title= "Arthur G. Altschul, 81, Banker, Art Collector and Philanthropist"|author=Eric Pace|date= March 20, 2002}} He led the private [[family office]], Overbrook Management Corporation, founded by his father to manage and protect the wealth and financial well-being of the Altschul Family. In 2002, the office opened to provides asset management and related services to institutional investors and high net worth individuals. Over the years, Overbrook’s leadership passed to him, and then to the third generation, his son, Arthur Goodhart Altschul, Jr, who currently serves as Overbrook's Chairman.[https://www.overbrook.com/default.asp?P=1020720&S=1020722 Our Team] overbrook.com ==Philanthropy== Altschul was on the Board of Trustees of many museums and philanthropic organisations, including the [[Whitney Museum]], the [[United Jewish Communities|United Jewish Appeal]], the [[Overbrook Foundation]], the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], [[The American Assembly]], and the International Foundation for Art Research. [[Barnard College]] at its 1984 commencement ceremonies awarded Altschul its highest honor, the [[List of Barnard College people#Recipients of the Medal of Distinction|Barnard Medal of Distinction]]. ==Personal life== Arthur Altschul married four times: *Stephanie Rosemary Wagner (married in 1956), who died in a plane crash in 1961. They had two children:{{cite news|url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FA0A16FD345F177A93C2AA178FD85F428585F9|work=The New York Times|title=Principals in Wedding Ceremony Here; Stephanie R. Wagner Is Bride Of Arthur Goodhart Altschul|date=April 30, 1956}} **[[Stephen Altschul]] (born in 1957), a mathematician and researcher. **Charles Altschul (born in 1958). *[[Siri von Reis]] (married in 1963; divorced in 1972), a botanist. They had three children: **[[Arthur Altschul, Jr.]] (born in 1964). In 2013, he married [[Palestinian people|Palestinian]] journalist [[Rula Jebreal]].{{cite news|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/pagesix/successful_match_QnkXWvgIuk9Bd6XhH6uTmN|work=New York Post|title="Arthur Altschul, Jr. engaged to Rula Jebreal"|date= May 2, 2013}} **Emily Helen Altschul (born in 1966). In November 2002, she married [[John Miller (journalist)|John Miller]], a journalist and former host of ''[[20/20]],'' a weekly news magazine on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]].{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/11/24/style/weddings-celebrations-emily-altschul-john-miller.html|work=The New York Times|title="WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS; Emily Altschul, John Miller"|date= November 24, 2002}} **[[Serena Altschul]] (born in 1970). She has worked as a broadcast journalist for the MTV, CNN and CBS networks. *Diana Landreth Childs (marriage ended by divorce). *[[Patricia Altschul|Patricia Dey]] (married in 1996). ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Lehman family}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Altschul, Arthur}} [[Category:1920 births]] [[Category:2002 deaths]] [[Category:People from Manhattan]] [[Category:American businesspeople]] [[Category:American people of German-Jewish descent]] [[Category:Lehman family]]

revision.text:
{{about||the Florida attorney|Barry Cohen (attorney)|the American art therapist|Barry Marc Cohen|the television director and bridge expert|Barry Crane}} {{Use Australian English|date=September 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2011}} {{Infobox MP | honorific-prefix = [[The Honourable]] | name = Barry Cohen | honorific-suffix = [[Order of Australia|AM]] | image = | constituency_MP = [[Division of Robertson|Robertson]] | parliament = Australian | majority = | predecessor = [[William Bridges-Maxwell]] | successor = [[Frank Walker (Australian politician)|Frank Walker]] | term_start = 25 October 1969 | term_end = 19 February 1990 | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1935|4|3}} | birth_place = [[Griffith, New South Wales]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|2017|12|18|1935|4|3}} | death_place = | nationality = Australian | spouse = Rae O'Neill | party = [[Australian Labor Party]] | relations = | children = | residence = | alma_mater = | occupation = Businessman | profession = | religion = [[Judaism]] | signature = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Barry Cohen''' [[Member of the Order of Australia|AM]] (3 April 1935 – 18 December 2017) was an Australian [[Australian Labor Party|Labor]] politician. He was a minister in the government of [[Bob Hawke]]. ==Biography== Cohen was born in [[Griffith, New South Wales]] and educated at Griffith High School, [[Sydney Grammar School]] and [[North Sydney Technical High School]]. He received a Bachelor of Arts from the [[Australian National University]]. He was a businessman before entering politics. He was the federal member for the seat of [[Division of Robertson|Robertson]] from [[Australian federal election, 1969|1969]] until his retirement before the [[Australian federal election, 1990|1990 election]]. Following the [[Australian Labor Party]]'s win under [[Bob Hawke]] at the [[Australian federal election, 1983|1983 election]], he was Minister for [[Minister for Home Affairs (Australia)|Home Affairs]] and [[Minister for the Environment, Heritage and the Arts (Australia)|the Environment]] from 1983 to 1984 and then [[Minister for the Environment, Heritage and the Arts (Australia)|Minister for Arts, Heritage and the Environment]] until 1987.{{cite web |title=Biography for Cohen, the Hon. Barry |publisher=[[Parliament of Australia]] |work=ParlInfo Web |url=http://parlinfoweb.aph.gov.au/piweb/view_document.aspx?id=8031&table=BIOGS |accessdate=1 December 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070915120142/http://parlinfoweb.aph.gov.au/piweb/view_document.aspx?TABLE=biogs&ID=8031 |archivedate=15 September 2007 |df=dmy }} At the [[New South Wales state election, 1999]] he was a candidate for [[electoral district of Gosford|Gosford]], losing to the incumbent Liberal member, [[Chris Hartcher]]. ==After politics== Cohen wrote a number of books on political anecdotes, and an autobiography:{{cite web | title =Barry Cohen | publisher=Celebrity Speakers | url =http://www.celebrityspeakers.com.au/brspeaker_bio.asp?Speaker_Index_Text=368 | accessdate = 1 December 2007 }} *''Life with Gough'' (1996) *''From Whitlam to Winston'' (1997) *''The Almost Complete Gough'' (2001) *''The Life Of The Party – Political Anecdotes'' (1987) In 2015, Cohen and three other former MPs brought a case before the [[High Court of Australia]], purporting that reductions to their retirement allowances and limitations on the number of "domestic return trips per year" under the Members of Parliament (Life Gold Pass) Act 2002 were unconstitutional under S51(xxxi) of the [[Constitution of Australia]]. They lost the case in 2016, with the court finding that Parliament was entitled to vary the terms of allowances.{{cite news | title=Former MPs lose High Court challenge over entitlements | date=12 Oct 2016 | publisher=ABC News | url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-10-12/high-court-rules-on-entitlements-gold-pass/7924916}} ==Personal== Cohen married Rae McNeill in October 1959 and they had three sons.{{cite book | title = Who's Who in Australia | publisher=Crown Contents | year = 2008 | location = North Melbourne | pages =2303 | url = http://www.crowncontent.com.au | isbn = 1-74095-160-3}} Although Cohen voted for the decriminalisation of [[homosexuality]] in the 1970s, he spoke out against gay marriage, arguing that "gay marriage and conventional marriage is [not] the same thing".{{cite news| url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/commentary/opposing-gay-marriage-doesnt-mean-im-barking/story-e6frgd0x-1226038720460 | first=Barry | last=Cohen | title=Opposing gay marriage doesn't mean I'm barking | date=14 April 2011 | work=The Australian}} Cohen died on 18 December 2017, having been diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease several years earlier.{{cite news|title=Barry Cohen, Hawke government minister and Alzheimer's campaigner, dies|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-12-18/minister-turned-alzheimers-campaginer-barry-cohen-dies/9268218|accessdate=18 December 2017|work=ABC News|date=18 December 2017|language=en-AU}} ==Honours== Cohen was appointed a Member of the [[Order of Australia]] in the Queen's Birthday Honours in 2007, for service to the Australian Parliament and to the community through a range of cultural and environmental roles and contributions to public discussion and debate.[http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/honour_roll/search.cfm?aus_award_id=1134701&search_type=quick&showInd=true COHEN, Barry], ''It's an Honour''. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{s-bef|rows=2|before=[[Tom McVeigh]] (home affairs and the environment)
[[Neil Brown (Australian politician)|Neil Brown]] ([[Minister for Competition Policy and Consumer Affairs (Australia)|consumer affairs]])}} {{s-ttl|title= Minister for [[Minister for Home Affairs (Australia)|Home Affairs]] and [[Minister for the Environment, Heritage and the Arts (Australia)|the Environment]] |years=1983–1984}} {{s-aft| rows=2| after=[[John Brown (Australian politician)|John Brown]] }} {{s-ttl | title= [[Minister for the Environment, Heritage and the Arts (Australia)|Minister for Arts, Heritage and the Environment]] | years=1984–1987}} {{s-par|au}} {{succession box | title=Member for [[Division of Robertson|Robertson]] | before= [[William Bridges-Maxwell]] | after= [[Frank Walker (Australian politician)|Frank Walker]] | years=1969–1990}} {{s-end}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cohen, Barry}} [[Category:1935 births]] [[Category:2017 deaths]] [[Category:Australian Labor Party members of the Parliament of Australia]] [[Category:Members of the Australian House of Representatives for Robertson]] [[Category:Members of the Australian House of Representatives]] [[Category:Members of the Order of Australia]] [[Category:Australian businesspeople]] [[Category:Jewish Australian politicians]] [[Category:20th-century Australian politicians]] [[Category:Deaths from Alzheimer's disease]]

{{Infobox church | name = Basilica of the
Immaculate Conception | fullname = | other name = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = ChurchJax1.jpg | imagesize = | imagelink = | imagealt = | landscape = | caption = | osgraw = | osgridref = | location = 121 E. Duval St.
[[Jacksonville, Florida]] | country = [[United States]] | denomination = [[Catholic Church]] | previous denomination = | churchmanship = | membership = | attendance = | website = {{URL|http://www.icjax.org/}} | former name = | bull date = | founded date = 1845 | founder = | dedication = [[Immaculate Conception]] | dedicated date = December 8, 1910 | consecrated date = | cult = | relics = | events = | past bishop = | people = | status = [[Basilica]]/[[Parish]] | functional status = Active | heritage designation = | designated date = | architect = M. H. Hubbard | architectural type = | style = [[Gothic Revival architecture|Gothic Revival]] | years built = 1907-1910 | groundbreaking = | completed date = | construction cost = | closed date = | demolished date = | capacity = | length = | width = | width nave = | height = | diameter = | other dimensions = | floor count = | floor area = | spire quantity = Two | spire height = | materials = | bells = | bells hung = | bell weight = | diocese = [[Diocese of St. Augustine|St. Augustine]] | bishop = Most Rev. [[Felipe de Jesús Estévez]] | pastor = Very Rev. Edward Murphy | vicar = | deacon = | director = | organist = | businessmgr = | liturgycoord = | reledu = | rcia = | youthmin = | flowerguild = | musicgroup = | parishadmin = | serversguild = | embedded = {{Infobox NRHP | name = Church of the Immaculate Conception | nrhp_type =nrhp | embed = yes | image = | caption = | coordinates = {{coord|30|19|44|N|81|39|19|W|display=inline,title}} | locmapin = Florida#USA | area = less than one acre | added = December 30, 1992 | builder = Halsema-[[O.P. Woodcock|Woodcock]] Co. | mpsub = Downtown Jacksonville MPS | refnum = 92001695{{NRISref|2009a}} }}}} The '''Basilica of the Immaculate Conception''' is a historic [[Catholic Church|Catholic]] [[church (building)|church]] in [[Downtown Jacksonville|Downtown]] [[Jacksonville, Florida]], U.S. A parish church in the [[Diocese of St. Augustine]], it represents Jacksonville's oldest Catholic congregation. The current building, dating to 1910, was added to the U.S. [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 1992 as the Church of the Immaculate Conception, and was named a [[minor basilica]] in 2013. It is located at 121 East Duval Street; its current pastor is Father Ed Murphy. ==History== [[File:CIC1901fire.jpg|thumb|280px|left|Ruins of the Church of the Immaculate Conception after the [[Great Fire of 1901]].]] The congregation was established in about 1845 as a [[Catholic mission|mission]] of the Catholic [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Savannah|parish of Savannah]] in [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], and the first church building was constructed by 1847. Immaculate Conception was designated its own parish in 1854, but the original building was destroyed by [[Union (American Civil War)|Union]] forces during the [[American Civil War]]. A second building was planned shortly after Jacksonville became part of the newly created Catholic [[Diocese of St. Augustine]] in 1870, and was completed in 1874. This was destroyed along with most of downtown Jacksonville in the [[Great Fire of 1901]].Wood 1992, p. 47. The current building was designed in 1905 by architect M. H. Hubbard, also the designer of [[Bethel Baptist Institutional Church]]. Construction began in 1907 and completed on December 8, 1910, when the building was dedicated. The structure is an example of [[Late Gothic Revival architecture]], considered one of the best such examples in Florida, featuring a [[Cruciform#Cruciform architectural plan|cruciform floor plan]], [[pointed arch]]es, [[tracery]] on the windows, [[buttress]]es and [[pinnacle]]s, high [[spire]]s, and a high [[Vault (architecture)|vault]] on the interior. The building's {{convert|178.5|ft|m|adj=on}} [[Steeple (architecture)|steeple]], topped by a gold-plated cross, was the highest point in the city for three years until the [[Heard National Bank Building]] was finished in 1913. In 1979 the church received ''solemn dedication'', meaning the structure cannot be demolished willfully or converted to another purpose besides a church. On December 30, 1992 it was listed in the U.S. [[National Register of Historic Places]].[http://www.nationalregisterofhistoricplaces.com/FL/Duval/state.html Duval County listings] at [http://www.nationalregisterofhistoricplaces.com National Register of Historic Places] Beginning in 2005 the church sought designation as a [[minor basilica]] from the [[Congregation for Divine Worship and the Discipline of the Sacraments]] due to its history. The request was renewed in 2013 by Bishop [[Felipe de Jesús Estévez]] and granted; the designation was announced on August 15, 2013.{{cite news |author= |date= August 15, 2013 |title= Jacksonville's Immaculate Conception named a Minor Basilica |url= http://jacksonville.com/news/metro/2013-08-15/story/jacksonvilles-immaculate-conception-named-minor-basilica |newspaper= The Florida Times-Union |location= |publisher= |accessdate= December 5, 2013 }} ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== *{{cite book |title= Jacksonville's Architectural Heritage |last= Wood |first= Wayne |authorlink= |coauthors= |year= 1992|publisher= [[University Press of Florida]] |location= |isbn= 0-8130-0953-7|page= |pages= |url= |accessdate=}} ==External links== * [http://www.icjax.org/ Official website] * [http://www.flheritage.com Florida's Office of Cultural and Historical Programs] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070216141414/http://www.flheritage.com/facts/reports/places/index.cfm?fuseaction=ListAreas&county=Duval Duval County listings] {{Roman Catholic Diocese of St. Augustine}} {{National Register of Historic Places in Florida}} {{Jacksonville attractions}} [[Category:Basilica churches in Florida]] [[Category:Roman Catholic churches in Florida]] [[Category:Roman Catholic Diocese of Saint Augustine]] [[Category:Roman Catholic churches in Jacksonville, Florida]] [[Category:History of Jacksonville, Florida]] [[Category:National Register of Historic Places in Jacksonville, Florida]] [[Category:Roman Catholic churches on the National Register of Historic Places in Florida]] [[Category:Downtown Jacksonville]] [[Category:1845 establishments in Florida]]

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{BLP primary sources|article|date=March 2009}} {{like resume|article|date=March 2009}} }}
'''Benjamin Gilad''' is a pioneer in the field of [[competitive Intelligence]], he has published multiple books and articles on the subject, is a co-founder of the [[Fuld-Gilad-Herring Academy of Competitive Intelligence]], and serves as a consultant for many [[Fortune 500]] companies.
== Education ==
Benjamin Gilad obtained his undergraduate degrees in [[Psychology]] and [[Philosophy]] from [[Tel Aviv University]]. After moving to the [[United States]] he obtained his [[Master of Business Administration]] from [[Central Missouri State University]], and later obtained a [[PhD]] from [[New York University]].<ref>Gilad, Benjamin. "Business War Games" Career Press: Franklin Lakes, NJ 2009</ref>
== Career ==
=== Israel ===
While living in [[Israel]] Dr. Gilad served in the [[Israel Defense Forces]].<ref>[http://tim.co.il.preview18.livedns.co.il/home/May_Highlight.aspx Technion Institute of Management Article] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090122022044/http://tim.co.il.preview18.livedns.co.il/home/May_Highlight.aspx |date=January 22, 2009 }}</ref> and worked as a police intelligence officer in Tel Aviv. He worked on many different cases covering a wide variety of criminal activity.<ref name="ben2">{{cite web |url=http://www.bengilad.com/academy_competitive_intelligence.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-11-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090402042801/http://www.bengilad.com/academy_competitive_intelligence.php |archivedate=2009-04-02 |df= }}</ref>
=== Rutgers University ===
Dr. Gilad is a former Associate Professor of Strategy at [[Rutgers University|Rutgers University's]] School of Management.<ref>Gilad, B. (2004, September). The Failure of CI. Comintel Newsletter. Retrieved February 11, 2009</ref>
=== Consultation ===
He also consults for many Fortune 500 companies including [[Kellogg Company|Kellogg]], [[E. I. du Pont de Nemours and Company|Dupont]], [[Ericsson]], and many others.<ref name="ben">[http://www.academyci.com/About/gilad.html Academy of CI Bio] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090106124414/http://www.academyci.com/About/gilad.html |date=2009-01-06 }}</ref>
== Fuld-Gilad-Herring Academy of Competitive Intelligence ==
Dr. Gilad, with Jan Herring, founded the Academy of Competitive Intelligence in 1996, and in 1999 they joined forces with Leonard Fuld to establish the first accredited professional program in CI. The academy has experienced great success with a wide variety of students from many varying backgrounds.<ref>[http://www.academyci.com/ftse/About_Competitive_Intelligence.html About Academy of CI] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081121214732/http://www.academyci.com/ftse/About_Competitive_Intelligence.html |date=November 21, 2008 }}</ref>
== Publications and awards ==
=== The Business Intelligence System ===
The Business Intelligence System published in 1988, co-authored with Tamar Gilad, was the first publication to introduce a model for a formal competitive intelligence function to the corporate world. This model has been adopted by an overwhelming number of large companies in the western hemisphere.<ref name="ben2"/>
=== Business Blind Spots ===
Business Blind Spots, first published in 1994 with a second edition appearing in 1998, is about the important role of intelligence in a business, and what happens when managers choose to ignore intelligence and allow blind spots to persist. The book also stresses the importance of the human aspect of intelligent corporations. In the book, Dr. Gilad maintains that hardware and software are not the solutions to the weakness in corporations; instead the solutions are the application of human-led systems and structures.<ref>[http://www.infonortics.com/publications/giladbb.html Publisher Web Page] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090224051140/http://www.infonortics.com/publications/giladbb.html |date=February 24, 2009 }}</ref> It is also the first book to introduce the blind spots war game methodology.<ref name="ben2" /> The book was called "inspirational" <ref>http://thoughtblender.blogspot.com/2007_09_01_archive.html</ref> and has been sold out in weeks.<ref>Albagli, A., W.A Baldwin and K. K. Coker. Book Review. The Journal of Technology Transfer, Vol. 22, No.1, March 1997.</ref>
=== Early Warning ===
Early warning, published in 2003, is about limiting surprise in the business world. The book covers the strategic early warning process model first written about by Dr. Gilad in 2001.<ref name="ben2" /> It also covers developing a Competitive Early Warning system to avoid such surprises, manage risk effectively, and avoid “industrial dissonance,” which is when market realities outpace corporate strategies.<ref>[http://www.amanet.org/books/book.cfm?isbn=9780814407868 American Management Association Overview]</ref> Gilad's Early Warning System has been quoted by Philip Kotler as one of the effective tools management can use in managing chaotic environments.<ref>Kotler, P. and J. Castlione. Chaotics: The Business of Managing and Marketing in the Age of Turbulence. Amacom, 2009</ref>
=== Business War Games ===
Business War Games (2009) is both about the theory of, and a practical manual for, running simple, reality-based war games throughout a company, enabling managers at all levels to formulate better strategies. War games are simulations of competitive dynamics in a business’ given market with the goal of “pressure testing” product, market, or the whole business unit’s strategic plan.<ref>[http://www.bengilad.com/business_war_games.php Business War Games Overview] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090403025605/http://www.bengilad.com/business_war_games.php |date=April 3, 2009 }}</ref> The book shows steps, and practical details, on how to decide whether war gaming is necessary, and which decisions to use it for. It also covers: how to prepare, run, and organize an inexpensive game, how to predict competitor moves with accuracy and little information, and why one does not need computers, consultants, or specialized software to conduct such games.<ref>[https://www.amazon.com/dp/1601630301 Editorial Review]</ref>
=== Articles ===
Dr. Gilad has written multiple articles related to the field of Competitive Intelligence. These articles appear in multiple CI related publications and on multiple web sites.<ref>[http://www.academyci.com/ResourceCenter/#bgart Academy of CI Article List] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090302093248/http://www.academyci.com/ResourceCenter/#bgart |date=March 2, 2009 }}</ref>
=== Awards ===
In 1996 Dr. Gilad was awarded the [[Society of Competitive Intelligence Professionals]] Meritorious Award. This award is given to a single individual each year that has made significant and meritorious contributions to the competitive intelligence profession. He was the second of the three Academy of Competitive Intelligence founders to be given the award.<ref>[http://www.scip.org/content.cfm?itemnumber=592&navItemNumber=2236 SCIP Meritorious Award Winners List] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111110202204/http://www.scip.org/content.cfm?itemnumber=592&navItemNumber=2236 |date=November 10, 2011 }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Gilad, Benjamin}} [[Category:Rutgers University faculty]] [[Category:New York University alumni]] [[Category:Business writers]] [[Category:Living people]]

|settlement_type = [[List of districts and neighborhoods of Los Angeles|Neighborhood of Los Angeles]] <!--such as Town, Village, City, Borough etc.--> |total_type=<!-- to set a non-standard label for total area and population rows --> |motto= <!-- images and maps -----------> |image_skyline=Bunker Hill Downtown Los Angeles.jpg |imagesize=250px |image_caption=Bunker Hill as seen from [[Los Angeles City Hall]] |image_flag= |flag_size= |image_sea= |seal_size= |image_shield= |shield_size= |image_blank_emblem= |blank_emblem_type= |blank_emblem_size= |image_map= |mapsize= |map_caption=
