|subdivision_type = Country |subdivision_name = [[United States]] |subdivision_type1 = State |subdivision_name1 = [[California]] |subdivision_type2 = County |subdivision_name2 = [[Los Angeles County, California|County of Los Angeles]] |subdivision_type3 = City |subdivision_name3 = [[Los Angeles]] |subdivision_type4 = |subdivision_name4 = <!-- Smaller parts (e.g. boroughs of a city) and seat of government --> |seat_type= |seat= |parts_type= |parts_style=<!--=list (for list), coll (for collapsed list), para (for paragraph format) Default is list if up to 5 items, coll if more than 5--> |parts=<!-- parts text, or header for parts list --> |p1= |p2=<!-- etc. up to p50: for separate parts to be listed--> <!-- Politics -----------------> |government_footnotes= |government_type= |leader_title= |leader_name= |leader_title1= |leader_name1= |leader_title2= |leader_name2= |leader_title3= |leader_name3= |established_title= |established_date= <!-- Area ---------------------> |area_magnitude= |unit_pref= |area_footnotes= |area_total_sq_mi= |area_land_sq_mi= |area_water_sq_mi= |area_water_percent= <!-- Elevation --------------------------> |elevation_footnotes=<!--for references: use tags--> |elevation_m= |elevation_ft= |elevation_max_m= |elevation_max_ft= |elevation_min_m= |elevation_min_ft= <!-- Population -----------------------> |population_as_of= |population_footnotes= |population_note= |population_total= |population_density_sq_mi= <!-- General information ---------------> |timezone= |utc_offset= |timezone_DST= |utc_offset_DST= |coordinates = {{coord|34.052035|-118.250347|display=inline}} <!-- Area/postal codes and others --------> |postal_code_type=[[ZIP Code]] |postal_code= |area_code=[[Area code 213|213]] |website= |footnotes= }}
'''Bunker Hill''' is a historic prominence that traditionally separated [[Downtown Los Angeles]] from the rest of the city to the west before the hill was [[2nd Street Tunnel|tunneled through at Second Street]] in 1924.<ref>[http://discoverlosangeles.com 2012-2013 Official Visitors Map], Los Angeles Tourism & Convention Board, 2012</ref>
In the late 20th century, the hill was lowered in elevation, and the entire area was redeveloped to supplant old frame and concrete buildings with modern high-rises and other structures for residences, commerce, entertainment, and education.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-angels-landing-20180530-story.html|title=Condos, restaurants, an elementary school. How an 80-story skyscraper could transform Bunker Hill|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|first=Roger |last=Vincent|date=May 30, 2018|access-date=31 May 2018}}</ref>
==History== [[Image:Downtown-LA-1900.jpg|thumb|300px|A view of Bunker Hill, 1900, with [[Pershing Square (Los Angeles)|Pershing Square]] in the foreground]]
===Early development=== In 1867, a wealthy developer, [[Prudent Beaudry]], purchased a majority of the hill's land. Because of the hill's excellent views of the [[Los Angeles Basin]] and the [[Los Angeles River]], he knew that it would make for an opulent subdivision. He developed the peak of Bunker Hill with lavish two-story [[Victorian architecture|Victorian]] houses that became famous as homes for the upper-class residents of Los Angeles. [[Angels Flight]], now dubbed "The World's Shortest Railway", took residents homeward from the bottom of the 33% grade and down again.
Initially a residential suburb, Bunker Hill retained its exclusive character through the end of [[World War I]], but in the face of increased urban growth fed by an extensive streetcar system, its wealthy residents began leaving for enclaves on the Westside and [[Pasadena, California|Pasadena]]. Bunker Hill's houses were increasingly subdivided to accommodate renters. Still, Bunker Hill was at this time "Los Angeles's most crowded and urban neighborhood".<ref>Mike Davis, "Hollywood's Dark Shadow," in ''Dead Cities and Other Tales'' (New York: The New Press, 2003; orig. ed. 2002), 132.</ref> By [[World War II]], the [[Pasadena Freeway]], built to bring shoppers downtown, was taking more residents out. Additional postwar freeway construction left downtown comparatively empty of both people and services. The once-grand Victorian mansions of Bunker Hill became the home of impoverished pensioners.<ref>Documentary "Bunker Hill" special feature on the DVD ''[[The Exiles (1961 film)|The Exiles]]''</ref>
===Bunker Hill Redevelopment Project=== In 1955, Los Angeles city planners decided that Bunker Hill required a massive [[slum clearance]] project. The top of Bunker Hill was cleared of its houses and then flattened as the first stage of the Bunker Hill Redevelopment Project to populate Bunker Hill with modern plazas and buildings. When the height limit of buildings for Los Angeles was finally raised (previously buildings were limited to 150 feet), developers built some of the tallest skyscrapers in the region to take advantage of the area's existing dense zoning. In approving such projects, the city sought to project a modern, sophisticated image.
The project is the longest redevelopment project in Los Angeles history. The majority of the skyscrapers on Bunker Hill were built in the 1980s, with a new skyscraper or two being finished nearly every year. However, the momentum died down in the 1990s, shortly after the 52-story [[Two California Plaza]] was finished.<ref name="nytimesNov1991">{{Citation | last = Stevenson | first = Richard W. | title = Office Glut Spreads in California | newspaper = New York Times | date = November 11, 1991 | url = https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D0CE7DD1731F932A25752C1A967958260&sec=&spon=&partner=permalink&exprod=permalink}}</ref> In 1999, the vacancy rate for downtown commercial skyscrapers was 26%, one of the highest in the nation for that time. Planned office towers were canceled, including California Plaza Three,<ref name="LAbusJrnl1993">{{Citation | last = Berton | first = Brad | title = Los Angeles Community Redevelopment Agency's notice of default suit against Bunker Hill Associates | newspaper = Los Angeles Business Journal | date = April 26, 1993 | url = http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Confusion+greets+Three+Cal+Plaza+default+notice,+some+see+union+tie-a013927656}}</ref> and the nearby four-towered Metropolis (brought back to life in 2005).
==Current area== [[Image:Downtown-Los-Angeles-Aerial-view-from-south-August-2014.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Aerial view in 2014]] [[Image:WaltDisneyConcertHall-12-22-04.jpg|thumb|[[Walt Disney Concert Hall]], Bunker Hill]] [[Image:Wellscali.jpg|thumb|The [[Wells Fargo Center (Los Angeles)|Wells Fargo Center]], [[One California Plaza]] and [[Two California Plaza]], today stands on the highest point of Bunker Hill. As seen from the top of the [[Westin Bonaventure Hotel]].]] [[Image:JohnFerraroBuilding-122204.jpg|thumb|[[John Ferraro|John Ferraro Building]], Bunker Hill, home to the Los Angeles Department of Water & Power]] Many of the older buildings and the early high-rises surrounding Bunker Hill are undergoing [[adaptive reuse]] from commercial to residential. This trend began in 2000, when the Los Angeles City Council passed an adaptive reuse ordinance, allowing old unused office buildings to be redeveloped as apartments or "lofts". Developers realized there was a high level of pent-up demand for living in or near downtown by artists and employees of various firms in the [[Financial District, Los Angeles|Financial District]] and government workers in the [[Civic Center, Los Angeles|Civic Center]], and that they could profit by supplying housing to meet such demand.
Because of the popularity of the [[New Urbanism]] in California, the city has required developers to build mixed-use residential buildings as much as possible. This means that the first floor of such residential developments is devoted to commercial retailers, so that residents do not have to constantly drive around for all their shopping trips and buildings present a more welcoming facade to passersby on the sidewalk.
Contributing to the resurgence of Bunker Hill has been the construction of public venues, such as [[Walt Disney Concert Hall]] and [[Cathedral of Our Lady of the Angels]], and the [[Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles|Museum of Contemporary Art]], as well as the [[Colburn School]], a community performing arts school and collegiate conservatory.
In February 2007, $2.05 billion was approved for the [[Grand Avenue Project]], which over the next 10 years will bring in over 2,000 new residential units, over 400 of them being affordable units for all degrees of [[poverty|low-income]] families; a million square feet (93,000 m²) of office space; a [[Mandarin Oriental Hotel Group|Mandarin Oriental]] hotel; 600,000 square feet (56,000 m²) of retail and entertainment space; and the [[Grand Park]], connecting City Hall to Bunker Hill. Office space and residential units will be in several [[skyscraper]]s ranging between 35-55 stories each. Nearby planned projects include [[L.A. Live]] on [[Figueroa Street]] and [[Olympic Boulevard (Los Angeles)|Olympic Boulevard]] in [[South Park, Los Angeles|South Park]] (the southern end of the Bunker Hill area). A new major modern art museum, [[The Broad]], opened on September 20, 2015, next to Disney Hall.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/arts/la-et-cm-broad-opening-day-20150921-story.html|title=The heat and the lines couldn't keep them from the Broad on opening day|first=Deborah|last=Vankin|date=21 September 2015|publisher=|accessdate=19 June 2017|via=LA Times}}</ref>
The [[Angels Flight]] tramway, which was rebuilt in 1996 near where it was originally located and shut down after a fatal accident in 2001, reopened on March 15, 2010, to provide a link between Bunker Hill and the revitalized downtown area. One sign of the success of the downtown renaissance is that the office vacancy rate for the fourth quarter of 2004 was 16%, compared to 19% for 2003, and 26% for 1999.<ref>Vincent, Roger (13 February 2014) [http://articles.latimes.com/2014/feb/13/business/la-fi-property-report-20140213 "With sale of Two California Plaza, Bunker Hill is poised for comeback"] ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''</ref>
===Mix of housing options=== While developers are primarily building market-rate housing on Bunker Hill today, the City of Los Angeles has very strict laws, rules, and ordinances established that promote the inclusion of all income levels into the residential mix. Some examples include incentives for the creation of affordable housing (rather than market-rate housing), the preservation of existing affordable housing, the development of affordable housing by the city itself (rather than waiting for private developers), and others. The city has written documentation regarding the development of affordable housing.<ref>[http://www.lacity.org/lahd/curriculum/index.html http://www.lacity.org/lahd/curriculum/index.html] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050216051527/http://www.lacity.org/lahd/curriculum/index.html |date=February 16, 2005 }} ''lacity.org''</ref>
On the topic of building affordable housing for very low-income to moderate-income, Principal City Planner Jane Blumenfeld said, "We are trying to make it attractive to build [downtown] and get this added affordable housing that we normally wouldn't have. We need an adequate amount of lower income housing so that in 20 years Downtown doesn't become an exclusive neighborhood."<ref>[http://www.downtownnews.com/articles/2005/03/28/news/news02.txt http://www.downtownnews.com/articles/2005/03/28/news/news02.txt]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ''downtownnews.com''</ref>
The Emerson apartment building, owned by the [[Related Companies]], has 271 units, of which 216 are leased at market rates. The other 55 units are at subsidized rates to tenants whose annual incomes are less than 50% of the local median, which was $42,700 for a family of four in 2014.<ref>Vincent, Roger (October 1, 2014) [http://www.latimes.com/business/realestate/la-fi-property-report-emerson-20141002-story.html "Developer of new Bunker Hill apartment high-rise woos older residents"] ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''</ref>
==In popular culture== [[Image:Angels Flight 2011.JPG|thumb|left|Angels Flight, December 2011]]
===Radio=== On "[[The Adventures of Philip Marlowe]]" radio program with episode named "Baton Sinister" dated September 17, 1949, Angels Flight is referenced as Marlowe has a rendezvous set in Bunker Hill.
===Film=== In the 1940s and 1950s, Bunker Hill was a popular film setting, especially in the [[film noir]] genre, because of its Victorian homes, its rambling hillside apartments and flophouses, its [[Angels Flight]] funicular, and its mean (or at least mean-looking) streets.<ref>LA Downtown News [http://www.ladowntownnews.com/news/will-angels-flight-ever-roll-again/article_f99ee604-bc49-11e3-abe6-0019bb2963f4.html Will Angels Flight Ever Roll Again?]</ref><ref>tumblr. [http://www.tumblr.com/search/Los+Angeles's+Bunker+Hill%3A+Pulp+Fiction's+Mean+Streets+and+Film+Noir's+Ground+Zero! Los Angeles's Bunker Hill: Pulp Fiction's Mean Streets and Film Noir's Ground Zero!]</ref> It was used extensively in such crime films as ''[[Cry Danger]]'' (1951), ''[[Kiss Me Deadly]]'' (1956), ''[[Criss Cross (1949 movie)|Criss Cross]]'' (1949), [[Joseph Losey]]'s ''[[M (1951 film)|M]]'' (1951), and ''[[Angel's Flight]]'' (1965).
Director [[Curtis Hanson]] re-created Bunker Hill in another hilly neighborhood altogether in his [[Oscar Award]]–winning ''[[L.A. Confidential]]'' (1997).<ref>Electric Earl [http://www.electricearl.com/bh/ Bunker Hill Goes to the Movies]</ref><ref>Pitzer College [https://www.pitzer.edu/academics/faculty/lerner/wide_angle/19_4/194dimendberg.htm From Berlin to Bunker Hill: Urban Space, Late Modernity, and Film Noir in Fritz Lang's and Joseph Losey's M Edward Dimendberg] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303233838/https://www.pitzer.edu/academics/faculty/lerner/wide_angle/19_4/194dimendberg.htm |date=March 3, 2016 }}</ref><ref>Time Friday, July 18, 2008 [http://content.time.com/time/arts/article/0,8599,1824503,00.html Exiles on Indie Street By Richard Corliss]</ref> [[Kent Mackenzie]] made a film in 1956 called ''Bunker Hill'' about the displacement of the residents who had to make way for construction.<ref>LA Observed July 31, 2010 [http://www.laobserved.com/archive/2010/07/weekend_viewing_bunker_hi.php Weekend viewing: Bunker Hill, 1956 by Kevin Roderick]</ref><ref>LA Observed August 3, 2010 [http://www.laobserved.com/archive/2010/08/bunker_hill_video_deleted.php Bunker Hill video deleted from Vimeo * By Kevin Roderick]</ref><ref>Los Angeles Film Forum [http://lafilmforum.org/archive/summer-2013-schedule/this-is-the-city This is the City]</ref> Another film by Mackenzie that was set in the area —his neo-realist and semi-documentary feature ''[[The Exiles (1961 film)|The Exiles]]'' (1961) — depicts the lives of a tribe of urban Indians on Bunker Hill in the late 1950s.<ref>Oscilloscope [http://www.oscilloscope.net/films/film/36/The-Exiles [http://www.oscilloscope.net/films/film/36/The-Exiles The Exiles]</ref>
Bunker Hill was a destination of many local artists and photographers, some in its heyday, others as it was being demolished and rebuilt. Among the latter was the Los Angeles photographer [[Ray McSavaney]].
[[Angels Flight]] and its Third Street neighborhood, c. 1930s, were re-created in South Africa for the filming of ''[[Ask the Dust (film)|Ask the Dust]]'' (2006), based on the novel by [[John Fante]], which was set in the district in the 1930s. Fante also wrote a book called ''Dreams From Bunker Hill,'' his last novel, dictated near death to his wife.
The [[2nd Street Tunnel]] under Bunker Hill is widely used in film and advertising.
===Music=== Bunker Hill is also the title of (and referenced in) the 1992 song from the ''[[Free-for-All (Michael Penn album)|Free-for-All]]'' album by Angeleno transplant [[Michael Penn]] and a [[B-Side|B-side]] of the [[Red Hot Chili Peppers]]. [[Jim Dawson]]'s 2008 book ''[[Angels Flight]]'' includes several chapters, complete with many dozens of early photos, on Bunker Hill and its literary and film background.
===Books=== Bunker Hill is the setting for much of [[Robin Robertson]]'s 2018 verse narrative ''The Long Take'' which won the 2018 [[Goldsmiths Prize]]. The book includes a map of the old Bunker Hill neighbourhood.
===Other media=== It is represented in the 2013 video game ''[[Grand Theft Auto V]]'' as "Pillbox Hill" ("Pillbox" and "Bunker" being similar) in the game's rendition of Los Angeles as Los Santos.
==Fire service== [[Image:LAFD Station - 3.JPG|thumb|Fire Station 3 Downtown]] [[Los Angeles Fire Department]] operates fire [https://web.archive.org/web/20061212060030/http://www.lafd.org/fs3.htm Station 3] (Civic Center/Bunker Hill) in the area.
==Education== The area is served by the [[Los Angeles USD]].
==Notable people== * [[Richard Crenna]], actor * [[John Fante]], American novelist * [[Jack Webb]], actor, producer, creator of [[Dragnet (franchise)|Dragnet]] and [[Adam-12]] * [[Otto J. Zahn]], Los Angeles City Council member in the 1920s and pigeon racer
== References ==

revision.text:
[[File:Un homme passant la serpillière sur les marches d'un bar.jpg|thumb|upright|Chores such as [[mop]]ping outdoors can be busy work.]] '''Busy work''' (also referred to as '''make-work''' and '''busywork''') can refer to activity that is undertaken to pass time and stay busy but in and of itself has no actual value. Busy work also occurs in business, military and other settings, in situations where people may be required to be present but may lack the opportunities, skills or need to do something more productive. People may engage in busy work to maintain an appearance of activity, in order to avoid criticism of being inactive or idle. The Merriam Webster dictionary defines busywork as "work that usually appears productive or of intrinsic value but actually only keeps one occupied." <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/busywork|title=Definition of BUSYWORK|website=www.merriam-webster.com|language=en|access-date=2018-08-30}}</ref>
==Educational settings== In the context of education, busy work allows students to work independently, to test their own knowledge and skills, and to practice using new skills [[Learning|learned]] in the educational setting.<ref name="BostonPTA">(1901) [https://books.google.com/books?id=n2BMAAAAIAAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false Plans for busy work - Boston Primary Teachers' Association - Google Books<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> It can consist of various types of [[schoolwork]] assigned by a teacher to keep students occupied with activities involving learning and cognition while the teacher focuses upon another group of students.<ref name="BostonPTA"/> The functionality of busy work is associated with levels of interest students have with the content of the work, levels of enjoyment students have in performing the work, how purposeful the work is, and how accomplishment of the work is perceived by students.<ref name="BostonPTA"/> The perceived results of the work by students is significant: when students feel that they've succeeded in accomplishing a functional task, it's congruent with learning and the attainment of new skills.<ref name="BostonPTA"/>
Busy work can also be used to keep the students occupied with educational tasks during idle times, such as instances when time in school remains but the day's curriculum has already concluded.<ref name="BostonPTA"/> This application of busy work to consume idle time was common in [[primary education]], but the need for work to have educational content, rather than existing just to consume time, is now preferred.<ref>{{citation |page=475 |chapter=Busy work |author=[[Paul Monroe]] |title=A Cyclopedia of Education |year=1910}}</ref>
Busy work has historical precedent in [[primary education]]. Conditioning students to believe that busy work carries the same value as progressive work can lead to students maintaining this belief later in life, carrying it through to the workplace.
==Business and work settings== [[File:Lightmatter paperwork.jpg|thumb|The constant processing of [[wikt:paperwork|paperwork]] can be a form of busy work, particularly in situations when it is a lower priority compared to other tasks.]] In business and work settings, people may engage in busy work simply to appear like they're being busy and productive, with the primary goal of actually simply maintaining an ''appearance'' of activity in efforts to protect their employment status (to avoid [[termination of employment|termination]] or sanctions).<ref name="Slack">(2001) [https://books.google.com/books?id=3AuP7HV14SYC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false Slack: Getting Past Burnout, Busywork, and the Myth of Total Efficiency - Tom DeMarco - Google Books <!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Workers believe that it is more important to maintain a constant appearance of working urgently so that they and others believe that what is being done is important. Constant urgency in workers can lead to disproportionate distribution of actual work, as workers may put off important work by attempting to complete previously-designated less important work. Maintaining very high levels of constant busyness may actually be detrimental to the operations of a business or organization in which new tasks are not undertaken in a timely manner because workers are always very busy.<ref name="Slack"/> That can also lead to workers taking shortcuts to accomplish tasks more quickly, which can negatively affect the quality of work results.<ref name="Slack"/> Busy work also can be counterproductive in work settings because it may not be aligned with the overall objectives and priorities of an organization's plans for attaining and maintaining success in its ventures.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/johnkotter/2012/01/19/why-busy-work-doesnt-work/ | title=Why Busy Work Doesn't Work | publisher=Forbes Magazine | date=January 19, 2012 | accessdate=September 1, 2012 | author=Kotter, John}}</ref> The assumption that activity in the workplace is more important than productivity in the workplace can lead to employees thinking that quantity of work is better than quality of work, which is not productive to the overall functioning of a business.
==Military settings== Busy work is used in armed forces to keep servicemembers from becoming bored, inactive and idle. Tasks of this sort include [[military parade|drill]], memorizing regulations, getting haircuts, [[spit and polish]]ing footwear and other cleaning chores such as [[holystone|scrubbing the deck]].<ref>{{citation |page=356 |title=The Greenwood Encyclopedia of Daily Life in America: The War of Independence and antebellum expansion and reform, 1763-1861 |author=Randall M. Miller |year=2009 |isbn= 9780313337031}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=The Treatment of Dipsomaniacs|journal=The British Medical Journal|volume=1|issue=741|publisher=British Medical Journal|date =13 March 1875|location =London|jstor=25240702}}</ref>
==See also== {{portal|Education|Business and economics}} {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Parkinson's law]] * [[Boondoggle (project)]] * [[Displacement activity]] * [[Handwaving]] * [[Make-work job]] * [[Hobby|Pastime]] * [[Penal labour]] * [[Red tape]] * [[Underpants Gnomes]] * [[Vacuum activity]] * [[Workhouse]]
{{div col end}}
==References== {{reflist}}
===Additional sources=== * (1909) [https://books.google.com/books?id=IP8VAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover Education by doing: occupations and busy work for primary classes - Anna Johnson - Google Books<!-- Bot generated title -->] * (2010) [https://books.google.com/books?id=iLZ7FK0Z0BYC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false Do More Great Work: Stop the Busywork, and Start the Work That Matters - Michael Bungay Stanier - Google Books<!-- Bot generated title -->] * [https://www.usatoday.com/money/smallbusiness/columnist/edmunds/2006-04-11-busy-work_x.htm USATODAY.com - Be sure 'busy work' isn't keeping you from growing your business<!-- Bot generated title -->] * (2012) [https://www.forbes.com/sites/johnkotter/2012/01/19/why-busy-work-doesnt-work/]<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kotter|first1=John|title=Why Busy Work Doesn't Work}}</ref>
==External links== * {{Wiktionary-inline}}
* [http://onlineassignmentexperts.com Editing busy writing work]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Busy Work}} [[Category:School terminology]] [[Category:Standards-based education]] [[Category:Education reform]] [[Category:Business terms]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Christoph Gerlinger | image = Christoph Gerlinger.jpg | caption = Christoph Gerlinger, 2008 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1967|07|27}} | birth_place = [[Hessen]], Frankfurt am Main, [[West Germany]] | nationality = [[Germany|German]] | occupation = Founder and CEO of [http://www.german-startups.com German Startups Group Berlin GmbH & Co. KGaA] | alma mater = JW Goethe University (1988 - 1992) | known for = Founder and CEO of Frogster Interactive Pictures AG }} '''Christoph Gerlinger'''<ref>[http://www.startupbootcamp.org/mentors/christoph-gerlinger/ startupbootcamp] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120922000715/http://www.startupbootcamp.org/mentors/christoph-gerlinger/ |date=2012-09-22 }}. Christoph Gerlinger</ref> (born July 27, 1967 in [[Frankfurt/Main]], [[West Germany]] and raised there) is a German [[venture capitalist]] and [[Internet entrepreneur]]. He is best known as the founder and CEO of the [[venture capital]] investor [[German Startups Group Berlin GmbH & Co. KGaA|German Startups Group]], which is publicly listed on the [[Frankfurt Stock Exchange]].<ref>[http://www.goingpublic.de/german-startups-group-startet-der-boerse-ueber-platzierungspreis/]. Going Public, German Startups Group debütiert an der Börse über Platzierungspreis - 11 November 2015</ref><ref>[https://www.wealthmanagement.commerzbank.de/media/wealth_management/pdf_1/20151127_Wertvorstellung_ES.pdf]. Wertvorstellung 01/2016, S. 14 - 17. Der Überflieger. Investieren in Start-ups? Christoph Gerlinger, CEO der German Startups Group, zeigt, wie es funktioniert</ref> Prior to that he was a senior executive and [[entrepreneur]] in computer and [[online game]]s companies since 1996. He was CEO of the [[Massively multiplayer online game|MMO Games]] publisher {{ill|Frogster Interactive Pictures AG|de|Frogster Interactive Pictures|vertical-align=sup}} (now Gameforge Berlin AG),<ref>[http://www.boerse-online.de/aktie/nachrichten/deutschland/:Interview-mit-Christoph-Gerlinger--Fokussieren-statt-diversifizieren/517401.html boerse-online.de]. March, 2010</ref> listed at Frankfurt stock exchange from 2006 until its takeover in 2010.<ref>[http://eon.businesswire.com/news/eon/20100804006296/en Enhanced Online News]. 2010 Gameforge Purchases 60 Percent of Shares in Frogster Interactive Pictures AG</ref> Gerlinger was named one of Germany's most 50 interesting young entrepreneurs by a leading German business magazine.<ref>[http://blog.wiwo.de/gruenderraum/2007/05/01/51f9036695bc2b1e68e19a45df8392c8/ Wirtschafts Woche]. May, 2007 Liste: Die 50 interessantesten Gründer</ref>
== Education and career == Gerlinger earned a master's degree in Business Administration and Management from JW [[Goethe University Frankfurt]] am Main in 1992.
Early in his career, Gerlinger was CFO of the German subsidiary of Psygnosis (Sony Group)(1996 - 1998). Later he was CFO and Co-Founder of [[cdv Software Entertainment|CDV Software Entertainment AG]] (1999 - 2001), listed at the [[Frankfurt Stock Exchange]] from 2000 until 2010, before serving as [[General Manager]] of Atari's German entity Infogrames Deutschland GmbH (2002). In early 2005, Gerlinger founded the MMO Games Publisher Frogster Interactive Pictures AG. He was Frogster's long standing CEO and worked with the team during its critical growth phases.<ref>http://www.german-startups.com/index.php/about-us/</ref> He left Frogster at the end of 2011 after the takeover by its competitor Gameforge.<ref>[http://www.4-traders.com/FROGSTER-INTERACTIVE-PICT-473980/news/Frogster-Interactive-Pictures-AG-Christoph-Gerlinger-resigns-from-Executive-Board-at-Frogster-13870750/ www.4-traders.com]. November, 2011 Frogster Interactive Pictures AG : Christoph Gerlinger resigns from Executive Board at Frogster</ref> He then founded German Startups Group, which was released publicly on 27 July 2012.<ref>https://www.vc-magazin.de/allgemein/german-startups-group-geht-an-den-start/</ref> <ref>[http://www.german-startups.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/120727_GSG_PM-launch_Eng.pdf www.german-startups.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140521180641/http://www.german-startups.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/120727_GSG_PM-launch_Eng.pdf |date=2014-05-21 }}. German Startups Group provides Berlin with breath of fresh capital – press release 27 July 2012</ref> German Startups Group became the second most active venture capital investor in Germany since 2012.<ref>[https://www.cbinsights.com/blog/germany-vc-overview/]. CB Insights, Germany Venture Capital Overview</ref> Gerlinger regularly publishes articles and gives interviews on venture capital and economical topics. <ref>http://www.faz.net/aktuell/finanzen/fonds-mehr/start-ups-in-deutschland-es-ist-zum-heulen-15128337.html</ref> <ref>http://www.german-startups.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/Berlin-Valley-Christoph-Gerlinger.png</ref> <ref>Christoph Gerlinger: Venture Capital als Anlageklasse, in: FAZ, 3. September 2016</ref> <ref>http://www.profil-zeigen.de/christoph-gerlinger-ueber-startups-in-deutschland/</ref> <ref>https://www.4investors.de/php_fe/index.php?sektion=stock&ID=98468</ref> <ref>http://www.manager-magazin.de/unternehmen/artikel/a-976259.html</ref><ref>http://www.german-startups.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/Private-Wealth-Magazin.pdf Wagnis mit Kalkül. Private-Wealth-Magazin 01/2015, S. 68 - 70 </ref> <ref>http://www.german-startups.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/GoingPublic-April-2016.pdf E-Commerce kann auch an der Börse erfolgreich sein. Going Public, April 2016, S. 48 - 49 </ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == *[http://www.facebook.com/christoph.gerlinger Christoph Gerlinger on Facebook]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Gerlinger, Christoph}} [[Category:1967 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:German businesspeople]]

revision.text:
'''David Berry''' (December 1795 – 23 September 1889) was Scottish born horse and cattle breeder, landowner and benefactor in colonial [[New South Wales]].
Berry was the eighth of nine children born to James Berrie (died 1827) and his wife Isabel Tod (died 1830) and was baptised 29 December 1795.<ref>Baptisms (OPR). Scotland. Cupar, Fife. 29 December 1795. BERRY, David. 420/00 0030 0122. http://www.scotlandspeople.gov.uk : accessed 13 Jul 2014.</ref><ref> {{Australian Dictionary of Biography |first=M. D. |last=Stephen |title=Berry, David (1795–1889) |id2=berry-david-2983 |accessdate=13 November 2013 }}</ref> [[Alexander Berry]] was his eldest brother.<ref name=SMH> {{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13741347 |title=Death of Mr. David Berry |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=24 September 1889 |accessdate=25 August 2014 |page=8 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
Berry was born at [[Cupar]], [[Fife]], Scotland, and was educated at the [[University of St Andrews]].<ref name=Mennell>{{cite Australasia|Berry, David}}</ref> He arrived in New South Wales on board the ''Midlothian''<ref name=SMH/> in July 1836, and proceeded to the estate of his elder brother, Dr. Alexander Berry, at [[Coolangatta Estate]], which he managed in conjunction with another brother, John, for eleven years, and after the latter's death carried on the concern alone until 1873, when Dr. Alexander Berry died and devised the whole of his property to his brother David, who followed the system of cultivating and fencing a large portion of his land whilst the remainder was leased out in farms of varying size on peculiar and unusually profitable terms.<ref name=Mennell/> Mr. Berry died, at the age of ninety-three, on 23 September 1889, and by his will bequeathed £100,000 to his ''alma mater'', St. Andrews University, and a like sum to found a hospital in the [[City of Shoalhaven|Shoalhaven]] district of New South Wales.<ref name=Mennell/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Berry, David}} [[Category:1795 births]] [[Category:1889 deaths]] [[Category:Australian businesspeople]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of St Andrews]] [[Category:Scottish philanthropists]] [[Category:Settlers of Australia]] [[Category:Scottish emigrants to colonial Australia]] [[Category:People from Cupar]]

{{Orphan|date=August 2014}}
{{Infobox person | name = Evgeny Markin | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = 20 January 1975 | birth_place = [[USSR]] | nationality = [[Russia]]n | education = [[Diplomatic Academy of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Russian Federation]] in Moscow, Russia | occupation = Businessman, [[public figure]] and politician. }}
'''Evgeny L. Markin''' (in [[Russian language|Russian]]: Евгений Леонидович Маркин; born in 1975), is a [[Russia]]n businessman, public figure and politician.
== Education ==
Graduated from school with advanced study of Chinese in [[Vladivostok]].<ref name="PrimaMedia">[http://primamedia.ru/news/11.05.2012/205165/primore-stanet-zhemchuzhinoy-rossii-regionom-s-mirovim-urovnem-zhizni---evgeniy-.html Приморье станет жемчужиной России, регионом с мировым уровнем жизни] // PrimaMedia</ref> In 1997 Markin finished Far Eastern State Academy of Economics and Management with a degree in economics. In 2010 he graduated from Diplomatic Academy of [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Russia)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs]].
== Business career ==
* From 1995 until 1998 worked in leading travel companies(Bureau of International Youth Tourism "Sputnik", Travel Business Club "Olga"). Evgeny Markin was a specialist in the direction of outbound tourism in Southeast Asia. * From 1998 until 2001 worked in travel agency “Westminster” (Hong Kong). * From 2001 until 2006 Markin led the company «Bysiness Symbol», which provided consulting services in GR in South-East Asia for Russian entrepreneurs. * Since 2013 he has worked in LLC “Stroygazmontazh” as Advisor to General Director on cooperation with Asia-Pacific countries
==Public and political career==
*From December 2006 to April 2008 Evgeny Markin worked in the Administration of [[Primorsky Krai|Primorsky Territory]], held an office as: ** Deputy Head of the representative office of the Primorsky Territory Administration under the Government of the Russian Federation (Moscow); ** Deputy Director of the International Cooperation and Tourism Department of the Primorsky Territory Administration;<ref name="PrimaMedia" /><ref name="Аргументы и Факты">[http://www.vl.aif.ru/culture/art/56167 Европа с азиатским колоритом] // Еженедельник "Аргументы и Факты" № 7 от 15 февраля 2012</ref> ** Assistant to Governor of the Primorsky Territory Administration; * From April 2008 until March 2009 he worked in the Ministry of Regional Development of the Russian Federation and held positions, such as: ** Assistant on the realization of the Olympic objects construction programme; ** Deputy Head of the Northern Territories Development Section of the Far East and Northern Territories Development Department; * From June 2010 to August 2012 Markin was the Director of the International Cooperation and Tourism Department of Primorsky Territory in the Administration of Primorsky Territory, Assistant to Governor of the Primorsky Territory Administration. * In September 2012 he held an office of the Assistant to Minister, Head of the Secretariat in the Ministry of Regional Development. * Evgeny Markin is one of the founders of [http://rusca.ru/ "Voskresenie" Russian Cultural Association], established by the initiative of the nationals, who are living in the southern China, for the performance of public activities and development of national and cultural relations between Russia and China. * Markin Evgeny is the Adviser to Secretary of Patriarchal Council on Culture for cooperation with [[PRC]] [[Archimandrite]] [[Tikhon (Shevkunov)]]<ref name="Patriarchia.ru">[http://www.patriarchia.ru/db/text/3672585.html Готовится китайский перевод книги «"Несвятые святые" и другие рассказы»] // Official page of [[Patriarchate of Moscow and all the Rus']]</ref><ref name="Pravoslavie.ru">[http://www.pravoslavie.ru/news/71432.htm Готовится китайский перевод книги «"Несвятые святые" и другие рассказы»] // Православие.Ru</ref><ref name="Patriarchia.ru2">[http://www.patriarchia.ru/db/text/3672693.html В Шанхае подписано соглашение о создании Центра изучения православной культуры] // Official page of [[Patriarchate of Moscow and all the Rus']]</ref><ref name="Pravoslavie.ru2">[http://www.pravoslavie.ru/news/71442.htm В Шанхае подписано соглашение о создании Центра изучения православной культуры] // Православие.Ru</ref>
== Hobbies and interests ==
Speaks fluent Chinese and English. Married, has daughter and son.
==References== <references/>

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Francesco De Rubertis | caption = Partner at medicxi | alma_mater = [[University of Pavia]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]])
[[University of Geneva]] ([[Ph.D.]]) | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1970|1|23}} | birth_place = [[Italy]] | occupation = [[Partner (business rank)|Partner]] at medicxi | spouse = Sandra Henchoz De Rubertis (separated since 2013) }} '''Francesco De Rubertis''' (born January 23, 1970) is a partner at medicxi, a [[venture capital]] firm with offices in [[London]], Jersey and [[Geneva]], having co-founded the firm in February 2016.{{cite news |title= J&J and GSK join Medicxi’s European life sciences push |url= http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/10e91eac-c921-11e5-be0b-b7ece4e953a0.html#axzz3yzLTOazH |work= FT |date= February 2, 2016}} Prior to that he was a partner at another venture capital firm, [[Index Ventures]], having led the firm’s efforts to establish its life sciences practice after joining in 1997.{{cite news |title= Veni, vidi, V.C.|url=http://www.unige.ch/presse/campus/pdf/c83/etudiantEs.pdf|work= University of Geneva student magazine|date= November 6, 2009}} ==Early life and education== De Rubertis was born in [[Italy]]. He graduated from the [[University of Pavia]] with a [[Bachelor of Arts]] in [[Genetics]] and [[Microbiology]], before earning a [[Ph.D.]] in [[Molecular Biology]] from the [[University of Geneva]], where he also met his wife, Sandra Henchoz, who was a fellow student. De Rubertis engaged in [[postdoctoral research]] in [[molecular genetics]] at the [[Whitehead Institute]] at [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] (MIT), and later earned the [[Chartered Financial Analyst]] (CFA) designation.{{cite news|title= Executive Profile|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=160717&privcapId=111656446&previousCapId=91996&previousTitle=Index%20Ventures|work= Bloomberg Businessweek|date= May 10, 2013}} ==Career== After his postdoctoral work at MIT, in 1997 De Rubertis moved back to [[Geneva]], where he joined Index Ventures and helped co-found the firm’s [[life sciences]] practice. In 2009 he moved to [[London]] (site of another Index office) where he continues to reside.{{cite news |title= Veni, vidi, V.C.|url=http://www.unige.ch/presse/campus/pdf/c83/etudiantEs.pdf|work= University of Geneva student magazine|date= November 6, 2009}} De Rubertis is responsible for all of Index Ventures’ investments in the life sciences. He has served on the Boards of Directors of many companies, including Addex Therapeutics ({{SWX|ADXN}}), CellZome (acquired by [[GlaxoSmithKline]] for $120 Million {{cite news |title= GSK acquires Cellzome 100% |url=http://www.eurobiotechnews.eu/news/news/2012-02/gsk-acquires-cellzome-100.html|work= EuroBiotechnologyNews|date= May 15, 2012}}), [[Genmab]] ({{OMX|CSE11143|GEN}}), Molecular Partners ({{SWX|MOLN}}), PanGenetics (acquired by [[Abbott Laboratories]]), and Parallele Bioscience (acquired by [[Affymetrix]]).{{cite news|title= GSK Press release|url=http://us.gsk.com/html/media-news/pressreleases/2012/2012-pressrelease-1090596.htm|work= GlaxoSmithKline|date= May 15, 2012}} In 2012 De Rubertis spearheaded the launch of Index Ventures’ $200 Million life sciences fund in partnership with [[GlaxoSmithKline]] (GSK) and [[Johnson & Johnson]] (J&J), to invest in early-stage biotechnology companies .{{cite news |title= Index Launches Its First Life Sciences Fund: $200M And Partnering With Glaxo and Johnson & Johnson |url=https://techcrunch.com/2012/03/20/index-launches-its-first-life-sciences-fund-200m-and-partnering-with-glaxo-and-johnson-johnson/|work= [[TechCrunch]]|date= March 20, 2012}} De Rubertis is the author of several publications in international scientific journals.{{cite web|title=Google Scholar search: "Francesco De Rubertis"|url=https://scholar.google.com/scholar?q=%22Francesco+De+Rubertis%22&btnG=&hl=en&as_sdt=0%2C7 }} In 2010 De Rubertis was named by ''BioWorld'' as one of 28 "movers and shakers" predicted to shape the biotechnology industry over the next two decades .{{cite news |title= The Future Is Here: Who Will Shape Biotech Over the Next 20 Years? BioWorld Says…|url= http://www.bioworld.com/img/BIO20.pdf|work= BioWorld 20th Anniversary Edition|year= 2010}} In October 2012 De Rubertis was named by ''[[Xconomy]]'' as one of 40 of “Young and Proven” biotech venture capitalists.{{cite news |title= Who Will Survive the Biotech VC Downturn? The Young and the Proven|url= http://www.xconomy.com/national/2012/10/22/who-will-survive-the-biotech-vc-downturn-the-young-and-the-proven/|work= [[Xconomy]]|date= October 22, 2012}} De Rubertis is a member of the Strategic Advisory Board of the University of Geneva.{{cite web|url=https://www.medicxi.com/team/francesco-de-rubertis|title=Medicxi Partner bio: Francesco De Rubertis|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} In February 2016 De Rubertis launches an independent venture capital firm Medicxi (formerly Index Ventures Life Sciences) and announces the closing of Medicxi Ventures 1 (MV1) a €210m fund including GSK and Johnson & Johnson Innovation.{{Cite web|url=https://www.medicxi.com/news/medicxi-formerly-index-ventures-life-sciences-launches-as-an-independent-venture-capital-firm-and-announces-closing-of-a-210m-fund-including-gsk-and-johnson-johnson-innovation|title=Medicxi Ventures, Formerly Index Ventures Life Sciences, Launches as an Independent Venture Capital Firm and Announces Closing of a €210m Fund including GSK and Johnson & Johnson Innovation {{!}} Medicxi|website=www.medicxi.com|access-date=2017-12-09}} Medicxi is managed by four Partners Francesco de Rubertis, Kevin Johnson, David Grainger and Michèle Ollier all of whom previously led the Life Sciences practice at Index Ventures. On November 30, 2017 De Rubertis was named in the Bloomberg Top 50 most influential people of 2017. He was selected as one of 10 nominees in the Tech (& Science) category along with Elon Musk (Tesla, SpaceX), Masayoshi Son (Softbank Group) and Martin Lau (Tencent Holdings).{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/features/2017-bloomberg-50/|title=Meet This Year’s Bloomberg 50|work=Bloomberg.com|access-date=2017-12-09}} The Bloomberg Top 50 consists of 5 categories Tech (& Science), Business, Politics, Finance and Entertainment. De Rubertis’s reputation for halving the time it takes for a return on biotech investments has Silicon Valley eager to get in on a $300 million fund he’s raised for late-stage startups. Medicxi Growth 1, which made its first investments in health care and diabetes treatments, is taking minority stakes in companies that are developing multiple therapies, have full management teams, and intend to go public as independent businesses. This is a departure for De Rubertis. He has focused on “skinny” startups—with small management teams and only one therapy—that can integrate into larger companies after being bought. The shift hasn’t diminished interest in the fund. Verily, Alphabet Inc.’s life-sciences arm, has also invested in MG-1 ==External links== * [http://www.medicxiventures.com medicxi website] * [http://www.indexventures.com Index Ventures website] * {{Twitter}} ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:De Rubertis, Francesco}} [[Category:1970 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Venture capitalists]] [[Category:Italian businesspeople]] [[Category:University of Pavia alumni]] [[Category:University of Geneva alumni]]

{{Infobox person | name = Gedvydas Vainauskas | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1955|11|7}} | birth_place = [[Utena]], [[Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic|Lithuanian SSR]], [[Soviet Union]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = Lithuanian | other_names = | occupation = | years_active = | alma_mater = [[Vilnius University]] | spouse = Bronė Vainauskienė (divorced in 2013);
Liuminata Vainauskienė (married in 2014) | children = Jonas Vainauskas | parents = }} '''Gedvydas Vainauskas''' (born November 7, 1955) is a Lithuanian journalist, publishing company [[Lietuvos rytas]] Chief Editor, shareholder, founder and former [[BC Lietuvos rytas]] president. ==Biography== Vainauskas graduated Kaunas 4th High School. Following it, he gained a journalism degree in [[Vilnius University]] in 1979. Vainauskas is the largest shares holder of [[Lietuvos rytas]] (25,5 % in 2009), founder and former president of [[BC Lietuvos rytas]] for 20 years from 1997 to 2017.{{cite web|title="Lietuvos ryto" akcininkai pritarė akcijų pardavimui "Snorui"|url=http://www.delfi.lt/verslas/medija/lietuvos-ryto-akcininkai-pritare-akciju-pardavimui-snorui.d?id=22997691|website=DELFI.lt|accessdate=8 July 2009}} He resigned from the basketball club president post after international [[racism]] scandal in 2017.{{cite news|last1=Ward-Henninger|first1=Colin|title=Lithuanian pro basketball team president blames team's struggles on black players|url=http://www.cbssports.com/nba/news/lithuanian-pro-basketball-team-president-blames-teams-struggles-on-black-players/|accessdate=17 June 2017|work=CBSSports.com|date=15 June 2017}}{{cite web|title=G. Vainausko pareiškimas apie juodaodžius žaidėjus sukėlė tikrą audrą|url=http://www.delfi.lt/krepsinis/naujienos/g-vainausko-pareiskimas-apie-juodaodzius-zaidejus-sukele-tikra-audra.d?id=74956802|website=Krepsinis.lt|accessdate=15 June 2017}}{{cite web|title=ESPN žurnalistai sumaišė G. Vainauską su žemėmis ir išvadino idiotu|url=http://www.delfi.lt/krepsinis/naujienos/espn-zurnalistai-sumaise-g-vainauska-su-zememis-ir-isvadino-idiotu.d?id=74970742|website=Krepsinis.lt|accessdate=17 June 2017}}{{cite web|title=Eurolygos drausmės komisija pradėjo tyrimą dėl Vainausko pasisakymo|url=https://www.basketnews.lt/news-110632-eurolygos-drausmes-komisija-pradejo-tyrima-del-vainausko-pasisakymo.html|website=BasketNews.lt|accessdate=16 June 2017|language=lt}}{{cite web|title=R. Šimašius kirto G. Vainauskui dėl rasizmo|url=http://www.delfi.lt/news/daily/lithuania/r-simasius-kirto-g-vainauskui-del-rasizmo.d?id=74960432|website=DELFI.lt|accessdate=16 June 2017}}{{cite web|title=Gedvydas Vainauskas oficialiai atsistatydina iš "Lietuvos ryto" klubo prezidento pareigų|url=http://sportas.lrytas.lt/krepsinis/2017/06/20/news/gedvydas-vainauskas-oficialiai-atsistatydina-is-lietuvos-ryto-klubo-prezidento-pareigu-1731479/|website=lrytas.lt|accessdate=20 June 2017|language=lt-LT}}{{cite web|title=Per visą pasaulį nuskambėjusiam G.Vainauskui – pasmerkimas net iš NBA žvaigždžių|url=https://www.15min.lt/24sek/naujiena/lietuva/per-visa-pasauli-nuskambejusiam-g-vainauskui-pasmerkimas-net-is-nba-zvaigzdziu-875-815536|website=24sek.lt|accessdate=21 June 2017}} ==Personal life== Vainauskas has a son Jonas Vainauskas with his first wife Bronė Vainauskienė. They have divorced in 2013.{{cite web|title="Lietuvos ryto" vyr.redaktoriaus G.Vainausko žmona prašo ją išskirti dėl sutuoktinio kaltės|url=http://www.delfi.lt/verslas/medija/lietuvos-ryto-vyrredaktoriaus-gvainausko-zmona-praso-ja-isskirti-del-sutuoktinio-kaltes.d?id=60466711|website=DELFI.lt|accessdate=18 January 2017}} In 2014, he married his second wife Liuminata Mickutė during wedding ceremony which was held in [[Venice]], [[Italy]].{{cite web|title=Venecijoje Gedvydas Vainauskas vedė 29-eriais metais jaunesnę Liuminatą Mickutę|url=https://www.15min.lt/vardai/naujiena/lietuva/venecijoje-gedvydas-vainauskas-vede-29-eriais-metais-jaunesne-liuminata-mickute-1050-456048|website=15min.lt|accessdate=26 September 2014}} ==Decorations== *2000: Commander's Cross of the [[Order of the Lithuanian Grand Duke Gediminas]] (by president [[Valdas Adamkus]] decree) ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Vainauskas, Gedvydas}} [[Category:1955 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Utena]] [[Category:Vilnius University alumni]] [[Category:Lithuanian journalists]] [[Category:Lithuanian businesspeople]] [[Category:Lithuanian mass media owners]] [[Category:2017 controversies]] [[Category:Racism in sport]] [[Category:20th-century Lithuanian businesspeople]] [[Category:21st-century Lithuanian businesspeople]]

{{Infobox officeholder |name = Gregorio S. Araneta |image = Gregorio S. Araneta.jpg |image_size = 220px <!-- --> |office = [[Taft Commission|Philippine Commission]] |term_start = February 25, 1909 |term_end = October 27, 1913 |appointer = |predecessor = |successor = <!-- --> |office2 = [[Department of Justice (Philippines)|Secretary of Finance and Justice]] |term_start2 = July 1, 1908 |term_end2 = October 10, 1913 |appointer2 = [[Governor-General of the Philippines|Governor-General]] [[James Francis Smith]] |predecessor2 = [[Henry C. Ide]] |successor2 = [[Victorino Mapa]] <!-- --> |office3 = [[Solicitor-General of the Philippines|Attorney General of the Philippines]] |term_start3 = July 16, 1906 |term_end3 = July 1, 1908 |predecessor3= Lebbeus R. Wifley |successor3 = Ignacio Villamor <!-- --> |office4 = [[Solicitor-General of the Philippines]] |term_start4 = June 15, 1901 |term_end4 = July 16, 1906 |predecessor4= ''office created'' |successor4 = Ignacio Villamor <!-- --> |office5 = [[Malolos Republic|Vice-President of the Assembly of Representatives]] |term_start5 = September 15, 1898 |term_end5 = November 13, 1899 <!-- --> |birth_date = April 16, 1869<ref name="NHCP">{{Cite sign|title=Gregorio Araneta y Soriano (1869–1930)|type=historical marker|language=tl|year=1988|publisher=[[National Historical Commission of the Philippines]]}}</ref> |birth_place = [[Molo, Iloilo]], [[Captaincy General of the Philippines]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1930|5|9|1869|4|16|mf=y}} |death_place = [[Manila]], [[Insular Government of the Philippine Islands|Philippine Islands]] |other_names = Don Gregorio Araneta y Soriano |spouse = [[Carmen Zaragoza y Rojas]] |known_for = |occupation = [[lawyer]] and [[businessman]] |nationality = [[Filipino people|Filipino]] }}
'''[[Don (honorific)|Don]] Gregorio Soriano Araneta''' (born ''' Gregorio Araneta y Soriano'''; April 16, 1869 – May 9, 1930) was a [[Filipino people|Filipino]] [[lawyer]], [[businessman]], [[nationalist]] and [[patriotism|patriot]], during the [[History of the Philippines (1521–1898)|Spanish]] and [[History of the Philippines (1898-1946)|American colonial periods]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.nhi.gov.ph/downloads/fihgov0012.pdf | title=Gregorio S. Araneta | work=National Historical Institute }}</ref>
==Early life and career== In 1891, he graduated from the [[University of Santo Tomas]] with a degree in law. He defended prominent Filipinos accused of financially supporting the [[Katipunan]].
In May 1898, Araneta was appointed member of the 21-man Consultative Assembly, which the Spanish [[Governor-General of the Philippines]] [[Basilio Agustin]] formed in an attempt to rally Filipinos to the Spanish side of the [[Spanish–American War]]. This assembly, however, failed.
===Aguinaldo's Cabinet=== Araneta participated in the drafting of the [[Malolos Constitution]]. He resigned as Secretary and accepted his appointment as Justice of the Ministry of Justice.
===Supreme Court=== On January 25, 1899, the Diplomatic Corps of the [[First Philippine Republic]] was organized and Araneta was among those appointed as member but he chose to abandon the revolutionary government. Months after the [[Philippine–American War]] broke out, America established the civil courts in the Philippines. In May 1899, General [[Elwell Otis]] appointed Araneta as Associate Justice of the [[Philippine Supreme Court]], the youngest to occupy the position at 30 years old. Araneta's sympathies became clearer when he joined the [[Federal Party (Philippines)|Federal Party]] that favored America’s annexation of the Philippines.
===Bureau of Justice=== On June 15, 1901, he was appointed [[Solicitor General (Philippines)|Solicitor General]]. When Attorney General Libbeus R. Wifley accepted a post in China, Araneta was made his successor. He took his oath of office as Attorney General on July 16, 1906. Two years after, July 1, 1908, he was appointed to the [[Taft Commission|Philippine Commission]] and at the same time Secretary of Justice and Finance. He was the first Filipino to hold a sensitive post, being a commissioner with portfolio. He resigned from government service on October 10, 1913. With Salvador Zaragoza, he established a law office, which attracted many clients.
==Later career== During the [[Philippine Senate elections, 1916|first Senatorial election in 1916]], he ran for a seat in the Senate but lost to [[Rafael Palma]]. That same year, he accepted a teaching post in the [[University of Santo Tomas]] and at the same attended to his private law practice. Araneta convinced the Supreme Court to reverse its previous decision on two cases. Araneta also gained respect for his ethical principles.{{CN|date=March 2015}} He turned down the offer of House Speaker [[Sergio Osmeña]] to seat as Chief Justice of the Supreme Court in favor of [[Manuel Araullo]], who he thought to be more deserving for the post. He was again offered the same position during the time of Senate President [[Manuel Luis Quezon]] but he also declined, this time for ''[[delicadeza]]'', because he was then involved in a case pending before the Supreme Court.
==Personal life== Araneta married [[Carmen Zaragoza y Rojas]] on March 7, 1896. The couple had 14 children: Carmen, Jose, Salvador, Consuelo, Paz, Rosa, Antonio, Teresa, Ramon, Vicente, Conchita, Margarita, Luis and Francisco.
==Death== He died on May 9, 1930 of [[myocardial infarction]].
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Authority control}}

revision.comment: /* Critical evaluation */
revision.text:
[[File:Folio Plot BCG Matrix Example.png|BCG Matrix|thumb|Portfolio growth–share matrix]] {{Strategy}} The '''growth–share matrix''' (aka the '''product portfolio matrix''', '''Boston Box''', '''BCG-matrix''', '''Boston matrix''', '''[[Boston Consulting Group]] analysis''', '''portfolio diagram''') is a chart that was created by [[Bruce D. Henderson]] for the [[Boston Consulting Group]] in 1970 to help corporations to analyze their business units, that is, their [[product line]]s. This helps the company allocate resources and is used as an analytical tool in [[brand|brand marketing]], [[product management]], [[strategic management]], and [[Modern portfolio theory|portfolio analysis]]. Some analysis of market performance by firms using its principles has called its usefulness into question. == Overview == To use the chart, analysts plot a [[scatter graph]] to rank the business units (or products) on the basis of their relative [[market share]]s and growth rates. *'''''[[Cash cow]]s''''' is where a company has high market share in a slow-growing industry. These units typically generate cash in excess of the amount of cash needed to maintain the business. They are regarded as staid and boring, in a "mature" market, yet corporations value owning them due to their cash-generating qualities. They are to be "milked" continuously with as little investment as possible, since such investment would be wasted in an industry with low growth. *'''''Dogs''''', more charitably called ''pets'', are units with low market share in a mature, slow-growing industry. These units typically "break even", generating barely enough cash to maintain the business's market share. Though owning a break-even unit provides the social benefit of providing jobs and possible synergies that assist other business units, from an accounting point of view such a unit is worthless, not generating cash for the company. They depress a profitable company's [[return on assets]] ratio, used by many investors to judge how well a company is being managed. ''Dogs'', it is thought, should be sold off. *'''''Question marks''''' (also known as '''problem children''' or '''Wild cats''') are businesses operating with a low market share in a high-growth market. They are a starting point for most businesses. Question marks have a potential to gain market share and become stars, and eventually cash cows when market growth slows. If question marks do not succeed in becoming a market leader, then after perhaps years of cash consumption, they will degenerate into dogs when market growth declines. Question marks must be analyzed carefully in order to determine whether they are worth the investment required to grow market share. *'''''Stars''''' are units with a high market share in a fast-growing industry. They are graduated ''question marks'' with a market- or niche-leading trajectory, for example: amongst market share front-runners in a high-growth sector, and/or having a [[monopolistic]] or increasingly dominant [[USP (marketing)|unique selling proposition]] with burgeoning/fortuitous [[proposition (value)|proposition]] drive(s) from: novelty (e.g. [[Last.FM upon CBS Interactive's due diligence]]), fashion/promotion (e.g. newly prestigious [[List of celebrity-branded fragrances|celebrity-branded fragrance]]s), [[customer loyalty]] (e.g. [[greenfield (investment)|greenfield]] or [[military]]/[[gang enforcement]] backed, and/or innovative, [[grey-market]]/[[illicit retail of addictive drugs]], for instance the British East India Company's, late-1700s opium-based Qianlong Emperor embargo-busting, [[Canton System]]), [[goodwill (accounting)|goodwill]] (e.g. [[Monopsony|monopsonies]]) and/or [[leverage (finance)|gearing]] (e.g. [[Oligopoly|oligopolies]], for instance [[Portland cement producer]]s near [[boomtown]]s),{{citation needed| date= December 2013| pending= I have an authoritative cutting filed/to-bring, from FT or Economist as I recall.}} etc. The hope is that stars become next cash cows. :Stars require high funding to fight competitors and maintain their growth rate. When industry growth slows, if they remain a niche leader or are amongst the market leaders, stars become cash cows; otherwise, they become dogs due to low relative market share. As a particular industry matures and its growth slows, all business units become either ''cash cows'' or ''dogs''. The natural cycle for most business units is that they start as ''question marks'', then turn into ''stars''. Eventually, the market stops growing; thus, the business unit becomes a ''cash cow''. At the end of the cycle, the cash cow turns into a ''dog''. As BCG stated in 1970:
Only a diversified company with a balanced portfolio can use its strengths to truly capitalize on its growth opportunities. The balanced portfolio has: *stars whose high share and high growth assure the future; *cash cows that supply funds for that future growth; and *question marks to be converted into stars with the added funds.
==Practical use== "''To be successful, a company should have a portfolio of products with different growth rates and different market shares. The portfolio composition is a function of the balance between cash flows. High growth products require cash inputs to grow. Low growth products should generate excess cash. Both kinds are needed simultaneously.''"—Bruce Henderson.{{cite web|last=Henderson|first=Bruce|title=The Product Portfolio|url=https://www.bcgperspectives.com/content/classics/strategy_the_product_portfolio/|accessdate=3 April 2013}} For each product or service, the 'area' of the circle represents the value of its sales. The growth–share matrix thus offers a "map" of the organization's product (or service) strengths and weaknesses, at least in terms of current profitability, as well as the likely cashflows. The need which prompted this idea was, indeed, that of managing cash-flow. It was reasoned that one of the main indicators of cash generation was relative market share, and one which pointed to cash usage was that of market growth rate. ===Relative market share=== This indicates likely cash generation, because the higher the share the more cash will be generated. As a result of 'economies of scale' (a basic assumption of the BCG Matrix), it is assumed that these earnings will grow faster the higher the share. The exact measure is the brand's share relative to its largest competitor. Thus, if the brand had a share of 20 percent, and the largest competitor had the same, the ratio would be 1:1. If the largest competitor had a share of 60 percent, however, the ratio would be 1:3, implying that the organization's brand was in a relatively weak position. If the largest competitor only had a share of 5 percent, the ratio would be 4:1, implying that the brand owned was in a relatively strong position, which might be reflected in profits and cash flows. If this technique is used in practice, this scale is logarithmic, not linear. On the other hand, exactly what is a high relative share is a matter of some debate. The best evidence is that the most stable position (at least in [[fast-moving consumer goods]] markets) is for the brand leader to have a share double that of the second brand, and triple that of the third. Brand leaders in this position tend to be very stable—and profitable; the Rule of 123. The selection of the relative market share metric was based upon its relationship to the experience curve. The market leader would have greater experience curve benefits, which delivers a cost leadership advantage.Fripp, Geoff.[http://www.business-portfolio-analysis.com/the-bcg-matrix-and-the-experience-curve/ "BCG Matrix and the Experience Curve"] Guide to the BCG Matrix Another reason for choosing relative market share, rather than just profits, is that it carries more information than just cash flow. It shows where the brand is positioned against its main competitors, and indicates where it might be likely to go in the future. It can also show what type of marketing activities might be expected to be effective. {{Citation needed|date=February 2009}} ===Market growth rate=== Rapidly growing in rapidly growing markets, are what organizations strive for; but, as we have seen, the penalty is that they are usually net cash users – they require investment. The reason for this is often because the growth is being 'bought' by the high investment, in the reasonable expectation that a high market share will eventually turn into a sound investment in future profits. The theory behind the matrix assumes, therefore, that a higher growth rate is indicative of accompanying demands on investment. The cut-off point is usually chosen as 10 per cent per annum.Fripp, Geoff.[http://www.business-portfolio-analysis.com/free-excel-template-download-of-the-bcg-matrix/how-to-guide/the-bcg-matrix-where-to-draw-the-line/ "BCG Matrix: Where to Draw the Line?"] Guide to the BCG Matrix Determining this cut-off point, the rate above which the growth is deemed to be significant (and likely to lead to extra demands on cash) is a critical requirement of the technique; and one that, again, makes the use of the growth–share matrix problematical in some product areas. What is more, the evidence, from [[fast-moving consumer goods]] markets at least, is that the most typical pattern is of very low growth, less than 1 per cent per annum. This is outside the range normally considered in BCG Matrix work, which may make application of this form of analysis unworkable in many markets. {{Citation needed|date=February 2009}} Where it can be applied, however, the market growth rate says more about the brand position than just its cash flow. It is a good indicator of that market's strength, of its future potential (of its 'maturity' in terms of the market life-cycle), and also of its attractiveness to future competitors. It can also be used in growth analysis. ===Critical evaluation=== While theoretically useful, and widely used, several academic studies have called into question whether using the growth–share matrix actually helps businesses succeed, and the model has since been removed from some major marketing textbooks.Competitor-oriented Objectives: The Myth of Market Share http://cogprints.org/5196/1/myth_of_market_share.pdf See discussion on page 14.{{cite journal | url = http://marketing.wharton.upenn.edu/documents/research/Effects%20of%20portfolio%20planning%20methods-empirical%20results.pdf | title = Effects of portfolio planning methods on decision making: experimental results | author = J. Scott Armstrong and Roderick J. Brodie | journal = International Journal of Research in Marketing | volume = 11 | issue = 1 | pages = 73–84 | year = 1994 | publisher = Science Direct | doi = 10.1016/0167-8116(94)90035-3 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100620225128/http://marketing.wharton.upenn.edu/documents/research/Effects%20of%20portfolio%20planning%20methods-empirical%20results.pdf | archivedate = 2010-06-20 | df = }} One study ([http://jom.sagepub.com/content/18/4/717.abstract Slater and Zwirlein, 1992]) which looked at 129 firms found that those who follow portfolio planning models like the BCG matrix had lower shareholder returns. There are further criticisms to the B.C.G Matrix. The Matrix assumes that dogs have low market share and relatively low market growth rate.{{Cite journal|last=Duica|first=Andrea|date=July 2014`|title=The rise and fall of B.C.G. Matrix|url=http://conferinta.management.ase.ro/archives/2014/pdf/13.pdf|journal=PROCEEDINGS OF THE 8th INTERNATIONAL MANAGEMENT CONFERENCE|volume=1|pages=3}} This can be challenged as there are several dogs on the market which are very profitable and retain significant market share. BIC razor blades are a modern day example. BIC Razor Blades cost the firm an average of £0.05 to produce and have a retail selling price of £2.43.{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1191456/Sharp-practice-The-razor-heads-cost-just-5p-make-sell-2-43-each.html|title=The razor heads that cost just 5p to make, but sell for £2.43 each|work=Mail Online|access-date=2017-05-12}} This market is to expand by 25% annually for the next 5 years.{{Cite web|url=http://fortune.com/2015/10/23/gillette-shaving-club-wars/|title=Gillette is clawing back market share from the shaving clubs|website=Fortune|access-date=2017-05-12}} This demonstrates how the B.C.G Matrix contradicts itself as a dog with little cash usage has considerably high market share within the market. ===Misuse=== As originally practiced by the [[Boston Consulting Group]],[http://futureobservatory.dyndns.org/9435.htm the Rule of 123] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061003100819/http://futureobservatory.dyndns.org/9435.htm |date=2006-10-03 }} the matrix was used in situations where it could be applied for graphically illustrating a portfolio composition as a function of the balance between cash flows.{{cite web|last=Henderson|first=Bruce D.|title=The Product Portfolio|url=https://www.bcgperspectives.com/content/classics/strategy_the_product_portfolio/|accessdate=16 May 2013}} If used with this degree of sophistication its use would still be valid. However, later practitioners have tended to over-simplify its messages.{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} In particular, the later application of the names (problem children, stars, cash cows and dogs) has tended to overshadow all else—and is often what most students, and practitioners, remember. This is unfortunate,{{according to whom|date=August 2013}} since such simplistic use contains at least two major problems: *'Minority applicability'. The cashflow techniques are only applicable to a very limited number of markets (where growth is relatively high, and a definite pattern of product life-cycles can be observed, such as that of ethical pharmaceuticals). In the majority of markets, use may give misleading results. *'Milking cash cows'. Perhaps the worst implication of the later developments is that the (brand leader) cash cows should be milked to fund new brands. This is not what research into the [[fast-moving consumer goods]] markets has shown to be the case. The brand leader's position is the one, above all, to be defended, not least since brands in this position will probably outperform any number of newly launched brands. Such brand leaders will, of course, generate large cash flows; but they should not be 'milked' to such an extent that their position is jeopardized. In any case, the chance of the new brands achieving similar brand leadership may be slim—certainly far less than the popular perception of the Boston Matrix would imply. Perhaps the most important danger is, however, that the apparent implication of its four-quadrant form is that there should be balance of products or services across all four quadrants; and that is, indeed, the main message that it is intended to convey. Thus, money must be diverted from 'cash cows' to fund the 'stars' of the future, since 'cash cows' will inevitably decline to become 'dogs'. There is an almost mesmeric inevitability about the whole process. It focuses attention, and funding, on to the 'stars'. It presumes, and almost demands, that 'cash cows' will turn into 'dogs'. The reality is that it is only the 'cash cows' that are really important—all the other elements are supporting actors. It is a foolish vendor who diverts funds from a 'cash cow' when these are needed to extend the life of that 'product'. Although it is necessary to recognize a 'dog' when it appears (at least before it bites you) it would be foolish in the extreme to create one in order to balance up the picture. The vendor, who has most of his (or her) products in the 'cash cow' quadrant, should consider himself (or herself) fortunate indeed, and an excellent marketer, although he or she might also consider creating a few stars as an insurance policy against unexpected future developments and, perhaps, to add some extra growth. There is also a common misconception that 'dogs' are a waste of resources. In many markets 'dogs' can be considered loss-leaders that while not themselves profitable will lead to increased sales in other profitable areas. ===Alternatives=== As with most marketing techniques, there are a number of alternative offerings vying with the growth–share matrix although this appears to be the most widely used. The next most widely reported technique is that developed by McKinsey and General Electric, which is a three-cell by three-cell matrix—using the dimensions of 'industry attractiveness' and 'business strengths'. This approaches some of the same issues as the growth–share matrix but from a different direction and in a more complex way (which may be why it is used less, or is at least less widely taught). A more practical approach is that of the [[Boston Consulting Group's Advantage Matrix]], which the consultancy reportedly used itself though it is little known amongst the wider population. ==Other uses== The initial intent of the growth–share matrix was to evaluate business units, but the same evaluation can be made for [[product line]]s or any other cash-generating entities. This should only be attempted for real lines that have a sufficient history to allow some prediction; if the corporation has made only a few products and called them a product line, the [[sample variance]] will be too high for this sort of analysis to be meaningful. ==References== {{Strategic planning tools}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Growth-share matrix}} [[Category:Boston Consulting Group]] [[Category:Brand management]] [[Category:Product management]] [[Category:Portfolio theories]] [[Category:Strategic management]] [[Category:Marketing techniques]]

revision.text:
{{infobox company |image = |name = Interogo Foundation |founded = 1989 |area_served = Worldwide |founder = [[Ingvar Kamprad]] |hq_location = [[Liechtenstein]] |brands = |parent = |subsid = [[Inter IKEA Holding S.A.]]
[[Interogo Holding A.G.]] (non-[[IKEA]] related) |website = {{url|https://www.interogoholding.com/governance/interogo-foundation}} |type = [[Private foundation|Foundation]] }} {{Template:IKEA ownership chart}} '''Interogo Foundation''' is a [[Foundation (nonprofit organization)|foundation]] registered in Liechtenstein. It owns [[Inter IKEA Holding S.A.]] registered in Luxembourg, which owns [[Inter IKEA Systems B.V.]], registered in the Netherlands, and thereby controls the [[intellectual property]] of the [[IKEA]] brand. [[Ingvar Kamprad]], the founder of IKEA, and his family control the Interogo Foundation.{{Cite news|url=http://www.svt.se/ug/ingvar-kamprad-bekraftar-stiftelsen-i-mejl-till-tt |title=Ingvar Kamprad bekräftar stiftelsen i mejl till TT |publisher=Svt.se |date= 2011-01-26|accessdate=2011-01-28|language=swedish}} Royalties of 3% on all IKEA products has resulted in the foundation controlling assets valued at US $15 billion.{{Cite news|url=http://www.svt.se/ug/ingvar-kamprad-gommer-ikea-miljarder-i-skatteparadis |title=Kamprad gömmer Ikea-miljarderna i skatteparadis |publisher=Svt.se |date= 2011-01-26|accessdate=2011-01-28|language=swedish}} ==History == The foundation was founded on the 29 March 1989 in Vaduz, Liechtenstein. The aim of the foundation is to secure the continued existence of Inter IKEA Holding S.A. and to influence the leadership of the company.{{Cite web|url=http://svt.se/content/1/c8/02/30/50/85/Stadgar_Interogo.pdf |title=Gruendungsurkunde |publisher=Interogo Foundations |date= 1989-03-29|accessdate=2011-01-28|language=german|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121009000003/http://www.svt.se/content/1/c8/02/30/50/85/Stadgar_Interogo.pdf|archive-date=October 9, 2012}} ==Governance== The foundation board has at least two members, who were originally lawyers Herbert Oberhuber and Johannes Burger. The foundation may be changed into a company or a trust if circumstances have changed so that this is in the foundation's interests. Meetings of the board are announced by the president of the foundation. === Appo Trust === The members of Interogo Foundation can be appointed or replaced by the Appo Trust based in [[Ontario]], [[Canada]], or by an equal trust created by the Interogo Foundation. Appo Trust is currently controlled by the [[Kamprad]] family. {{Cite news|url=http://www.smp.se/inblick/two-people-in-total-control/|title=Two people in total control - Smålandsposten|last=Vikingson|first=Bosse|work=Smålandsposten|access-date=2018-11-18|language=sv-SE}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.va.se/nyheter/2011/01/27/kamprads-20-miljardersklipp/|title=Kamprads 20-miljardersklipp|work=Veckans affärer|access-date=2018-11-18}} ==See also== * [[IKEA]] * [[Stichting INGKA Foundation]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20121009000003/http://www.svt.se/content/1/c8/02/30/50/85/Stadgar_Interogo.pdf Founding document of the foundation.] * [http://www.svt.se/ug/granskningen-av-ikea-ett-brett-samarbetsprojekt Information from the Nation Swedish Broadcasting Company, SVT.] {{sv}} {{IKEA ownership}} {{business-org-stub}} [[Category:Companies of Liechtenstein]] [[Category:1989 establishments in Liechtenstein]] [[Category:IKEA]]

revision.text:
'''Jim Perdue''' has been the Chairman and advertising spokesman of [[Perdue Farms]] since 1991.<ref>[http://www.perdue.com/Corporate/Our_Story/ Purdue Farms: Our Story]</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.delmarvanow.com/story/news/local/maryland/2017/03/08/perdue-randy-day-ceo/98923958/|title=Perdue Farms announces new CEO|work=Delmarva Daily Times|access-date=2017-03-09|language=en}}</ref> He is a third generation leader of the company founded by his grandfather in 1920.
Like his father, [[Frank Perdue|Frank]], Jim Perdue grew up in the family business, but didn't decide to make it his business right away. He wanted to pursue his dream of becoming a [[marine biologist]], and went on to earn his Ph.D. in [[fisheries]]. But in 1983, he accepted his dad's invitation to return to the family business, joining the company as an entry-level management trainee. After working many different management jobs in just about every area of the company, and earning his master's degree in business along the way, Jim became chairman in 1991 and also took over as advertising spokesperson, appearing in humorous TV commercials. He enjoys vacationing in [[Bethany Beach, DE]]. Jim started doing commercials with his dad in 1995. As of September 3, 2017, Jim can be seen doing commercials with his sons, Chris and Ryan Perdue, fourth generation in the family business.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.meatpoultry.com/articles/news_home/Business/2017/09/Fourth_generation_of_Perdues_s.aspx?ID=%7B0707B2EA-5B32-4ADE-AA3E-87862151BB40%7D&p=1&cck=1|title=Fourth generation of Perdues star in company’s commercials {{!}} MEAT+POULTRY|website=www.meatpoultry.com|access-date=2017-09-08}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Perdue, Jim}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Advertising people]] [[Category:American food industry business executives]] [[Category:American chairmen of corporations]]
