revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Patrick Cudahy |image=Patrick Cudahy (1902).jpg | birth_name = Patrick Cudahy Jr. | birth_date = {{birth date|1849|3|17}} | birth_place = [[Callan, County Kilkenny]], [[Ireland]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1919|9|25|1849|3|17}} | relatives = [[Michael Cudahy (industrialist)|Michael Cudahy]] (brother)
[[Michael Cudahy (electronics)|Michael Cudahy]] (grandson)
[[Robert J. Beck]] (great-great-grandson)
Edward Cudahy Sr. (brother)
[[Edward Cudahy Jr.]] (nephew)
Catarine Sullivan Cudahy (sister-in-law) | spouse = Anna Cudahy | children = [[John Cudahy]]
Michael Cudahy | occupation = industrialist | parents = Patrick Cudahy Sr. }} [[Image:Patrick Cudahy.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Statue in Sheridan Park]] '''Patrick Cudahy Jr.''' (kŭd ŭ hay); March 17, 1849 – July 25, 1919) was an [[United States|American]] [[industrialist]] in the meat packing business and a [[patriarch]] of the Cudahy family. ==Background== Cudahy was born on [[St. Patrick's Day]] in [[Callan, County Kilkenny]], [[Ireland]].[http://www.wisconsinhistory.org/dictionary/index.asp?action=view&term_id=1213& Cudahy, Patrick 1849 - 1919] - Dictionary of Wisconsin History - Wisconsin Historical Society[http://www.livestockexpo.org/ssclub/ssbook_pdfs/abc.pdf ''"Saddle and Sirloin Portrait Catalogue"''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080703183359/http://www.livestockexpo.org/ssclub/ssbook_pdfs/abc.pdf |date=2008-07-03 }} - North American International Livestock Exposition - (Adobe Acrobat *.PDF document)Sherman, Jeff. [http://staff.onmilwaukee.com/buzz/articles/cudahy.html ''"Milwaukee Talks: Michael Cudahy"''] - OnMilwaukee.com - August 28, 2002 A few months after he was born, his family moved to [[Milwaukee, Wisconsin]]. He worked his way up at the Plankinton and Armour [[Meat packing industry|meat packing]] plant in the [[Menomonee River Valley, Milwaukee|Menomonee River Valley]], becoming the superintendent in 1874. In 1888, the owner, [[John Plankinton]], transferred the company to Patrick and his brother, John. The company became known as Cudahy Brothers.[https://www.wisconsinhistory.org/Records/Image/IM87686 Cudahy Brothers Co. Letterhead]. Wisconsin Historical Society."[http://content.wisconsinhistory.org/cdm/ref/collection/wmh/id/48517 Caught in the Middle: The Seizure and Occupation of the Cudahy Brothers Company, 1944-1945]". ''Wisconsin Magazine of History'', vol. 78, no. 3 (Spring, 1995): 200-218.[https://emke.uwm.edu/entry/cudahy-brothers/ Cudahy Brothers]. ''Encyclopedia of Milwaukee''. The company changed its name to Patrick Cudahy, Inc. in 1957, long after Cudahy's death.{{cn|date=May 2018}} In 1892, Cudahy moved the company to a 700-acre (2.8 km²) plot of land south of [[Milwaukee]] which he and his brother John bought for the purpose. This land was in the former [[Lake, Milwaukee County, Wisconsin|Town of Lake]], which is now divided between the municipalities of Milwaukee, St. Francis, and Cudahy. Cudahy "had a bittersweet relationship with the village of Cudahy" in part because he supported [[temperance movement|temperance]] and "fought against liquor". He "argued with the Cudahy Common Council about the spread of taverns in the village", although he also worked to assist business development and the construction of a new library. He said, "It is a source of satisfaction to me to look over those 25 years and see what has been accomplished, but I would feel much better if there were not the antagonistic spirit in Cudahy which seems to prevail to a great extent among its citizens."[http://www.ansci.wisc.edu/Meat_HOF/1993/cudahy.htm Patrick Cudahy and Michael F. Cudahy] WISCONSIN MEAT INDUSTRY HALL OF FAME University of Wisconsin-Madison Patrick Cudahy is buried at [[Calvary Cemetery, Milwaukee, Wisconsin|Calvary Cemetery]] in Milwaukee. == Family == Patrick Cudahy's family includes: [[Patrick Cudahy Sr.]], father * [[Michael Cudahy (meat packing)|Michael Cudahy]] (1841-1910), brother (president of Armour-Cudahy company, co-founder of [[Cudahy Packing Company]] (Omaha), and the city of [[Cudahy, California]] * John Cudahy (1843-1915), brother (silent partner of Patrick Jr. in the meat packing plants, Milwaukee and Chicago; Louisville) * '''Patrick Cudahy Jr. (1849-1919), self''' ** Michael Francis Cudahy (1886-), son (President of Patrick Cudahy, Inc. from 1919 onwards) *** [[Richard Dickson Cudahy]] (1926-2015), grandson (jurist) ***** [[Robert J. Beck]] (1961- ), great-great grandson (educator and international law scholar) ** [[John Cudahy|John Clarence Cudahy]] (1887-1943), son (lawyer, real estate broker, and U.S. ambassador to [[Poland]], [[Ireland]] and [[Belgium]]) *** [[Michael Cudahy (electronics)|Michael Cudahy]] (1924- ), grandson (Founder of [[Marquette Electronics]] and philanthropist) ** Helen Cudahy (1890/1-1917), daughter, committed suicide by leaping from a ship into the ocean"[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1955&dat=19171027&id=iJktAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Bp4FAAAAIBAJ&pg=4198,3483144&hl=en American Girl, Fearing U-boats, Kills Herself]", ''Reading Eagle'', October 27, 1917, p. 1. Retrieved July 26, 2015. * [[Edward Cudahy Sr.|Edward Aloysius Cudahy Sr.]] (1860-1941), brother, co-founder Cudahy Packing Company (Omaha) ** [[Edward Cudahy Jr.|Edward Aloysius Cudahy Jr.]] (1884-1961), nephew ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== *Cudahy, Patrick. [https://archive.org/stream/patrickcudahyhis01cuda#page/n7/mode/2up Patrick Cudahy: his Life], Milwaukee: Burdick & Allen, 1912. ==External links== *[http://www.patrickcudahy.com/company-founder.html Biography of Patrick Cudahy at Patrick Cudahy, Inc.] *{{findagrave|9696166}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cudahy, Patrick}} [[Category:1849 births]] [[Category:1919 deaths]] [[Category:American people of Irish descent]] [[Category:People from County Kilkenny]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Milwaukee]] [[Category:Cudahy family]] [[Category:Irish emigrants to the United States (before 1923)]]

revision.comment: removed [[Category:People from Lebanon County, Pennsylvania]]; added [[Category:People from Cornwall, Pennsylvania]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox person |name = Peter Grubb Jr. |image = |alt = |caption = |birth_date = September 8, 1740 |birth_place = Pennsylvania |death_date = January 17, 1786 |death_place = Cornwall, Pennsylvania |parents = [[Peter Grubb (mason)|Peter Grubb]], Martha Bates |nationality = |other_names = |known_for = Co-owner of [[Cornwall, Pennsylvania|Cornwall Ironworks]] and operator of [[Hopewell (on Hammer Creek)|Hopewell Forges]] |occupation = Businessman & [[Ironmaster]] |religion = |spouse = Mary Shippen Burd (married 1771 - died 1774) |partner = Susan Brandelbury (c. 1768) Hannah Bellarby Grubb (1774) |children = three sons, one daughter |relatives = [[Curtis Grubb]] (brother), [[Nathaniel Grubb]] (uncle) |title = Colonel, 8th Lancaster Battalion }}
'''Peter Grubb Jr.''' (1740–1786), [[Patriot (American Revolution)|Patriot]] and second son of [[Peter Grubb (mason)|Peter and Martha Bates Grubb]], was a second-generation member of the [[Grubb Family Iron Dynasty]] along with his older brother [[Curtis Grubb]]. They operated the [[Cornwall, Pennsylvania|Cornwall Ironworks]], making significant contributions to the [[American Revolutionary War]] effort.
The brothers inherited the ironworks from their father in 1754, with Peter, as the youngest, receiving only a one-third interest. They took over operation of the ironworks about 1765 and expanded it successfully. Peter, who had more ironmaking experience, took over the nearby [[Hopewell (on Hammer Creek)|Hopewell Forges]], making [[bar iron]] from [[pig iron]] produced by Curtis at [[Cornwall Furnace]]. They operated the business through and after the Revolution, becoming quite prosperous until they died, Peter in 1786 and Curtis in 1789.<ref name = dibert>{{cite book | last = Dibert | first = James | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Iron, Independence and Inheritance | publisher = [[Cornwall Iron Furnace]] | year = 2000 | location = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = | page = }}</ref><ref name = dgrubb>{{cite book | last = Grubb | first = David | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = The Grubb Family of Grubb's Landing, Delaware | publisher = Higginson Book Co. | year = 2008 | location = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = | page = }}</ref>
Most of the Cornwall Ironworks fell out of family hands during the period 1783 - 1802, to [[Robert Coleman (industrialist)|Robert Coleman]] who became Pennsylvania's first millionaire. But a portion remained with Peter Jr.'s heirs, who added to it to become major Pennsylvania producers of iron in the mid-19th century, operating out of [[Mount Hope Estate]].
== Patriotism ==
The Grubb brothers were major contributors to the Revolutionary War effort, their Cornwall Ironworks supplied cannon, ammunition, shot and saltpans (used to make salt from seawater) to the Colonial forces. [[George Washington]] personally visited Cornwall to inspect the facility. Both brothers were elected as militia [[colonel]]s, Peter's unit was the 8th Lancaster Battalion and Curtis' was the 2nd Lancaster Battalion, both assigned to the [[Flying Camp]].
== Business career ==
Peter and his brother took over the operation of the ironworks about 1765, with Peter operating the Hopewell Forges and Curtis the Cornwall Furnace. They were successful operators of the ironworks through the Revolution. They were, however, complex individuals whose affairs were closely intertwined and became increasingly acrimonious. Their ongoing feuds and legal entanglements led to the fragmentation of the ironwork's ownership and its eventual loss by the Grubb family into the hands of [[Robert Coleman (industrialist)|Robert Coleman]], who used it to build his fortune.
Tensions between the brothers reached the crisis point in 1783 when Curtis decided to marry his 20-year-old cousin Ann Grubb, granddaughter of the brothers' uncle [[Nathaniel Grubb]]. Inheritance concerns by Curtis' oldest son, Peter III (actually called Peter Jr. to distinguish him from Curtis' brother Peter), resulted in him being given a portion of Curtis' holdings, which then required a legal division of the assets that had previously been shared informally. Included in Peter III's newly acquired assets were a one-third interest in the Hopewell Forges. Peter, who had been running the forges, became fearful and reacted by purchasing land at Mount Hope to build his own furnace in competition with his brother, going heavily into debt. The feud intensified and Peter III became concerned for the business and sold his interest to Robert Coleman, a friend who had worked for the brothers and was by then also an ironmaster. Curtis, concerned with the competition, allied himself with Coleman and tried various tactics to put Peter out of business. Succumbing to the pressure, Peter became distraught and committed suicide in 1786, at the age of only 45. The ironworks were apportioned by the courts among Curtis, Peter's estate, and Coleman.
Robert Coleman additionally acquired the Mount Hope furnace from Peter's estate. After Curtis' death in 1789 he operated the ironworks for the heirs until 1798, when they sold their interests to him. Thus Robert Coleman became the owner of most of the former Grubb holdings, which he added to his own and expanded to become Pennsylvania's first millionaire.
The holdings remaining in Peter's estate were eventually expanded upon by his second son [[Henry Bates Grubb]], whose family went on to become one of Pennsylvania's largest iron producers in the mid-19th century, with their center of operations at [[Mount Hope Estate]].
== Personal life ==
Before the brothers took over the ironworks in 1765, Peter had moved to the mansion built by his father and was learning the iron making business. He continued to reside in the mansion and took over operation of the Hopewell Forges. The [[Hopewell (on Hammer Creek)|Hopewell Forge Mansion]] still stands, denoted by a historic marker, on modern-day Route 322.
Peter married Mary Shippen Burd, of Lancaster, in 1771, at the Burd family estate known as "Tinian." They had two sons, Alan Burd Grubb and [[Henry Bates Grubb]], but unfortunately Mary died from complications of childbirth. Peter never got over the loss, became despondent, and never married again. He was the less gregarious of the brothers, and being a minority partner in the ironworks probably didn't help his disposition. He developed an increasing drinking problem and was known for sometimes erratic behavior. On two occasions he was brought before Council to answer for statements he made while drinking; he was acquitted both times, as he had just "behaved in his usual mad way." Certainly Peter's drinking problem contributed to his suicide in 1786; he took his own life at the Hopewell Forges and was buried there by his brother-in-law [[Jasper Yeates]].<ref name = pistol>{{cite book| title = The History of a Flintlock Pistol | author = Samuel E. Dyke | year = 1955 | location = Lancaster Historical Society}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Peter Grubb Jr. Grave Memorial | url = https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/52188974 | doi = | id = | isbn = | page = }}</ref>
Although Peter never married again, he did have a relationship with Hannah Bellarby Grubb, the adopted daughter of his uncle Samuel Grubb. Hannah came into Peter's household after Mary's death to help with the two infants. Peter and Hannah had a daughter, Hannah Elizabeth Grubb, late that same year. Peter acknowledged his daughter, later remembering her in his will, but did not marry Hannah. Hannah is believed to have then moved with her daughter to Curtis Grubb's household to help care for his two young children, whose mother had also died, probably in childbirth. Hannah later bore Curtis a son, [[Jehu Grubb]]. Peter also had a relationship with a Susan Brandelbury before he was married; a son was produced, Samuel Brandelbury, who was also remembered in Peter's will.
== Sons in the family iron business ==
With their remaining share of Peter's estate as a foundation, this family become one of the largest iron producers in Pennsylvania during the mid-19th century.
=== Son of Peter Grubb Jr. ===
*[[Henry Bates Grubb]] (1774–1823) was the family's first "real" ironmaster; he bought out his brother, Alan Burd Grubb, and built the original mansion at [[Mount Hope Estate]].
=== Sons of Henry Bates Grubb ===
*[[Edward Burd Grubb Sr.]] (1810–1867) was a family ironmaster, an ardent [[Abolitionism in the United States|abolitionist]], and a leading citizen in [[Burlington, New Jersey]]. *[[Clement Brooke Grubb]] (1815–1889) was a family ironmaster and banker, the first manager of Mount Hope Estate, and the owner of several iron production operations. *Alfred Bates Grubb (1821–1885) was involved in the family iron business, bought 50% of Mount Hope Estate from Clement for $25,000, managing it until his death. His estate sold it back to Clement for $300,000.
== Other descendants of interest ==
=== Descended from Henry Bates Grubb ===
*[[Edward Burd Grubb Jr.]] (1841–1913) was a Civil War General, a candidate for Governor, and later Ambassador to Spain. After the war he joined the family iron business as President of the Lebanon Valley Furnace Company. *Daisy Elizabeth Brooke Grubb (1850–1936) was the youngest daughter of Clement Brooke Grubb, who inherited the [[Mount Hope Estate]] and was its last family resident. She transformed the 12 room Federal style mansion into a 32-room Victorian mansion that is listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]]. *Edward Burd Grubb III (1893–1973) was President of the [[New York Curb Exchange]] during the critical period after the creation of the SEC.
=== Descended from Hannah Elizabeth Grubb ===
*[[Samuel P. Heintzelman]] (1805–1880) was a Civil War General who commanded the 3rd Corps during the [[Peninsula Campaign]]. *[[Stuart Heintzelman]] (1876–1935) was a career Army officer who was promoted to Major General in 1931.
== References and external links ==
{{Reflist}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Grubb, Peter Jr.}} [[Category:1740 births]] [[Category:1786 deaths]] [[Category:People from Cornwall, Pennsylvania]] [[Category:American people of Cornish descent]] [[Category:People of colonial Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Patriots in the American Revolution]] [[Category:Grubb family]] [[Category:Businesspeople who committed suicide]]

revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{no footnotes|date=June 2013}} {{Lead rewrite|date=October 2010}}f pi9ugpi9ug }}
'''Plant lifecycle management''' ('''PLM''') is the process of managing an industrial facility's data and information throughout its lifetime. Plant lifecycle management differs from [[product lifecycle management]] by its primary focus on the integration of '''logical''', '''physical''' and '''technical''' plant data in a combined plant model.
A PLM model can be used through a plants whole lifecycle, covering: *Design, *Construction, *Erection, *Commissioning, *Handover, *Operation, *Maintenance/Refurbishment/Life Extension, *Decommissioning, *[[Land rehabilitation]].
== Parts of the model ==
=== Logical model === The logical plant model may cover: *[[Process and instrumentation diagram|Process & instrumentation diagrams]] (P&ID) *[[Piping and instrumentation diagram|Pipe & instrumentation diagrams]] (P&ID) *[[P&ID|P&I schematic]] *[[Process flow diagram|Process flow]] *Massflow diagram (similar to the process flow but used in the mineral industry) *Electrical key diagram *Cabling diagram *Electrical *[[Hydraulics|Hydraulic]] *[[Pneumatic]] *Heating venting & air-conditioning ([[HVAC]]) *Water and wastewater
=== Physical model === Physical parts of a plant are usually represented by 3D CAD models. The [[Computer-aided design|CAD]] system used would typically focus on top-down, routing, and [[Digital mockup|DMU]] and would differ on many point from the systems used in the mechanical industry, or for [[Architectural engineering]]. Sometimes the [[Computer-aided design|CAD]] system would be supplemented by software to generate 3D views or walk-through features.
=== Technical model === The technical data is typically managed by an [[enterprise resource planning|ERP]] system or some other [[database]]. There could also be links to systems for handling unstructured data, like [[Electronic document management|EDM]] systems.
=== Integration === *Integration with Enterprise (EPCM, ePCM), *Integration with Enterprise (Owner/Operator), *Integration with Regulator.
=== Applicability === *New Build *Return to Service (RTS)
== See also == * [[Lifecycle management (disambiguation)|Lifecycle management]] * [[ISO 10303]] - Industrial automation systems and integration—Product data representation and exchange * [[ISO 15926]] - Process Plants including Oil and Gas facilities life-cycle data
==Notes== {{reflist}}
== Further reading == *[http://www.tappsa.co.za/archive2/APPW_2004/Title2004/Efficient_management/efficient_management.html about Virtual Mill] *[http://virtual.vtt.fi/multimedia/publications/arplantlifecycle-ice2007.pdf about Augmented reality]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Plant Lifecycle Management}} [[Category:Product lifecycle management]] [[Category:Computer-aided design]] [[Category:Management by type]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2016}} {{Infobox Public transit | name = Metro Purple Line | box_width = 320px | image = LACMTA Circle Purple Line.svg | imagesize = 20px | image2 = Union Station Metro Red & Purple Lines Station 2.JPG | imagesize2 = 300px | alt2 = Metro Purple Line at Union Station. | caption2 = Metro Purple Line at [[Union Station (Los Angeles)|Union Station]]. | owner = [[Metro Rail (Los Angeles County)|Metro Rail]] | locale = | transit_type = [[Heavy rail]] | line_number = 805 | stations = 8 | ridership = 149,096 (July 2016; avg. weekday, combined with [[Red Line (Los Angeles Metro)|Metro Red Line]]) | website = {{url|www.metro.net/around/rail/purple-line/|Purple Line}} | began_operation = {{Start date and age|January 30, 1993}} (as a branch of the Red Line, renamed in 2006) | operator = {{LACMTA link logo|showtext=yes}} | character = Subway (fully underground) | depot = Division 20 (Santa Fe Ave) | vehicles = [[Breda A650]] | train_length = 4 cars (2 cars during off-peak hours) | headway = | system_length = {{convert|6.4|mi|km|1|abbr=on}}{{cite web |url=https://partners.skanska.com/usa/projects/098010/Q/C0980%20Conformed%20Contract%20Documents/7._All_Other_Project_Definition_Docs/Technical_Reports/Operations_and_Maintenance_Plan_FINAL_Rev_G_091013.pdf |title=Regional Connector Transit Corridor Project Contract No. E0119 – Operations and Maintenance Plan (Final) |publisher=Los Angeles County Metropolitan Transit Authority |format=PDF |department=2.1 Metro Light Rail Overview |page=2-1 |date=September 10, 2013 |access-date=2017-05-19 |quote=The Purple Line operates 6.4 miles between Union Station in downtown Los Angeles and Wilshire/Western Station in Koreatown...}}{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1997/oct/22/news/mn-45417/2|title=Beleaguered MTA on Verge of Tunnel Triumph|first1=Richard|last1=Simon|first2=Jeffrey L.|last2=Rabin|date=October 22, 1997|accessdate=2014-02-27|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]}} | notrack = 2 | track_gauge = {{Track gauge|ussg}}
([[standard gauge]]) | el = 750 [[volt|V]] [[direct current|DC]] [[third rail]] | average_speed = | top_speed = | map = {{Metro Purple Line}} | map_state = show }} The '''Purple Line''' is a [[heavy rail]] [[Rapid transit|subway line]] operating in [[Los Angeles]], running between [[Downtown Los Angeles|downtown]] and the [[Mid-Wilshire]]/[[Koreatown, Los Angeles, California|Koreatown]] districts. It is one of six lines on the [[Los Angeles County Metro Rail|Metro Rail System]], operated by the [[Los Angeles County Metropolitan Transportation Authority]]. The Metro Purple Line is one of the city's two [[Rapid transit|subway]] lines (along with the [[Red Line (Los Angeles Metro)|Metro Red Line]]). Although they separate west of Downtown Los Angeles, the two subway lines (Purple and Red) were originally branded as two branches of the Red Line. The Purple Line was instituted as its own line, separate from the Red Line, in 2006. {{As of|2013|October}}, the combined Red and Purple lines averaged 169,478 boardings per weekday.{{cite web |url=https://www.metro.net/news/pages/ridership-statistics/ |title=Ridership Statistics - Rail Ridership Estimates |publisher=Los Angeles County Metropolitan Transit Authority |date=August 20, 2013 |accessdate=2013-08-25}} Out of the eight stations served, only two of them are exclusive to the Purple Line, with the other six shared with the Red Line. ==Service description== ===Route=== [[File:Interior of Metro Purple Line Train.JPG|thumb|Inside train fleet number #530 on the Metro Purple Line|left]] The Metro Purple Line is a {{convert|6.4|mi|km|adj=on}} line that begins at Union Station. At Union Station, passengers can connect to the [[Silver Line (Los Angeles Metro)|Metro Silver Line]] bus rapid transit line, and the [[Gold Line (Los Angeles Metro)|Metro Gold Line]]. The Purple Line travels southwest through [[Downtown Los Angeles]], passing the Civic Center, Pershing Square (near the Historic Core) and the Financial District. Passengers can connect to the Metro Silver Line (both directions) at Civic Center Station. At Pershing Square Station, passengers can board the northbound Metro Silver Line bus at Olive Street/5th Street. At {{LA Metro station|7th St/Metro Center}} Station, travelers can connect to the [[Blue Line (Los Angeles Metro)|Metro Blue Line]], [[Expo Line (Los Angeles Metro)|Metro Expo Line]] and the [[Silver Line (Los Angeles Metro)|Metro Silver Line]]. From here, the train travels between 7th Street and Wilshire Boulevard (and briefly Ingraham Street) west through Pico-Union and Westlake, arriving at {{LA Metro station|Wilshire/Vermont}} in the city's [[Mid-Wilshire]]/[[Koreatown, Los Angeles|Koreatown]] district. Up to this point, track is shared with the [[Red Line (Los Angeles Metro)|Metro Red Line]]: at Wilshire/Vermont, the two lines diverge. The Purple Line continues west for one additional mile, and terminates at {{LA Metro station|Wilshire/Western}}. ====Duplicate service on Wilshire==== The Purple Line runs underground, below [[Wilshire Boulevard]] which is served on the surface by Metro Local route 20 and [[Metro Rapid]] route 720. Despite the duplicate service, Metro considers the redundant bus service justified because both bus routes run frequently from Downtown Los Angeles. Unlike the Purple Line, they run along the ''entire'' Wilshire corridor, west to [[Beverly Hills, California|Beverly Hills]], [[Westwood, Los Angeles|Westwood]] and [[Santa Monica]]. ===Hours of operation=== Trains run between approximately 4:45 a.m. and 11:30 p.m. daily, with late night weekend service running until approximately 2:00 a.m.{{cite web |url=http://media.metro.net/riding_metro/bus_overview/images/802.pdf |title=Red & Purple lines timetable |publisher=Los Angeles County Metropolitan Transit Authority |date=June 23, 2013 |accessdate=2013-11-17}} First and last train times are as follows: '''To/From Wilshire/Western'''
:''Eastbound'' :*First Train to Union Station: 4:41 a.m. :*Last Train to Union Station: 11:42 p.m. (2:01 a.m. Friday and Saturday nights) :''Westbound'' :*First Train to Wilshire/Western: 4:56 a.m. :*Last Train to Wilshire/Western: 11:27 p.m. (2:12 a.m. Friday and Saturday nights) During the evenings Purple Line trains sometimes run as shuttles. Passengers must transfer to a Red Line train at Wilshire/Vermont. This will change once the Purple Line is extended to Westwood. ===Headways=== Trains on the Purple Line operate every ten minutes during peak hours Monday through Friday.{{cite web|url=http://media.metro.net/riding_metro/maps/images/system_map.pdf |title=Metro Bus & Rail System Map |publisher=Los Angeles County Metropolitan Transit Authority |date=December 2013 |accessdate=2014-01-15}} They operate every twelve minutes during the daytime weekdays and all day on the weekends after approximately 10 a.m. (with a 15-minute headway early Saturday and Sunday mornings). Night service can range between 20–30 minutes. ===Ridership=== The Purple Line is utilized mostly as a downtown shuttle on its shared segment with the Red Line. The stub between Vermont and Western has a very low ridership. According to Metro Service Coordinator Conan Cheung, the stub is operating 11% full during peak hours, and even lower at other times.{{cite web |first=Dana|last=Gabbard |url=http://la.streetsblog.org/2010/11/23/metros-conan-cheung-updates-on-next-18-months-of-service-planning/ |title=Metro’s Conan Cheung Updates on Next 18 Months of Service Planning |work=Streetsblog LA |date=November 23, 2010 |accessdate=2016-02-01}} ==History== {{Main|History of Los Angeles Metro Rail and Busway}} The current Purple Line is the product of a long-term plan to connect [[Downtown Los Angeles]] to central and western portions of the city with a heavy rail subway system. Originally planned in the 1980s to travel west down [[Wilshire Boulevard]] to [[Fairfax Avenue]] and then north to the [[San Fernando Valley]], a methane explosion at a [[Ross Dress for Less]] clothing store near Fairfax in 1985, just as construction got underway, led to a legal prohibition on tunnelling in a large part of Mid-Wilshire. Instead, after some wrangling, a new route was chosen up [[Vermont Avenue]] to [[Hollywood Boulevard]]. However, a short one-mile branch down Wilshire from [[Wilshire/Vermont station|Vermont]] to [[Wilshire/Western station|Western]] was allowed to remain in the system. The service currently designated as the Purple Line opened in two ''minimum operating segments:'' *MOS-1, which consisted of the original five stations from {{LA Metro station|Union Station}} to {{LA Metro station|Westlake/MacArthur Park}}, opened on January 30, 1993.{{cite news |first=Mark |last=Katches |authorlink= |title=Red Line Rolls to Raves – It's Smooth Railing As L.A. Subway Opens |url= |work=[[Los Angeles Daily News]] |publisher= |date=January 31, 1993}} *MOS-2A, including three new stations between {{LA Metro station|Westlake/MacArthur Park}} and {{LA Metro station|Wilshire/Western}}, opened in 1996.{{cite news |first=David |last=Bloom |authorlink= |title=MTA Unveils New Downtown Line |url= |work=[[Los Angeles Daily News]] |publisher= |date=May 22, 1996}} The Vermont branch began service in 1999. Initally, both branches were designated as part of the Red Line, but in 2006 trains travelling between Union Station and Wilshire/Western were rebranded the Purple Line for greater clarity. == Current and proposed extension == {{Main|Purple Line Extension}} Metro is now aiming to complete the subway to the Westside. The new project is called the [[Purple Line Extension]] (the project was previously called the Westside Subway Extension) and the first phase broke ground on November 7, 2014. Metro released the Final Environmental Impact Report (FEIR) on March 19, 2012, and the first phase of the project (to Wilshire / La Cienega) was approved by Metro's Board of Directors on April 26, 2012.{{cite web |url=https://www.metro.net/projects/westside/final-eis-eir/ |title=Purple Line Extension - Final EIR/EIS |publisher=Los Angeles County Metropolitan Transit Authority |date=February 6, 2013 |accessdate=2013-11-17}} Notice to proceed was issued to [[Tutor Perini]] on April 26, 2017 for phase two from Wilshire/La Cienega Station to Century City/Constellation Station. Pre-construction has commenced. http://thesource.metro.net/2017/04/27/notice-to-proceed-issued-for-section-2-of-purple-line-extension/ Metro is still attempting to obtain funding for phase three. == Station listing == [[File:LA Metro Purple Line Union Station.JPG|thumb|Metro Purple Line train at Union Station. The Metro Red and Purple lines both end at Union Station,
the eastern terminus of both lines.]] [[File:7th Street Metro Station.JPG|thumb|Metro Red & Purple Lines platform at 7th Street/Metro Center Station. At this transfer station passengers can connect to the Metro Silver Line at the street level, or the Metro Blue & Expo Lines above this platform.]] [[File:Westlake & Alvarado Metro Red & Purple Lines Station.JPG|thumb|Westlake/MacArthur Park Metro Red & Purple Lines station platform.]] The following table lists the stations of the Purple Line, from east to west: {| class="wikitable" |- ! width="155" | Station ! Connections ! Date Opened ! Station Parking ! City/ Neighborhood |- | [[Union Station (Los Angeles)|Union Station]] | {{LACMTA icon strip|Red}}[[Red Line (Los Angeles Metro)|Metro Red Line]]

(under construction) | |rowspan="3"|''2023'' |rowspan="7"|None |[[Miracle Mile, Los Angeles|Miracle Mile]] |-bgcolor="lightgray" |''[[Wilshire/Fairfax station|Wilshire/Fairfax]]''
(under construction) | |[[Beverly Grove, Los Angeles|Beverly Grove]] |-bgcolor="lightgray" |''[[Wilshire/La Cienega station|Wilshire/Cienega]]''

(under construction) | |rowspan="3"|[[Los Angeles]] |-bgcolor="lightgray" |''[[Westwood/UCLA Station (Los Angeles Metro station)|Westwood/UCLA]]''
(Pre-Construction Activity) | |-bgcolor="lightgray" |''[[Westwood/VA Hospital (Los Angeles Metro station)|Westwood/VA Hospital]]''
(Pre-Construction Activity) | |} ==Operations== ===Maintenance=== The Purple Line is operated out of the Division 20 Yard (Santa Fe Yard) located at 320 South Santa Fe Avenue Los Angeles. This yard stores the fleet used on the Red and Purple Line. It is also where heavy maintenance is done on the fleet. Subways get to this yard by continuing on after Union Station. Trains make a right turn before coming to surface level at Ducommun Street, and then travel south to 1st Street where they enter the yard. ===Rolling stock=== The Purple Line uses [[Breda A650]] {{convert|75|ft|m|adj=on}} electric [[multiple unit]] cars built by [[Società Italiana Ernesto Breda|Breda]] in [[Italy]]. Trains usually run in four-car consists during peak hours and two-car consists outside of peak hours. The acceleration for cars #531 and up is similar to that of cars used by the [[Washington Metro rolling stock|Washington Metro]] because they both use [[General Electric]] [[traction motor]]s.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ob9oItpOyEc&feature=related Red line train][https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nlutTFq4WjA&feature=related Washington Metro train] The cars are maintained in a Metro yard on Santa Fe Drive near 4th Street alongside the [[Los Angeles River]] in Downtown Los Angeles. In March 2017, Metro ordered new [[CRRC HR4000]] railcars, some of which will operate on the Purple Line once the extension is completed.{{cite web | url=http://www.progressiverailroading.com/mechanical/news/LA-Metro-inks-pact-with-CRRC-for-up-to-282-new-rail-cars--51154 | title=L.A. Metro inks pact with CRRC for up to 282 new rail cars | publisher=Progressive Railroading | date=March 24, 2017 | accessdate=March 24, 2017}} ==See also== * [[Purple Line Extension]] * [[Red Line (Los Angeles Metro)]] * [[Los Angeles County Metro Rail]] * [[Los Angeles County Metropolitan Transportation Authority]] == References == {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Attached KML |display=title,inline}} {{commons category|LACMTA Purple Line}} *[https://www.metro.net/riding_metro/purple_line.htm Purple Line homepage] *[https://www.metro.net/riding_metro/bus_overview/images/802.pdf Purple Line schedule] {{Metro Red Line navbox}} {{Los Angeles County Metropolitan Transportation Authority}} {{USSubway}} {{Public Transportation in Greater Los Angeles}} [[Category:Purple Line (Los Angeles Metro)| 01]] [[Category:Los Angeles Metro Rail lines]] [[Category:Public transportation in Los Angeles]] [[Category:Public transportation in Los Angeles County, California]] [[Category:Central Los Angeles]] [[Category:Downtown Los Angeles]] [[Category:Koreatown, Los Angeles]] [[Category:Mid-Wilshire, Los Angeles]] [[Category:Wilshire Boulevard]]

The '''SKS process''' is a framework of Stop/Keep-doing/Start that is used to collect or categorize feedback.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Beck|first1=Catherine|last2=D'Elia|first2=Paul|last3=Lamond|first3=Michael|title=Easy and Effective Professional Development: The Power of Peer Observation to Improve Teaching|date=September 14, 2014|publisher=Routledge|location=London|isbn=978-1138023918|edition=1}}</ref>
You can ask customers or colleagues:<ref>{{cite web|last1=DeLong|first1=Thomas|title=Three Questions for Effective Feedback|url=https://hbr.org/2011/08/three-questions-for-effective-feedback|website=Harvard Business Review|publisher=Harvard Business Review|accessdate=21 January 2016}}</ref> * What should I stop doing? * What should I keep doing? * What should I start doing?
[[File:Traffic lights icon.svg|10px|left|Traffic Light]] Alternatively, you can develop conclusions and present them using a traffic light icon as the activities that an organization should ''stop'' (red light), ''continue'' (yellow light), or ''start'' (green light).<ref>{{cite web|last1=Korostoff|first1=Kathryn|title=“Mission: Possible”: A Structured Approach to Qualitative Analysis|url=http://www.researchrockstar.com/mission-possible-a-structured-approach-to-qualitative-analysis/|website=Research Rockstar|publisher=Research Rockstar|accessdate=21 January 2016}}</ref>
This approach is also used in [[agile development]], where it is known as Start/Stop/Continue.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Derby|first1=Esther|last2=Larsen|first2=Diana|title=Agile Retrospectives: Making Good Teams Great!|date=2006|publisher=Pragmatic Bookshelf|isbn=978-0977616640|edition=1}}</ref>

{{unreferenced|date=July 2007}}
'''Sales variance''' is the difference between actual [[sales]] and budget sales. It is used to measure the performance of a sales function, and/or analyze business results to better understand [[Market (economics)|market]] conditions.
There are two reasons actual sales can vary from planned sales: either the volume sold varied from plan (sales volume variance), or sales were at a different price from what was planned (sales price variance). Both scenarios could also simultaneously contribute to the variance.
For example: The plan was to sell 5 widgets at $3 each, for a budgeted sales of: (5*$3)=$15. In reality, 6 widgets were sold at $2 each, for an actual sales of: (6*$2)=$12. The total variance was thus ($12–$15)=$3 (U)nfavourable or minus $3, since total sales was less than planned.
== Sales price variance == Sales Price Variance: The sales price variance reveals the difference in total revenue caused by charging a different selling price from the planned or standard price. The sales price variance is calculated as: Actual quantity sold * (actual selling price - planned selling price). In the example, the sales price variance was 6*($2–$3)= -$6 (U)nfavourable or minus $6, since the sales price was less than planned.
== Sales volume variance == Sales Volume Variance is calculated as: budgeted selling price*(actual sales volume-budgeted sales volume)
Sales Volume Variance is further sub-divided into two variances. # Sales Mix Variance # Sales Quantity Variance
==Total variance == The total variance can thus be seen [[algebra]]ically to be (minus $6) plus (plus $3), giving (minus $3). Or: -6+3=-3.
This result tells us that the negative effect of [[selling]] at a lower price was twice the positive effect of selling at a higher volume than planned. This might have occurred where prices were lowered to increase volume, but actual volume increases did not meet expectations, perhaps due to competitors also cutting their prices, or changes in customer preferences.
[[Category:Sales]] [[Category:Management accounting]]
{{retailing-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox Officeholder | name = Susi Pudjiastuti | image = Susi Pudjiastuti.jpg | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1965|1|15}} | birth_place = {{Flagicon|Indonesia}} [[Pangandaran]], [[West Java]], [[Indonesia]] | deathdate = | deathplace = | yearsactive = | order = | president = [[Joko Widodo]] | office = 6th [[Ministry of Maritime Affairs and Fisheries (Indonesia)|Minister of Maritime Affairs and Fisheries of Indonesia]] | term_start = 27 October 2014 | term_end = | predecessor = Sharif Cicip Sutarjo | successor = | order2 = | alma_mater = [[Diponegoro University]] ([[Honorary degree|Dr.h.c.]]) | occupation = Head Minister of Maritime Affairs and Fisheries Indonesia | nationality = {{Flag|Indonesia}}n | religion = [[Sunni Islam]] | parents = [[Hajji|H.]] Ahmad Karlan (Father)
[[Hajji|Hj.]] Suwuh Lasminah (Mother) | influences = | influenced = }} '''Susi Pudjiastuti''' (born 15 January 1965) is an [[Indonesia]]n entrepreneur. She is [[Indonesia]]'s [[Minister (government)|Minister]] of [[Ministry of Marine Affairs and Fisheries (Indonesia)|Maritime Affairs and Fisheries]] under President [[Joko Widodo]]'s 2014-2019 [[Working Cabinet (Joko Widodo)|Working Cabinet]].{{cite web | url=https://blogs.wsj.com/indonesiarealtime/2014/12/04/a-fish-a-plane-whats-the-tattoo-on-susi-pudjiastutis-leg/ | title=A Fish? A Plane? What’s the Tattoo on Susi Pudjiastuti’s Leg? | work=Wall Street Journal | date=4 December 2014 | accessdate=17 December 2014 | author=Schonhardt, Sara}} She is also the owner of PT ASI Pudjiastuti Marine Product, a seafood export company, and PT ASI Pudjiastuti Aviation, which operates [[Susi Air]] charter airline.{{cite web | url=http://industri.bisnis.com/read/20130501/98/11824/susi-air-bidik-pendapatan-rp400-miliar-pada-2013 | title=Susi Air Bidik Pendapatan Rp400 Miliar Pada 2013 | work=Industri Bisnis | date=1 May 2013 | accessdate=17 December 2014 | author=Wedo, Henrykus F. Nuwa}}{{cite web | url=http://www.tribunnews.com/nasional/2014/10/26/profil-menteri-kelautan-dan-perikanan-susi-pudjiastuti | title=Profil Menteri Kelautan dan Perikanan Susi Pudjiastuti | work=Tribune News | date=26 October 2014 | accessdate=17 December 2014 | author=Widianto, Willy}} ==Early life, family, and education== Pudjiastuti was born 15 January 1965, in [[Pangandaran]], [[West Java]], the daughter of [[Hajji|Haji]] Ahmad Karlan and [[Hajji|Hajjah]] Suwuh Lasminah. She is [[Javanese people|Javanese]], but her family are fifth-generation settlers of Pangandaran which is predominantly [[Sundanese people|Sundanese]]. Her family business was engaged primarily in [[real estate]] and [[livestock]] farming.{{cite web | url=http://edukasi.kompasiana.com/2014/11/11/keuletan-dan-ketekunan-bisa-mengalahan-budi-pekerti-belajar-dari-menteri-susi-pudjiastuti-685942.html | title=Keuletan dan Ketekunan Bisa "Mengalahkan" Fanatisme Pendidikan Budi Pekerti (Belajar Dari Sosok Menteri Susi Pudjiastuti) | work=Kompasiana | date=11 November 2014 | accessdate=17 December 2014 | author=Mengkaka, Blasius | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141218053216/http://edukasi.kompasiana.com/2014/11/11/keuletan-dan-ketekunan-bisa-mengalahan-budi-pekerti-belajar-dari-menteri-susi-pudjiastuti-685942.html | archivedate=18 December 2014 | df=dmy-all }} Following [[junior high school]], Pudjiastuti continued [[senior high school]] at SMA Negeri 1 Yogyakarta, but did not complete her studies after she was expelled for political activism in the Golput (Golongan Putih, or [[Absentee ballot|absenteeism]] in protest of [[Golkar]] rule) movement, which was banned under then President [[Suharto]]'s [[New Order (Indonesia)|New Order]].{{cite web | url=http://www.merdeka.com/politik/ini-penyebab-menteri-susi-pudjiastuti-cuma-berijazah-smp.html | title=Ini penyebab Menteri Susi Pudjiastuti cuma berijazah SMP | work=Merdeka | date=27 October 2014 | accessdate=17 December 2014 | author=Simanjuntak, Laurencius }} Pudjiastuti was the first Indonesian minister to have never completed a high school education,{{cite web | url=http://www.indopos.co.id/2014/10/susi-pudjiastuti-pengusaha-sukses-tak-lulus-sma-bisa-jadi-menteri.html | title=Susi Pudjiastuti, Pengusaha Sukses Tak Lulus SMA Bisa Jadi Menteri | work=Indopos | date=27 October 2014 | accessdate=17 December 2014 | author=Kurniawan, Aryo | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141218065931/http://www.indopos.co.id/2014/10/susi-pudjiastuti-pengusaha-sukses-tak-lulus-sma-bisa-jadi-menteri.html | archivedate=18 December 2014 | df=dmy-all }} although after she became a government minister she enrolled for a late high school program (''Paket C'') and she officially graduated in 2018.{{cite news |last1=Hermansyah |first1=Dadang |title=Menteri Susi Lulus Ujian Paket C dan Dapat Ijazah Setara SMA |url=https://news.detik.com/berita/4113497/menteri-susi-lulus-ujian-paket-c-dan-dapat-ijazah-setara-sma |accessdate=13 July 2018 |work=detiknews |date=13 July 2018 |language=id}} Susi Pudjiastuti has three children, Panji Hilmansyah, Nadine Kaiser, and Alvy Xavier.{{cite web | url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/susi-air-and-mechtronix-team-up-to-develop-cessna-grand-caravan-simulator-117231718.html| title=SUSI AIR AND MECHTRONIX TEAM UP TO DEVELOP CESSNA GRAND CARAVAN SIMULATOR | work=PR News Wire | date=2 March 2014 | accessdate=18 December 2014}} Her first son, Panji Hilmansyah, died aged 31 at January 2016 in [[Florida]] due to [[heart failure]].http://news.detik.com/berita/3120507/almarhum-panji-hilmansyah-insinyur-pesawat-terbang-putra-menteri-susi Susi is divorced and is known to have tattoos and be a chain-smoker.{{cite news | url=https://www.economist.com/special-report/2016/02/27/the-13466-island-problem | date=27 February 2016 | work=The Economist | title=The 13,466-island problem | accessdate=15 September 2018 }} ==Entrepreneurship and Susi Air== In 1983 Pudjiastuti embarked on a career as an entrepreneur, starting as a [[seafood]] distributor at a Fish Auction Facility (TPI) in Pangandaran.{{cite web | url=http://www.globalindonesianvoices.com/17051/who-is-susi-pudjiastuti-indonesias-marine-and-fishery-minister/ | title=Who is Susi Pudjiastuti, Indonesia’s Marine and Fishery Minister? | work=Indopos | date=27 October 2014 | accessdate=17 December 2014 }} Her distributorship evolved into a seafood processing plant in 1996 named PT ASI Pudjiastuti Marine Product which specialized in export-quality [[lobster]]s packaged as "Susi Brand." {{cite web | url=http://politik.kompasiana.com/2014/10/30/tak-ada-gading-yang-tak-retak-688678.html | title=Tak Ada Gading yang Tak Retak | work=Kompasiana | date=31 October 2014 | accessdate=17 December 2014 | author=Yuli, Saskia | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141218050913/http://politik.kompasiana.com/2014/10/30/tak-ada-gading-yang-tak-retak-688678.html | archivedate=18 December 2014 | df=dmy-all }} PT ASI Pudjiastuti Marine Product expanded and began exporting its products to [[Asia]] and America.{{cite web | url=http://bisnis.liputan6.com/read/2124703/cuma-tamat-smp-bos-susi-air-mampu-jadi-menteri-kelautan | title=Cuma Tamat SMP, Bos Susi Air Mampu Jadi Menteri Kelautan | work=Liputan 6 | date=26 October 2014 | accessdate=17 December 2014 | author=Dwi Afriyadi , Achmad}} The growing demand for PT ASI Pudjiastuti Marine Product's fresh seafood lead to rapid air transport as a necessity for the business. In 2004, Pudjiastuti acquired a [[Cessna 208 Caravan]] and established PT ASI Pudjiastuti Aviation. The [[Cessna]] was given the call-sign "[[Susi Air]]" and was used to transport fresh Indonesian seafood to Jakarta as well as overseas to [[Singapore]], [[Hong Kong]], and [[Japan]].{{cite web | url=http://politik.kompasiana.com/2014/10/30/tak-ada-gading-yang-tak-retak-688678.html | title=Tak Ada Gading yang Tak Retak | work=Kompasiana | date=30 October 2014 | accessdate=17 December 2014 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141218050913/http://politik.kompasiana.com/2014/10/30/tak-ada-gading-yang-tak-retak-688678.html | archivedate=18 December 2014 | df=dmy-all }} During the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami]] which devastated [[Aceh]] and the west coast of [[Sumatra]], Susi Air, which at the time only consisted of two [[Cessna Grand Caravan]]s, was one of the first responders which distributed food and supplies to victims in isolated areas of the disaster. During this period, Susi Air was routinely chartered in Aceh by [[NGO]]s for [[humanitarian relief]] missions. The revenues earned from the NGO Aceh missions enabled Susi Air to acquire new airplanes and expand its fleet to routes in [[Papua (province)|Papua]] and [[Kalimantan]]. Susi Air is now the largest operator of Cessna Grand Caravans in the Asia Pacific region {{cite web | url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2013/04/29/executive-column-susi-air-a-business-started-accident.html| title=Executive Column: Susi Air, a business started by accident | work=The Jakarta Post | date=29 April 2014 | accessdate=17 December 2014 }} ==Appointment as Minister of Marine Affairs and Fisheries== On 26 October 2014, President [[Joko Widodo]] appointed Pudjiastuti as Minister of [[Ministry of Marine Affairs and Fisheries (Indonesia)|Marine Affairs and Fisheries]] under his 2014-2019 [[Working Cabinet (Joko Widodo)|working cabinet]]. Prior to accepting her appointment, Pudjiastuti relinquished her position as President Director of PT ASI Pudjiastuti Marine Product and PT ASI Pudjiastuti Aviation.{{cite web | url=http://www.tribunnews.com/nasional/2014/10/26/susi-pudjiastuti-langsung-lengser-dari-jabatan-dirut-susi-air| title=Susi Pudjiastuti Langsung Lengser Dari Jabatan Dirut Susi Air| work=Tribun News | date=26 October 2014 | accessdate=17 December 2014 }} She inherited an agency in danger of being eliminated. Foreign fishing boats regularly encroached on Indonesian waters surrounding the archipelago's 17,500 islands. She impounded hundreds of foreign fishing boats and then blew them up. Since taking office, most of the 10,000 foreign fishing boats preying on Indonesia's biodiversity have quit Indonesian waters. From 2013–2017 fishing stocks have more than doubled on her watch.{{cite news |last1=Beech |first1=Hannah |last2=Suhartono |first2=Muktita |title=Indonesian minister doesn't mind making enemies |url=https://www.pressreader.com/thailand/bangkok-post/20180625/282879436483004 |accessdate=27 June 2018 |work=Bangkok Post |date=25 June 2018}}{{cite news |title=Indonesian 'enforcer' helps revive fishery |url=https://www.bangkokpost.com/news/asean/1248922/meet-indonesias-enforcer-of-the-seas |accessdate=27 June 2018 |work=Bangkok Post |agency=Associated Press |date=13 May 2017}} On 16 September 2016, [[World Wide Fund for Nature|WWF]] awarded her the Leaders for a Living Planet Award. This is in recognition of her efforts as Ministry of Marine Affairs and Fisheries in promoting sustainable development in the Indonesian fisheries sector and conservation of the marine ecosystem, as well as her fierce crackdown on illegal fishing in Indonesian waters.{{cite web| title = Susi Pudjiastuti Terima Penghargaan WWF Leaders for a Living Planet | date = 18 September 2016 | work = WWF Indonesia | url = http://www.wwf.or.id/?50982/Susi-Pudjiastuti-Terima-Penghargaan-WWF-Leaders-for-a-Living-Planet | language = Indonesian}} According to a study published in the journal ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]'', Susi's aggressive anti-illegal fishing policies have "reduced total fishing effort by at least 25%, (...) [potentially] generate a 14% increase in catch and a 12% increase in profit."{{cite journal| title = Rapid and lasting gains from solving illegal fishing |last1=Cabral|first1=Reniel B.|author2=et al.| date = April 2018 | work = Nature Ecology & Evolution | url = https://www.nature.com/articles/s41559-018-0499-1.epdf?shared_access_token=0f0Asv4Lo7P6CA7kwiwIP9RgN0jAjWel9jnR3ZoTv0PRh-MpU0vTRaPU4XNu_ty6PpXG9KvG-Nn5n_Og1NcloOQZWPlc45hInonEKvs7oFWh37E9A0Ns-snQqo465Ak9N_l9CjVYu2-NCC3vwIW8LDyBgncd8v0lb7O2vcTR2B0%3D| volume = 2 | pages = 650–658 }} == Awards and honors == * Purwa Citra Priangan Award for Fishermen Life Motivator; by Pikiran Rakyat. 2004 * Award for Tourism Pioneer; by West Java Department of Culture and Tourism. 2004 * Award for Pioneer Fishery Export; by Governor of West Java. 2005 * EY Awards, Young Enterpreneur of the Year; by Ernst and Young Indonesia. 2005 * Primaniyarta Award for Best Small & Medium Enterprise;33 by President of RI. 2005 * Metro Eagle Award, Award for Economics; by Metro TV. 2006 * Inspiring Woman for Development Motivator; by Governor of West Java. 2008 * West Java Best Trader (''Saudagar Tatar Sunda''); by West Java Trade and Commerce. 2008 * The Best Indonesia Berprestasi Award; by PT Excelcomindo Pratama. 2009 * Sofyan Ilyas Award; by Ministry of Marine Affair and Fisheries. 2009 * The Indonesian Small & Medium Business Entrepreneur Award; by Ministry of Cooperative & SME. 2010 * Ganesha Widya Jasa Aditama Award; by Institute Technology of Bandung. 2011 * Award For Innovative Achievements, Extraordinary Leadership and Significant Contributions to the Economy at Women and Economy Summit (WES), USA; by APEC. 2011 * People of The Year 2013; by MNC Group Newspaper (''Koran Sindo''). 2014 * Person of The Year 2014; by ''Warga Kota Solo''. 2015 * First Women to be Minister of Maritime Affairs and Fisheries; by Indonesian Record Museum (MURI). 2015 * ''Perempuan Jawa Barat'' Award; by The Indonesian Youth Committee (KNPI). 2015 * 10 November Award; by Sepuluh November Institute of Technology, Surabaya (ITS Surabaya). 2015 * ''Tokoh Publik Inspirasional Tahun Ini'', Public Relations Award and Summit; by Serikat Perusahaan Pers. 2016 * Leaders for Living Planet Award; by World Wide Fund (WWF). 2016 * Doctor Honoris Causa by Diponegoro University. 2016 * Peter Benchley Ocean Awards. 2017 * Seafod Champion Award. 2017 * The BBC 100 Women. 2017 * Doctor Honoris Causa; by Sepuluh November Institute of Technology, Surabaya. 2017 * ''Srikandi Nekat'' Award; by Retno Sekar Budoyo Foundation. 25 February 2018. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:1965 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Javanese people]] [[Category:Sundanese people]] [[Category:People from Pangandaran]] [[Category:Government ministers of Indonesia]] [[Category:Indonesian businesspeople]] [[Category:Indonesian women in business]] [[Category:BBC 100 Women]] [[Category:Women government ministers of Indonesia]] [[Category:Working Cabinet (Joko Widodo)]]

{{Infobox casino | casino = The D Las Vegas Casino Hotel | theme = | logo = The_D_Las_Vegas_logo.png | logo_size = 200px | image = The D Las Vegas October 2012.jpg | image_size = 225 | coordinates = {{coord|36|10|11|N|115|8|34|W|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | location = [[Downtown Las Vegas]], [[Nevada]] | address = 301 [[Fremont Street]] | date_opened = {{start date and age|1980}} | names_pre = Sundance Hotel
Fitzgeralds Hotel & Casino | date_closed = | casino_type = Land | owner = Derek Stevens (78%)
Greg Stevens (22%) | architect = | shows = ''Marriage Can Be Murder''[http://www.reviewjournal.com/entertainment/shows/marriage-can-be-murder-funny-interactive-affair 'Marriage Can Be Murder' a funny, interactive affair][https://lasvegassun.com/news/2009/jun/26/vegas-pianist-wows-imelda-marcos/ "Murder" moves]
''[[Defending the Caveman]]''[http://www.broadwayworld.com/las-vegas/article/DEFENDING-THE-CAVEMAN-Returning-to-Las-Vegas-20150310 DEFENDING THE CAVEMAN Returning to Las Vegas] | rooms = 638 | space_gaming = {{convert|42000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} | attractions = | notable_restaurants = Joe Vicari's Andiamo Steakhouse
D Grill
American Coney Island | renovations = 1979, 2012 | website = [http://www.thed.com/ The D Las Vegas] | footnotes = {{ctbuh|14137}}{{emporis|122233}}{{skyscraperpage|10282}}{{structurae|}} }} '''The D Las Vegas Casino Hotel''' is a 34-story, 638-room hotel and casino in [[Downtown Las Vegas]] [[Nevada]], owned and operated by Derek and Greg Stevens. The D is located at the eastern end of the [[Fremont Street Experience]]. It has a {{convert|42000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} casino, several restaurants, a business center, and a pool. The casino now has more than 1,000 slot machines and 22 table games located on two floors. It is the tallest building in downtown Las Vegas and the second-tallest inside the city limits, having been surpassed by [[Allure Las Vegas]] in 2007. As Fitzgeralds, it had a "luck of the Irish" theme, with [[shamrock]]s and a [[leprechaun]]. In fall 2012, The D completed a property-wide renovation and rebranding to replace the Irish theme[http://www.ktnv.com/news/local/173676061.html ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121013014631/http://www.ktnv.com/news/local/173676061.html |date=October 13, 2012 }}{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/photos/galleries/2012/oct/10/1009DRooms/#axzz2Y0Su4QR4 |title=Renovations at the D Las Vegas - Las Vegas Sun News |publisher=Lasvegassun.com |date=2012-10-12 |accessdate=2015-09-25}} with a more contemporary feel.{{fact|date=June 2018}} == History == ===Sundance Hotel (1980–1987)=== The '''Sundance Hotel''' opened in 1980 on land owned by [[Moe Dalitz]]. Dalitz, an organized crime figure, faced difficulty from the [[Nevada Gaming Commission|Gaming Commission]], so the casino was nominally run by his associates, Al Sachs and Herb Tobman, who also owned the [[Stardust Resort & Casino|Stardust]] and [[Fremont Hotel and Casino|Fremont]] casinos.{{cite book |author=Michael Newton |title=Mr. Mob: The Life and Crimes of Moe Dalitz |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KZCUIxhP7ikC&pg=PA259 |year=2009 |publisher=McFarland |isbn=978-0-7864-3516-6 |pages=259–260|accessdate=14 March 2012}} In 1983, Sachs and Tobman faced suspension of their gaming licenses due to charges of [[Skimming (casinos)|skimming]]. Dalitz applied to manage the Sundance himself, but the Gaming Commission stalled on his application, until July 1984, when he agreed to surrender management to [[Jackie Gaughan]] until the casino could be sold. ===Fitzgeralds Hotel and Casino (1987–2012)=== [[File:A-2863813824.jpg|thumb|left|Former casino front under the Fitzgeralds name.]] Finally, in 1987, the Sundance was sold to [[Fitzgeralds Gaming|Lincoln Management Group]] (later Fitzgeralds Gaming) and renamed as Fitzgeralds Las Vegas. In December 2001, with Fitzgeralds Gaming in bankruptcy, [[The Majestic Star Casino, LLC]], owned by [[Don Barden]], bought the property, along with two other Fitzgeralds casinos in Colorado and Mississippi, for a total of $149 million.{{cite news|title=Detroiter Builds Out-Of-State Casino Empire|url=http://www.casinocitytimes.com/news/article/detroiter-builds-out-of-state-casino-empire-119934|accessdate=9 October 2011|newspaper=Casino City Times|date=21 April 2002}} At that point, Barden became the first [[African American]] casino owner in Las Vegas.{{cite web|url=http://www.blackwebportal.com/wire/DA.cfm?ArticleID=527 |title=Don Barden, The New Black Face Of Vegas |accessdate=2008-03-05 |work= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071210020045/http://www.blackwebportal.com/wire/DA.cfm?ArticleID=527 |archivedate=December 10, 2007 }} Barden separated Fitzgeralds Las Vegas from the Majestic Star umbrella two years later, to free it from restrictions imposed by the company's lenders.{{cite news|title=Fitzgeralds’ loss widens on occupancy weakness|first=Liz|last=Benston|date=13 November 2003|newspaper=Las Vegas Sun|url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2003/nov/13/fitzgeralds-loss-widens-on-occupancy-weakness/|accessdate=13 March 2012}} In May 2008, it was reported that Barden was pledging the property to generate a $35-million equity stake in a slots-only casino in Pittsburgh, making a sale likely for Fitzgeralds Las Vegas.{{cite news | author=Benjamin Spillman | url= http://www.lvrj.com/business/18721114.html | title= 'For sale' sign could be headed for Fitzgeralds | work=Las Vegas Review-Journal | date=7 May 2008 | accessdate=25 October 2012}} It was subsequently reported, however, that Barden had no need to sell Fitzgeralds to maintain a stake in the slots-only casino in Pittsburgh and that it would remain an asset which he could use to generate cash for his struggling gambling portfolio.{{cite news | author=Benjamin Spillman | url=http://www.lvrj.com/business/24623654.html | title=Fitz off the market for now | work=Las Vegas Review-Journal | date=12 July 2008 | accessdate=25 October 2012}} In October 2011, several months after Barden's death, his estate sold Fitzgeralds to brothers Derek and Greg Stevens, majority owners of the [[Golden Gate Hotel and Casino|Golden Gate]] casino.{{cite news |title=Fitzgerald's new owners plan makeover, new name |newspaper=Las Vegas Review-Journal |first=Caitlin |last=McGarry |url=http://www.lvrj.com/business/fitzgerald-s-new-owners-plan-makeover-new-name-132843123.html |date=29 October 2011 |accessdate=13 March 2012}} Derek took a 78% ownership share, with 22% for Greg.{{cite news |title=Stevens brothers get approval of Fitzgeralds purchase, say they’re planning upgrades |first=Cy |last=Ryan |newspaper=Las Vegas Sun |url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2011/oct/20/stevens-brothers-get-approval-purchase-fitzgeralds/ |date=20 October 2011 |accessdate=13 March 2012}} ===The D Las Vegas (2012–present)=== The new owners completed a $22 million renovation and rebranding to become the D Las Vegas in Fall 2012.{{cite web|last=Stutzlas |first=Howard |url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/casinos-gaming/derek-stevens-integral-downtown-revival |title=Derek Stevens integral to downtown revival | Las Vegas Review-Journal |publisher=Reviewjournal.com |date=2013-05-20 |accessdate=2015-09-25}} the D Las Vegas Casino Hotel stands for "downtown", and also refers to Derek Stevens' nickname, and the Stevens' hometown of [[Detroit]].{{cite news |title=Fitzgeralds in downtown Vegas to become the D |author= |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-505245_162-57396670/fitzgeralds-in-downtown-vegas-to-become-the-d/ |work=CBS News |date=March 13, 2012 |accessdate=March 13, 2012}} The remodel gave the property a more modern feel, including the addition of dancing dealers in table games. The second-floor casino has a "Vintage Vegas" theme featuring one of the only operational [[Sigma Derby]] games in Las Vegas. The multimillion-dollar renovation upgraded all of the guest rooms and created luxury suites. The D also added a fine Italian steakhouse, Joe Vicari's Andiamo Italian Steakhouse,{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.vegasinc.com/news/2013/jan/22/d-imports-new-steakhouse-detroit/ |title=The D imports new steakhouse from Detroit |publisher=Vegas Inc |date=2013-01-23 |accessdate=2015-09-25}} and opened the first [[American Coney Island]]{{cite web|url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2012/oct/03/original-american-coney-island-dog-stand-coming-la/#axzz2XveLhXRT |title=Original American Coney Island dog stand coming to Las Vegas - Las Vegas Sun News |publisher=Lasvegassun.com |date= |accessdate=2015-09-25}} outside of Michigan on the building's Fremont Street frontage. The property also features three distinct bars: Longbar,{{cite web|last=Stapleton |first=Susan |url=http://vegas.eater.com/archives/2012/03/13/fitzgeralds-converts-to-d-las-vegas-with-one-longbar.php |title=Fitzgerald's Converts to D Las Vegas with One Longbar - Eater Vegas |publisher=Vegas.eater.com |date=2012-03-13 |accessdate=2015-09-25}} said to be the longest bar in Nevada at just fewer than 100 feet long; D Bar – a permanent outdoor bar on Fremont Street Experience featuring flair bartenders as well as dancing bartenders;{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/casinos-gaming/properties-fremont-street-turn-permanent-bars |title=Properties on Fremont Street turn to permanent bars | Las Vegas Review-Journal |publisher=Reviewjournal.com |date=2012-06-15 |accessdate=2015-09-25}} and Vue Bar inside the second floor casino.{{cite web|url=http://downtown-vegas.com/hotel-the-d-las-vegas/ |title=downtown-vegas.com |publisher=downtown-vegas.com |date= |accessdate=2015-09-25}} The property's Fremont Street façade was enhanced with the addition of an exterior escalator and interactive video exhibition created by former Cirque du Soleil producer Roger Parent, which together feature more than 40 giant flat-screen monitors combined with hundreds of feet of LED signage.{{cite web|url=http://blog.vegas.com/las-vegas-hotels/a-resort-is-reborn-under-new-ownership-in-downtown-las-vegas-24772/ |title=A resort is reborn under new ownership in downtown Las Vegas | Las Vegas Blogs |publisher=Blog.vegas.com |date= |accessdate=2015-09-25}} Parent is also responsible for the casino's interior escalator which uses LED technology and music depicting vintage imagery to transport guests to the vintage second-floor casino.{{cite web|last=Sylvester |first=Ron |url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2013/mar/07/elevating-senses-escalator-d-las-vegas-features-to/ |title=Elevating the senses: Escalator at D Las Vegas features touch of Cirque - Las Vegas Sun News |publisher=Lasvegassun.com |date= |accessdate=2015-09-25}} In February 2017, The D added an exterior video wall promoted as the "World's Largest Keno Board", displaying a live feed of keno numbers as they're drawn inside the casino. In 2013, the D expanded into hosting [[martial arts]] events as the venue hosted [http://www.lionfight.com/ Lion Fight] 11, a [[Muay Thai]] Tournament. The main event featured a match between [[Tetsuya Yamato]], former [[World Boxing Council Muaythai|WBC Muay Thai]] Japan Champion, and [[Kevin Ross (kickboxer)|Kevin Ross]], an American Muay Thai boxer. In addition, Lion Fight 11 was featured on [[AXS TV]], a company founded by [[Mark Cuban]]. In late 2013, the D became the first casino in the world to accept [[bitcoin]] for hotel rooms, restaurants, and gift shop items. Additionally, a [[bitcoin ATM]] was installed next to the gaming floor where customers can buy and sell bitcoin instantly for cash. http://www.fastcompany.com/3035594/why-bitcoin-is-poised-to-win-big-in-las-vegas ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.thed.com|The D Las Vegas}} {{Las Vegas casinos}} {{Las Vegas hotels}} {{Las Vegas skyscrapers}} {{Buildings in Las Vegas timeline}} {{Downtown Las Vegas}} {{DEFAULTSORT:D Las Vegas}} [[Category:Casinos in the Las Vegas Valley]] [[Category:Downtown Las Vegas]] [[Category:Skyscraper hotels in Las Vegas]] [[Category:Hotels established in 2012]] [[Category:2012 establishments in Nevada]] [[Category:Casino hotels]]

revision.comment: Made a few minor text edits.
revision.text:
{{Insolvency}} '''Trading while insolvent''' is unlawful in a number of legal systems, and may result in the directors becoming personally liable for a company's debts.
Under [[UK insolvency law]] trading once a company is legally insolvent can trigger several provisions of the [[Insolvency Act 1986]], including:<ref>{{cite web|title=Insolvency Act 1986|url=http://www.insolvency.gov.uk/insolvencyprofessionandlegislation/legislation/uk/insolvencyact.pdf|archive-url=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20110709051253/http://www.insolvency.gov.uk/insolvencyprofessionandlegislation/legislation/uk/insolvencyact.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=9 July 2011|website=Insolvency.gov.uk|publisher=UK Statutes Crown|accessdate=29 July 2014}}</ref>
*[[Wrongful trading]] – Section 214 *[[Undervalue transaction|Transaction at an undervalue]] – Section 238 *[[Unfair preference|Preferences]] – Section 239 *Extortionate credit transactions – Section 244
A limited company becomes [[insolvent]] when it can no longer pay its bills when due, or its liabilities—including [[contingent liabilities]] such as [[redundancy payments]]—outweigh the company’s assets. This is a critical point in the lifespan of a company as it denotes when the [[Director (business)|directors]]' responsibilities change from the [[shareholders]] to the [[creditors]]. It also means that the directors need to be extremely careful when considering whether to continue to trade, or not. Any director who knows that the company is insolvent and makes the decision to continue to [[Trade (financial instrument)|trade]], and in doing so increases the debts of the company can be made liable for the company debts.<ref>{{cite web|title=Trading whilst insolvent|url=https://www.companyliquidation.solutions/trading-whilst-insolvent-wrongful-trading/|accessdate=14 November 2016}}</ref>
==Legal issues== In most legal systems, the liability in respect of other transactions only extends for a certain period of time prior to the company going into liquidation. In the UK, directors are exposed in respect of transaction at an undervalue, preferences, and extortionate credit transactions if the transaction occurred: a) while the company was insolvent; and b) within 2 years before the onset of liquidation if the transaction was with a connected person, and 6 months if the transaction was with an unconnected person.
Directors who continue to trade while insolvent may face disqualification under the Company Directors Disqualification Act 1986.<ref>{{cite web|title=Company Directors Disqualification Act 1986|url=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/1986/46/contents|website=legislation.gov.uk|publisher=Crown|accessdate=30 July 2014}}</ref> Under the provision of this act, when a company goes into [[liquidation]], the liquidator must make a report to the Disqualification Unit of the [[Department for Business, Innovation and Skills]] on the conduct of all directors. If the liquidator has come across any conduct which makes the director unfit to be involved in the management of a company in the future (which things would include trading while insolvent) the Department for Business, Innovation and Skills will apply to the Court for an order disqualifying the director or directors from acting as a [[Board of directors|company director]] for a certain period of time.
Many other countries have similar laws, often referred to as 'insolvent trading' or [[wrongful trading]].
==See also== *[[UK company law]] *[[US insolvency law]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Insolvency law of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Business law]] [[Category:United Kingdom company law]]
